The reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.

regionalEffects: The region around the volgoth is warped by its corrupting presence, creating the following effects:

items: Increasingly strange occurrences are observed within 1 mile of the volgoth. Pieces of wood boarding begin to rot. Vermin aboard ships become bolder. Coin and rations go missing. Food spoils at an increased rate. Fish brought out of water release a foul black ichor when cut. Dead seagulls fall from the sky.
Navigational equipment within 3 miles of the volgoth produce inaccurate results, directing ships erratically. Checks made to avoid getting lost are made at disadvantage.

For each hour a humanoid spends 1 hour within 1 mile of the volgoth, it must succeed on a  {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or gain a flaw from the Madness of the Volgoth table, which lasts until cured by a {@spell dispel evil and good}, {@spell greater restoration}, or {@spell wish} spell. A creature that succeeds on the saving throw can't be affected by this regional effect again for 24 hours.

regionalEffects: If the volgoth dies, all these effects end immediately.

regionalEffects.caption: Madness of the Volgoth
rows: Everyone is out to get me. There is no one I can trust.
I am drawn towards the deepest seas. Land holds no value for me anymore.
I am the most capable individual to lead this vessel. No one else is worthy.
I have terrifying recurring nightmares. Sometimes I wake up with scratches on my body. If questioned, I can never recall how I got them.
I spend every moment of my free time staring into the distance in search of a sign.
I'm almost there, only a few hours now. We can't stop travelling. I won't explain where we are going.

legendaryGroup.name: Kalantropis
lairActions: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the kalantropis takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; The kalantropis can't use the same effect two rounds in a row:

items: The kalantropis chooses up to four creatures within 500 feet of it, releasing an agonizing mental scream. If the target is not native to the plane it is currently on, it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes {@damage 8d6} psychic damage and is {@condition frightened} of the kalantropis until initiative count 20 on the next turn. While {@condition frightened} in this way, a target is overwhelmed by the desire to return to its native plane.
Each undead creature that the kalantropis can see can use its reaction to move up to its speed and make one weapon attack.

The kalantropis designates up to three 20-foot-radius spheres within 90 feet of it, which fill with miasma until initiative count 20 of the next round. Each creature that starts its turn within the miasma must make a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is poisoned until the smoke fades. While poisoned in this way, a creature suffers the effects of the {@spell slow} spell.

regionalEffects: Its decaying nature and desire to drive away intruders leave the ocean around the kalantropis an unbearable mire of sickness, creating the following effects:

items: Creatures within 1 mile of the kalantropis are haunted by hellish screams and moans, and feel the dread of being constantly watched.
A murky violet fog extends in a 3 mile radius around the kalantropis. Food within the area spoils at an increased rate, and fish within the area become diseased and emaciated.
Necrotic damage dealt to non-undead creatures within 1 mile of the kalantropis ignore resistances.

regionalEffects: If the kalantropis dies, the screams immediately cease, and the pestilence and negative energy stop affecting their space after {@dice 1d4} hours.

legendaryGroup.name: Storm Manta
regionalEffects: The raw elemental power that an adult storm manta exudes causes changes to the atmosphere around its lair, creating the following effects:

items: Heavy rain and strong winds rage within 1 mile of the manta's lair, accompanied by frequent lightning strikes.

Waves crash against the shore with increased intensity within 1 miles of the manta's lair. When a creature comes near the water's edge in the area, it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Strength saving throw or be smashed against the rocks, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) bludgeoning damage and dragged 20 feet out to sea.
Clouds within 3 miles of the manta's lair form into a slow- moving cyclone, darkening the sky.

regionalEffects: If the storm manta dies, these effects end immediately.

legendaryGroup.name: Seluchin
lairActions: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the seluchin takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; the seluchin can't use the same effect two rounds in a row:

items: Wisps of primal magic flow from the seluchin, casting dim light in a 100-foot radius around it until initiative count 20 on the next round. When a creature casts a spell while within this dim light, it must make on a {@dc 17} ability check using its spellcasting ability. On a failure, the magic recoils against it, and it takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage per level of the spell it cast.

The seluchin chooses one creature it can see within 120 feet of it, marking the creature with wisps of primal energy until initiative count 20 on the next round. When an effect would deal lightning damage to the seluchin, it instead takes no damage and redirects the lightning toward the marked creature, which takes the damage instead.
Gusting winds howl over the water. Each creature within 300 feet of the seluchin that is not in the water must succeed on a {@dc 17} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

regionalEffects: Where the seluchin goes, dark storm clouds and crashing waves follow, creating the following effects:

items: Torrential rainfall and stormy winds rage within 6 miles of the seluchin. These storms are never accompanied by thunder or lightning.
Deep-sea beasts within 3 miles of the seluchin begin to flee the depths, causing them to surface unnaturally.

The surface of the water within 1 mile of the seluchin shimmers with strange arcane lights. When a creature teleports within the area, it must succeed on a {@dc 17} Charisma saving throw or take {@damage 4d6} force damage.

regionalEffects: If the seluchin dies, deep-sea creatures return to their natural behavior, the rain and winds abate within {@dice 1d10} hours, and the arcane lights fade after {@dice 1d10} days.

magicvariant.name: +1 Adamantine Weapon
entries: You have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.
Melee weapons made of or coated with adamantine are unusually effective when used to break objects. Whenever an adamantine weapon hits an object, the hit is a critical hit.
The adamantine version of a melee weapon costs 500 gp more than the normal version, whether the weapon is made of the metal or coated with it.
You have a {=bonusWeapon} bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. Whenever you hit an object with this weapon, the hit is a critical hit.

magicvariant.name: +3 Adamantine Weapon
entries: You have a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.
Melee weapons made of or coated with adamantine are unusually effective when used to break objects. Whenever an adamantine weapon hits an object, the hit is a critical hit.
The adamantine version of a melee weapon costs 500 gp more than the normal version, whether the weapon is made of the metal or coated with it.
You have a {=bonusWeapon} bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. Whenever you hit an object with this weapon, the hit is a critical hit.

Dangerous ammunition crafted from antimatter, an attack made using this piece of ammunition deals {@damage 6d8} necrotic damage instead of a weapon's normal damage. Once the antimatter ammunition deals damage to a creature, it becomes a piece of nonmagical ammunition.

magicvariant.name: Black Ice Armour
entries: Sourced from Icewind Dale, black ice is a substance formed from the dust of Crenshinibon, the crystal shard, a source of supreme evil. When Crenshinibon was destroyed, the remnants of the crystal were flung far and wide, tainting the nearby ice, causing it to become metallic and corrupting. Black ice is mined by the dwarves of Icewind Dale, who are oblivious, or choose it ignore, its maddening properties.

Armour made of black ice confers resistance to cold damage. Any character in possession of an item forged of black ice must make a DC 12 Wisdom saving throw each dawn. On a failed save, the character develops an {@table indefinite madness|dmg} (see "{@variantrule Madness}" in chapter 8 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

Armour made of black ice confers resistance to cold damage. Any character in possession of an item forged of black ice must make a DC 12 Wisdom saving throw each dawn. On a failed save, the character develops an {@table indefinite madness|dmg} (see "{@variantrule Madness}" in chapter 8 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

magicvariant.name: Black Ice Weapon
entries: Sourced from Icewind Dale, black ice is a substance formed from the dust of Crenshinibon, the crystal shard, a source of supreme evil. When Crenshinibon was destroyed, the remnants of the crystal were flung far and wide, tainting the nearby ice, causing it to become metallic and corrupting. Black ice is mined by the dwarves of Icewind Dale, who are oblivious, or choose it ignore, its maddening properties.

A weapon made of black ice deals an extra {@damage 1d6} damage on a hit. Any character in possession of an item forged of black ice must make a DC 12 Wisdom saving throw each dawn. On a failed save, the character develops an {@table indefinite madness|dmg} (see "{@variantrule Madness}" in chapter 8 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

A weapon made of black ice deals an extra {@damage 1d6} damage on a hit. Any character in possession of an item forged of black ice must make a DC 12 Wisdom saving throw each dawn. On a failed save, the character develops an {@table indefinite madness|dmg} (see {@variantrule Madness} in chapter 8 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

magicvariant.name: +1 Black Ice Weapon
entries: Sourced from Icewind Dale, black ice is a substance formed from the dust of Crenshinibon, the crystal shard, a source of supreme evil. When Crenshinibon was destroyed, the remnants of the crystal were flung far and wide, tainting the nearby ice, causing it to become metallic and corrupting. Black ice is mined by the dwarves of Icewind Dale, who are oblivious, or choose it ignore, its maddening properties.

You have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. A weapon made of black ice deals an extra {@damage 1d6} damage on a hit. Any character in possession of an item forged of black ice must make a DC 12 Wisdom saving throw each dawn. On a failed save, the character develops an {@table indefinite madness|dmg} (see "{@variantrule Madness}" in chapter 8 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

You have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. A weapon made of black ice deals an extra {@damage 1d6} damage on a hit. Any character in possession of an item forged of black ice must make a DC 12 Wisdom saving throw each dawn. On a failed save, the character develops an {@table indefinite madness|dmg} (see {@variantrule Madness} in chapter 8 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).
This pale white blade is constructed entirely from a single crystal of salt. You gain a {=bonusWeapon} bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

This sword has 3 charges, and regains {@dice 1d3} expended charges daily at dawn. While holding it, you can use your action to expend 1 of its charges to cast the {@spell salt spray|BelzorMM} spell (save DC 15) from it. Additionally, when you attack a creature with this magic weapon and roll a 20 on the attack roll, you can cause the weapon to release a blast of saltwater, which destroys any nonmagical armor made of metal that the target is wearing.
Within the blade of this weapon shimmers the image of a brilliant nebula. As it moves, the misty appearance of the night sky trails behind it.
You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

This weapon has 5 charges, regaining {@dice 1d4+1} charges daily at midnight. When you hit a creature with an attack using this sword, you can spend 1 charge to fill a 15-foot cube with swirling nebula for 1 minute, originating from you and encompassing the creature. When a creature enters the area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, it is engulfed in ghostly flames that cause searing pain, and it must make a DC 17 Constitution saving throw. It takes {@damage 2d6} radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
A fishbone blade is a sword crafted in form of a fish's skeleton, and functions as a dancing sword. Attacks made with this weapon don't suffer disadvantage from being underwater.
When you speak the sword's command word to cause it to hover, it provides additional benefits while it is submerged in water, as specified in the sword's description.

entries.name: Master's Marlin
entries: When the sword deals damage to a creature, you gain advantage on the next attack you make against it before the end of the turn.

entries.name: Sage's Salmon
entries: When the sword deals damage to a creature, it has disadvantage on the next saving throw it makes against a spell you cast before the end of the turn.

entries.name: Surgeon's Sturgeon
entries: You can use a bonus action to cause the sword to fly up to 30 feet to another spot within 30 feet of you and stabilize an {@condition unconscious} creature within 5 feet of it.
This weapon shines with cosmic light, dispelling illusions and revealing truth. When this weapon comes in contact with illusion magic, it dispels the illusion if it is a spell of 3rd level or lower.

A cleric of the {@class Cleric|PHB|Light|Light|PHB} or {@class Cleric|PHB|Sky|Sky|ATLAS} domains of 10th level or higher can apply the glimmering property to a weapon by performing a 50 hour ritual. This ritual must be conducted within a {@spell hallow|PHB|hallowed} temple, on an altar to the god of the cleric's faith, and involves 500 gp of materials. The ritual must be completed within 10 days of its initiation, otherwise the ritual fails and must be started over.

This weapon has an unnaturally long tip lined with spiraling flutes. When attuned, the tip of the weapon spins at the wielder's command. You have a burrow speed equal to your walking speed and tremorsense for 30 feet while you hold this weapon.
You gain a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.
Additionally, if you make an attack at a creature after bursting out from underground, you deal an additional {@damage 2d12} radiant damage to the creature on a hit.

This weapon has 5 charges, regaining {@dice 1d4+1} charges daily at dawn. As a bonus action while you are holding this weapon, you can spend 1 charge and choose a creature that can see and hear you within 30 feet of you. That creature gains temporary hit points equal to your Charisma score. While the creature has these temporary hit points, it has advantage on attack rolls and saving throws.

As a reaction when you are reduced to 0 hit points or killed, you can choose a creature that can see or hear you within 30 feet of you. If that creature has a free attunement slot, it immediately becomes attuned to this weapon.

This magic weapon emits a cold mist, and is rimed over with small ice crystals. It has 3 charges, and regains {@dice 1d3} charges daily at dawn. As an action, you can expend a charge to slam the ground or the surface of a body of water, causing sharp ice spikes to form in a line 60 foot wide and 20 foot wide, which last until the end of your next turn. The area becomes difficult terrain for the duration. If a creature moves into or within the area, it takes {@damage 2d6} piercing damage for every 5 feet it travels.

You can use a bonus action to speak this magic bow's command word, causing moonlight to glow from the length. This moonlight sheds bright light in a 40-foot radius and dim light for an additional 40 feet. While the bow is glowing, it deals an extra {@damage 2d6} fire damage to any target it hits. The bow glows until you use a bonus action to speak the command word again or until you drop or stow the bow.

This blade has an unusual guard, circular and shining with tiny specks of light. When attuned, the guard spins slowly, and the blade emits a faint light. When unsheathed, this sword casts dim light in a 15-foot radius around it.
You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.
This weapon has 5 charges, and it regains {@dice 1d4+1} expended charges daily at dawn.

As an action, you can expend charges to release a beam of radiance. Each creature within a 5 ft. wide and 200 ft. long line must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 2d8} radiant damage for each charge expended and is blinded until the end of its next turn. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage and is not blinded.

The weapon gains the following ability if attuned by a paladin: As an action, you can expend a spell slot to release a beam of radiance. Each creature within a 5 ft. wide and 200 ft. long line must make a Constitution saving throw against your paladin spell save DC. On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 4d8} radiant damage for a 1st-level spell slot, plus {@damage 2d8} for each spell level higher than 1st, and is blinded until the end of its next turn. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage and is not blinded.
This magic bow is formed of silver, laced with veins of icy blue, and creates ammunition by freezing the water in the air into arrows or bolts.

You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon. When you make a ranged attack with this weapon, you can create one piece of magic ammunition from water within an open container within 5 feet of you. The ammunition created by the weapon melts after it hits or misses a target. When you create ammunition for the weapon in this way, you ignore the weapon's loading property, if it has it.

This weapon has 3 charges, and it regains {@dice 1d3} expended charges daily at dawn. When you make a ranged attack made with this weapon, you can expend 1 charge from the weapon to cast {@spell fog cloud}, centered on the target of the attack. When the spell is cast in this way, it doesn't require concentration.

entries.name: Surgeon's Sturgeon
entries: This savage blade is consists of shark's teeth bound to a staff of coral and decorated with pearls.

A number of the shark-tooth blade's teeth (typically {@dice 1d4}) are marked with runes. The first rune always grants a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. Each rune beyond the first grants the shark-tooth blade an additional property. The DM chooses each property or determines it randomly on the Shark-Tooth Blade Properties table.

You can perform a 1 hour ritual to etch a new rune into one of the blade's teeth, using the blood of a sea creature of CR 10 or higher killed within the past 1 hour. For each rune the blade possesses, the minimum CR required increases by 1.

entries.caption: Shark-Tooth Blade Properties
rows: Increase the bonus to attack and damage rolls by 1, to a maximum of +3. Reroll if the shark-tooth blade already has a +3 bonus.

You can use an action to cast one 1st-level spell (chosen by the DM) from the sword (spell save {@dc 15}, +7 to hit with spell attacks, +4 spellcasting ability modifier). After you cast the spell, you can't cast it again until the next dawn.

You can use an action to cast one 2nd-level spell (chosen by the DM) from the sword (spell save {@dc 15}, +7 to hit with spell attacks, +4 spellcasting ability modifier). After you cast the spell, you can't cast it again until the next dawn.

You can use an action to cast one 3rd-level spell (chosen by the DM) from the sword (spell save DC 15, +7 to hit with spell attacks, +4 spellcasting ability modifier). After you cast the spell, you can't cast it again until the next dawn.
The shark-tooth blade can be used as a spellcasting focus, and you gain a +1 bonus to spell attack rolls and to the saving throw DCs of your spells. Reroll if the shark-tooth blade already has a +3.
The shark-tooth blade gains the reach property.
The shark-tooth blade gains the finesse property.
The shark-tooth blade gains the heavy property.
The shark-tooth blade scores a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20.
Attack rolls made with the shark-tooth blade have advantage against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

entries: Forged from a fallen star in the fires of its violent impact, this hammer is always accompanied by the faint smell of burning ozone.
You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

This weapon has 5 charges, and it regains 1d4+1 expended charges daily at dusk. When you hit a creature with this weapon, you can expend 1 charge to intensify the weapon's weight, driving it downwards with tremendous force. Each creature within 10 feet of you must make a DC 18 Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

Additionally, you can expend 3 charges to cast {@spell reverse gravity} (save DC 18), centered on yourself. When you cast the spell in this way, you are immune to the spell's effect, and the spell ends at the start of your next turn.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The priest is a 5th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 13}, {@hit 5} to hit with spell attacks). The priest has the following cleric spells prepared:

trait.name: Divine Eminence
entries: As a bonus action, the priest can expend a spell slot to cause its melee weapon attacks to magically deal an extra 10 ({@damage 3d6}) radiant damage to a target on a hit. This benefit lasts until the end of the turn. If the priest expends a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the extra damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for each level above 1st.

trait.name: Dive Attack
entries: If the aarakocra is flying and dives at least 30 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a melee weapon attack, the attack deals an extra 3 ({@dice 1d6}) damage to the target.

action.name: Talon
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) slashing damage.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Summon Air Elemental
entries: Five aarakocra within 30 feet of each other can magically summon an {@creature air elemental}. Each of the five must use its action and movement on three consecutive turns to perform an aerial dance and must maintain concentration while doing so (as if concentrating on a spell). When all five have finished their third turn of the dance, the elemental appears in an unoccupied space within 60 feet of them. It is friendly toward them and obeys their spoken commands. It remains for 1 hour, until it or all its summoners die, or until any of its summoners dismisses it as a bonus action. A summoner can't perform the dance again until it finishes a short rest. When the elemental returns to the Elemental Plane of Air, any aarakocra within 5 feet of it can return with it.

trait.name: Incubation Period
entries: 1-4 days

trait.name: Echolocation
entries: The whale can't use its blindsight while deafened.

trait.name: Heated Body
entries: A creature that touches the whale or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 5 (1d10) fire damage.

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: The whale can hold its breath for 90 minutes.

trait.name: Keen Hearing
entries: The whale has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The whale deals double damage to objects and structures.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The whale makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its tail.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}29 ({@damage 6d6 + 8}) piercing damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw or be swallowed by the whale. A swallowed creature is blinded and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the whale, and it takes 14 ({@damage 4d6}) fire damage at the start of each of the whale's turns.

If the whale takes 30 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the whale must succeed on a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 20 feet of the whale. If the whale dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse by using 10 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}26 ({@damage 4d8 + 8}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Sonar Burst (Recharge 5–6)
entries: The whale releases a blast of thunderous energy in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or take 35 ({@damage 10d6}) thunder damage and become stunned until the end of the whale's next turn. On a successful save, the creature takes only half the damage and isn't stunned. A creature made of inorganic material such as stone, crystal, or metal has disadvantage on this saving throw. Objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried also take the damage.

trait.name: Spacefaring
entries: The dragon doesn't need to breathe.

trait.name: Stardust Form
entries: The dragon can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing. In addition, the dragon can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. The first time it enters a creature's space on a turn, or if a creature starts its turn within the dragon's space, that creature takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the dragon fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dragon can use its Frightful Presence. It then makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 2d10 + 8}) fire damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d6 + 8}) fire damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d8 + 8}) fire damage.

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each creature of the dragon's choice that is within 120 feet of the dragon and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 21} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the dragon's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Breath Weapon {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragon uses one of the following breath weapons.

items.name: Starfire Breath.
items.entry: The dragon exhales starfire in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw, taking 31 ({@damage 9d6}) fire damage and 31 ({@damage 9d6}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

items.name: Blinding Breath.
items.entry: The dragon releases a beam of radiance in a 90-foot that is 5 feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 21} Constitution saving throw. A creature take 31 ({@damage 9d6}) radiant damage and is {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn on a failed save, or half as much damage and is not {@condition blinded} on a successful one.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: The dragon makes a Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

legendary.name: Tail Attack
entries: The dragon makes a tail attack.

legendary.name: Twist Gravity (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The dragon shifts gravity around it. Each creature within 30 feet of the dragon must succeed on a {@dc 21} Strength saving throw or be pulled up to 20 feet closer to the dragon.

Formed from clouds of cosmic dust, nebula dragon distinguish themselves from true dragons through their amorphous form. Though they bear no draconic blood, nebula dragons are formed through the thoughts of a dragon, thus inheriting the cunning and greed of the true dragons.

entries.name: Diet of Dust
entries: Unlike their fleshy kin, nebula dragons grow and subsist entirely off a diet of dust and debris. Due to their diet, they age much slower than their true dragon counterparts, only reaching maturity after centuries.

A nebula dragon's physique allows it to combine and construct dust particles within its body into exotic and heavy metals. Nebula dragon produce these metals as a byproduct of their diet, jettisoning the metals they are unable to use for fusion.

entries.name: Created from Chaos
entries: Formed from clumps of cosmic dust, nebula dragons are born of chaos. Their personalities are likewise chaotically inclined, knowing neither good nor evil. Due in part to their isolation from other living creatures, nebula dragon are extremely self-centered, having no concept of compassion, sympathy, or empathy.

entries.name: A Nebula Dragon's Lair
entries: Though nebula dragon usually inhabit the emptiness of space, they sometimes form lairs upon asteroids or moons. The lair is glows faintly with the dragon's own stardust, and is littered with chunks of various metals produced by the dragon's internal fusion. Space whales shy far from these lairs, for fear of the dragon's wrath, but this in turn creates a haven for space squids, which feed off of the dragon's scattered stardust, safe from the space whales' hungry jaws.

monster.name: Adult Storm Manta
languages: understands Aquan and Auran but can't speak

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the manta fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The manta has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Storm Bringer
entries: While out of water, the manta is surrounded by strong winds, which blow around it in a 30-foot radius. The wind extinguishes unprotected flames in the area that are torch-sized or smaller, and disperses any vapor, gas, or fog that can be dispersed by strong winds. The area is difficult terrain for creatures other than the manta, and ranged weapon attacks that pass in or out of the wind are made at disadvantage.

trait.name: Sunlight Hypersensitivity
entries: The manta takes 20 radiant damage when it starts its turn in sunlight. While in sunlight, it has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The manta makes a tail attack and uses its Lighting Strike twice.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 4d6 + 6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Lightning Strike
entries: The manta calls down a bolt of lightning on a point it can see within 120 feet below it. Each creature within 5 feet of that point must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw, taking 16 ({@damage 3d10}) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Lightning Burst (Recharge 5–6)
entries: The manta releases a burst of lightning around it. Each creature within 30 feet of the manta must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes 44 ({@damage 8d10}) lightning damage and is {@condition paralyzed} until the end of its next turn. On a successful save, the target takes half as much damage and isn't {@condition paralyzed}.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The manta moves up to its speed.

legendary.name: Tail Attack
entries: The manta makes one tail attack.

legendary.name: Lightning Strike (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The manta uses its Lighting Strike.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Common

trait.name: Environment
entries: Forest, Ruins, Swamp

trait.name: Diet
entries: Insects

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Average

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Clever, Nervous

trait.name: Carving Claws
entries: Once per Short or Long Rest, the albertonykus can spend 1 minute to destroy up to 1 square foot of nonmagic wood.

trait.name: Standing Leap
entries: The albertonykus' long jump is up to 20 feet and its high jump is up to 10 feet, with or without a running start.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage.

The albertonykus is a tiny dinosaur whose claws are adept at ripping open wood. It uses this ability to access termites and other insects, the albertonykus' favorite meal. Its slender snout and tiny teeth make quick work of entire colonies, and its powerful legs allow it to escape any oncoming dangers.

trait.name: Spacefaring
entries: The dragon doesn't need to breathe.

trait.name: Stardust Form
entries: The dragon can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing. In addition, the dragon can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. The first time it enters a creature's space on a turn, or if a creature starts its turn within the dragon's space, that creature takes 14 ({@damage 4d6}) fire damage.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the dragon fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dragon can use its Frightful Presence. It then makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 17} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 2d10 + 10}) fire damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 17} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d6 + 10}) fire damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 17} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 2d8 + 10}) fire damage.

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each creature of the dragon's choice that is within 120 feet of the dragon and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 24} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the dragon's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Breath Weapon {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragon uses one of the following breath weapons.

items.name: Starfire Breath.
items.entry: The dragon exhales starfire in a 90-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 24} Dexterity saving throw, taking 45 ({@damage 13d6}) fire damage and 45 ({@damage 13d6}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

items.name: Blinding Breath.
items.entry: The dragon releases a beam of radiance in a 120-foot that is 10 feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 24} Constitution saving throw. A creature take 45 ({@damage 13d6}) radiant damage and is {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn on a failed save, or half as much damage and is not {@condition blinded} on a successful one.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: The dragon makes a Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

legendary.name: Tail Attack
entries: The dragon makes a tail attack.

legendary.name: Twist Gravity (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The dragon shifts gravity around it. Each creature within 30 feet of the dragon must succeed on a {@dc 24} Strength saving throw or be pulled up to 20 feet closer to the dragon.

Formed from clouds of cosmic dust, nebula dragon distinguish themselves from true dragons through their amorphous form. Though they bear no draconic blood, nebula dragons are formed through the thoughts of a dragon, thus inheriting the cunning and greed of the true dragons.

entries.name: Diet of Dust
entries: Unlike their fleshy kin, nebula dragons grow and subsist entirely off a diet of dust and debris. Due to their diet, they age much slower than their true dragon counterparts, only reaching maturity after centuries.

A nebula dragon's physique allows it to combine and construct dust particles within its body into exotic and heavy metals. Nebula dragon produce these metals as a byproduct of their diet, jettisoning the metals they are unable to use for fusion.

entries.name: Created from Chaos
entries: Formed from clumps of cosmic dust, nebula dragons are born of chaos. Their personalities are likewise chaotically inclined, knowing neither good nor evil. Due in part to their isolation from other living creatures, nebula dragon are extremely self-centered, having no concept of compassion, sympathy, or empathy.

entries.name: A Nebula Dragon's Lair
entries: Though nebula dragon usually inhabit the emptiness of space, they sometimes form lairs upon asteroids or moons. The lair is glows faintly with the dragon's own stardust, and is littered with chunks of various metals produced by the dragon's internal fusion. Space whales shy far from these lairs, for fear of the dragon's wrath, but this in turn creates a haven for space squids, which feed off of the dragon's scattered stardust, safe from the space whales' hungry jaws.

trait.name: Ambusher
entries: The anglerfish has advantage on attack rolls against any creature it has surprised.

trait.name: Sand Camouflage
entries: The anglerfish has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made to hide in sandy terrain.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The anglerfish can breathe only underwater.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 11}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the anglerfish can't bite another target.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Rare

trait.name: Environment
entries: Urban

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Hard

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Devious, Greedy

trait.name: Antimagic Susceptibility
entries: The gloves are incapacitated while in the area of an antimagic field. If targeted by dispel magic, the gloves must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against the caster's spell save DC or fall unconscious for 1 minute.

trait.name: Extra Hands
entries: If the gloves' Bond Strength is 14 or higher, as a bonus action, their ally can command them to perform simple tasks. This may include opening an unlocked door, holding items, handling containers, etc. You can move them up to 30 feet each time you command them. They can't activate magic items or carry more than 10 pounds.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the gloves remain motionless and aren't flying, they are indistinguishable from a normal pair of gloves.

trait.name: Perfect Transcribers
entries: If the gloves' Bond Strength is 16 or higher, they can be taught to repeat writing patterns.

For each hour spent teaching them, they can learn up to 25 words or a 1-square-foot image. They can be commanded as an action to repeat these patterns. They will continue to do so until they run out of material, or are commanded to stop as a bonus action.

action.name: Multiattack (optional)
entries: The gloves make two fist attacks.

action.name: Fist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 bludgeoning damage.

Best fitting a mischievous master, these gloves take great pleasure in picking pockets and tapping strangers' shoulders. Varying from mittens to gauntlets, these sentient constructs always come in pairs. The few that have lost their masters float through crowded areas, swapping goods from pack to pack.

{@b {@i Retrained Artisans.}}  If a wizard has dedicated time to teach a glove how to write or paint, it can recreate any artwork or writing perfectly once it has transcribed it. These constructs' existence has led to a large amount of counterfeit art entering circulation.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Rare

trait.name: Environment
entries: Ruins, Urban

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Easy

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Clever, Proud

trait.name: Antimagic Susceptibility
entries: The headwear is incapacitated while in the area of an antimagic field. If targeted by dispel magic, the headwear must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against the caster's spell save DC or fall unconscious for 1 minute.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the headwear remains motionless and isn't flying, it is indistinguishable from a normal hat.

trait.name: Speech Siphon
entries: While being worn by a creature that can speak at least one language, the headwear gains the ability to speak all languages known by its wearer.

action.name: Smother
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 1} to hit, reach 5 ft., one Medium or smaller creature. {@h}The creature is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 11}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition blinded} and at risk of suffocating, and the hat can't smother another target. In addition, at the start of each of the target's turns, the target takes 2 ({@damage 1d4}) bludgeoning damage.

Taking the form of hats, masks, or other headdress, these tiny constructs are a common companion to eccentric wizards or deviant druids. They have been known to fetch a high price in magic pawn shops, because their personalities slowly adapt to suit their wearers.

{@b {@i Allies of the Studious.}}  Most often, these hats and masks are happiest when worn during rituals, incantations, or long hours of research. Some of the older, well kept items even continue reciting spells after their masters are silenced.

{@b {@i Mental Connection.}}  Animated headwear has the strange ability to psychically connect to its wearer, and "siphon" their power of speech. Because of this, some have been used when studying languages.

action.name: Anchor Hand
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

First mate of Captain Callous, Anka is a simple ogre pirate who loves life on the High Seas. Although she's somewhat dim-witted, Anka has a good natural sense of direction and is a dedicated crewmember of the Devil's Fin. Anka's most curious feature is her missing arm, which has been replaced with an enormous ship's anchor.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Common

trait.name: Environment
entries: Coastal, Forest, Lake, River, Swamp

trait.name: Diet
entries: Nuts, Fish, Fruit

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Easy

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Childish, Friendly

trait.name: Lightweight
entries: The aquilops is immune to falling damage for up to 30 feet. If carried, the aquilops only weighs 2 pounds. In addition, an aquilops does not sink in water unless it is carrying more than 3 pounds.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d8}) piercing damage.

{@b {@i Aquilops are adorable, rabbit-sized dinosaurs.}}  Their hollow bones and large beaks imply their close relationship to birds, and allow them to drop long distances with little to no harm. They group together in forests near lakes, enjoying the bountiful supplies of nuts and fish.

ac.special: 11 + the level of the spell (natural armor)

hp.special: 20 (Lantern or Trumpet only) or 30 (Hound Only) + 5 for each spell level above 2nd

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell (Hound only)
entries: The archon spirit has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Lantern's Light (Lantern only)
entries: The archon sheds bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet.

trait.name: Rallying Call (Trumpet only)
entries: Once per turn when the archon deals damage, it grants one creature of its choice within 60 feet temporary hit points equal to half the damage dealt.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The celestial makes a number of attacks (or Trumpet uses) equal to half this spell's level (rounded down).

action.name: Greatsword (Hound only)
entries: {@atk mw} your spell attack modifier to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2 + #$prompt_number:min=2,title=Input the spell's level!,default=2$#|2d6 + 2 + the spell's level}) slashing damage.

action.name: Radiant Bolt (Lantern only)
entries: {@atk rs} your spell attack modifier to hit, range 60 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d8 + 2 + #$prompt_number:min=2,title=Input the spell's level!,default=2$#|1d8 + 2 + the spell's level}) radiant damage.

action.name: Trumpet (Trumpet only)
entries: One creature of the archon's choice within 60 feet must succeed on a Constitution saving throw (DC equal to your spell save) or take {@damage 1d6 + 2 + #$prompt_number:min=2,title=Input the spell's level!,default=2$#|1d6 + 2 + the spell's level} thunder damage.

monster.name: Armordillo
languages: understands Terran but can't speak it

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Uncommon

trait.name: Environment
entries: Desert, Forest, Mountain, Underground, Urban

trait.name: Diet
entries: Berries, Insects, Nuts

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Very Easy

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Cowardly, Generous

trait.name: Ball Up
entries: The armordillo rolls itself into a ball, completely protecting itself from attacks. Until it takes this action again to unravel, it benefits from full cover.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the armordillo remains balled up and motionless, it is indistinguishable from a shiny stone.

trait.name: Living Armor
entries: If the armordillo's Bond Strength is 12 or higher, it will attach itself to its ally. It may be "worn" as a helmet, pauldron or similar piece of armor. This grants its ally +1 to AC.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 slashing damage.

To the unsuspecting, an armordillo looks like nothing but a steel pauldron or vambrace. In fact, these friendly monsters serve other creatures as armor, as a way of traveling to new and remote locations.

entries.name: Armored Back
entries: An armordillo is covered in a shiny, jointed carapace that is as tough as tempered steel. When threatened, or during naps, it curls into a ball to present its armor and shield its vulnerable underside. This thick armor is at its strongest when fully surrounding the armordillo, and protects it from nearly all harm. The only true weakness of this defensive posture is the amount of time it takes to get out of it again.

entries.name: Protective Companion
entries: Armordillos seek to populate new locations far from their birthplaces. They are always born in groups of four, and the young gather together in groups that resemble piles of stones until their shells have hardened and acquired their metallic sheen.

Once an armordillo's armor has matured, it seeks out a larger creature to be its companion. It wraps itself around a part of the companion's body, using its shell to protect them. The armordillo will serve its companion this way for years, hoping to be carried to faraway places with abundant food and few other armordillos to compete with. The armordillo has a loyal streak, however, and may pass up opportunities to settle down if their companion still needs them.

entries.name: Fitting Dance
entries: When an armordillo finds a creature it wishes to serve, it performs a dance demonstrating its flexibility and durability—often crashing into obstacles or jumping from high up. If this absurd spectacle catches the target's attention, the armordillo will try to climb onto the creature. If the creature accepts this, the armordillo settles over a vulnerable spot and begins protecting its new companion.

trait.name: Astral Step
entries: As a bonus action, the lynx can magically shift from the Material Plane to the Astral Plane, or vice versa.

trait.name: Planar Pounce
entries: If the lynx returns from the Astral Plane and then hits a creature with a bite attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 11 ({@damage 2d10}) force damage and must succeed on a {@dc 17} Charisma saving throw or be banished to the Astral Plane until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The lynx makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its claw.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 1d10 + 6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Astral Rift {@recharge 5}
entries: The lynx tears a hole in the fabric of space, drawing creatures in. Each creature within 30 feet of the lynx must make a {@dc 17} Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 38 ({@damage 7d10}) force damage and is banished to the Astral Plane. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage and isn't banished. At the end of a banished creature's turns, it repeats the saving throw, returning from the Astral Plane and reappearing in the space it left or in the nearest unoccupied space if that space is occupied on a success.

These strange creatures, appearing like a lynx with vividly multicolored fur and much of their flesh missing, are hunters that reside in the Astral Plane. They venture forth to hunt, or to explore the many wonders of the worlds—and sometimes it's hard to tell the difference.

entries.name: Surreal Presence
entries: Astral lynxes carry with them a portion of their home plane, lending a dreamlike quality to their presence. Their coloration, posture, and even size are not fixed, and often differ from perspective to perspective. Some stories tell of these creatures wandering through mouse holes, walking across lakes, or pawing at the heavens, batting the very stars around the sky.

entries.name: Surreal Size
entries: A astral lynx's size is subjective and inconstant. The same lynx may barely fit through a door one moment, then leap nimbly through a keyhole the next, with observers disagreeing on how it occured.

entries.name: Hunters from the Emptiness
entries: Creatures on the Astral Plane neither age nor suffer from hunger or thirst. Like many creatures that live there, astral lynxes must go elsewhere to grow and raise young. To fuel that, though, they must hunt, and they do so by diving into the Material Plane to ambush prey.

entries.name: Unearthly Patience
entries: The unchanging nature of the Astral Plane negates any urgency in a hunt, and astral lynxes are content to wait weeks, months, or even years for the perfect moment to strike.

entries.name: Planar Attunement
entries: Astral lynxes always know the distance and direction to the nearest planar portal. They can also see from the Astral Plane into the Material Plane and vice versa, allowing them to watch unseen as they hunt or investigate.

entries.name: Insatiable Curiosity
entries: Their intelligence leaves astral lynxes with a second need that drives them from their home: curiosity. They are exceptionally inquisitive, and when not hunting, can be found sightseeing across the planes.

Astral lynxes venture forth from their home to see the wonders of the cosmos. Outside the Astral Plane, they are most commonly seen in places of great beauty, settlements with cultural significance, and sites where powerful things lie. Their innate desire to touch interesting things and play in interesting places can have wildly varying implications, from breaking a single blade of grass to accidentally toppling buildings with yard-wide paws and twists of space.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The astrid's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 17}, {@hit 9} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Elemental Demise
entries: If the astrid dies, its body disintegrates in a burst of light, leaving behind only equipment the astrid was wearing or carrying.

trait.name: Spacefaring
entries: The astrid doesn't need to breathe.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The astrid makes three longbow attacks.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 10} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) piercing damage plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) radiant damage.

action.name: Blinding Teleport
entries: The astrid releases a burst of light, and then magically teleports, along with any equipment it is wearing or carrying, up to 120 feet to an unoccupied space it can see. Each creature within 30 feet of the astrid when it teleports must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition blinded} until the end of the astrid's next turn.

Spacefaring genies that live among the stars, the astrid are tall and slender, with pale skin that glows softly of starlight. Crowned with shining gold and silken ribbon, they fly through the sky in a graceful cosmic dance, leaving a trail of stardust behind them as they pass.

entries.name: Capricious Twinkle
entries: Among the stars, the astrid rarely receive visitors. As such, their tendencies as hosts are rather peculiar. Bearing little concept of wealth, morality, and ownership, an astrid may presume that artifacts and objects brought before it by its visitors are intended as gifts, and will not hesitate to take hold of anything that catches its eye.

entries.name: Hunter of Stars
entries: The denizens of the stars alongside the astrids know better than to trifle with the pale genies. Powerful archers wielding bows of light, with the ability to blink across the sky in chase, the astrid are formidable hunters. Astrid rarely engage with the other genies, preferring the isolation of space.

entries.name: Shine Bright
entries: Playful and luminescent, astrids leap and bound across the night sky, performing a cosmic dance to any stargazers below. From a distance, the dancing lights pose a spectacular show. For those up close, however, the bright lights and stray arrows of the astrid's dance can pose hazardous.

entries.name: Variant: Genie Powers
entries: Genies have a variety of magical capabilities, including spells. A few have even greater powers that allow them to alter their appearance or the nature of reality.

entries.name: Disguises
entries: Some genies can veil themselves in illusion to pass as other similarly shaped creatures. Such genies can innately cast the {@spell disguise self} spell at will, often with a longer duration than is normal for that spell. Mightier genies can cast the {@spell true polymorph} spell one to three times per day, possibly with a longer duration than normal. Such genies can change only their own shape, but a rare few can use the spell on other creatures and objects as well.

entries.name: Wishes
entries: he genie power to grant wishes is legendary among mortals. Only the most potent genies, such as those among the nobility, can do so. A particular genie that has this power can grant one to three wishes to a creature that isn't a genie. Once a genie has granted its limit of wishes, it can't grant wishes again for some amount of time (usually 1 year). and cosmic law dictates that the same genie can expend its limit of wishes on a specific creature only once in that creature's existence.

To be granted a wish, a creature within 60 feet of the genie states a desired effect to it. The genie can then cast the wish spell on the creature's behalf to bring about the effect. Depending on the genie's nature, the genie might try to pervert the intent of the wish by exploiting the wish's poor wording. The perversion of the wording is usually crafted to be to the genie's benefit.

monster.name: Awakened Mug
languages: understands one language spoken by its creator

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Uncommon

trait.name: Environment
entries: Urban

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Easy

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Generous, Impulsive

trait.name: Antimagic Susceptibility
entries: The mug is incapacitated while in the area of an antimagic field. If targeted by dispel magic, the mug must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against the caster's spell save DC or fall unconscious for 1 minute.

trait.name: Fickle Bartenders
entries: The mug can be coaxed into chilling, warming, or flavoring its contents with a {@dc 14} Persuasion check.

trait.name: Novice Alchemist
entries: If the mug's Bond Strength is 12 or higher, it can call upon arcane energy and recreate a liquid it has held for more than 7 days. After 1 hour of brewing, the liquid is transmuted. The new liquid cannot be worth more than 10 gp.

trait.name: Strange Language
entries: The mug can speak if it contains alphabet soup. It will likely use this form of communication to complain about not being full of its favorite beverage, often a type of ale.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit -1} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Spill Over
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 3} to hit, range

{@b {@i 5/15 ft.}} , one target. {@h}4 ({@dice 1d4 + 2}) fire (or acid, depending on the mug's contents) damage. After using this action, the mug falls {@condition prone} and is emptied of its contents.

Awakened mugs live to serve, a truth so literal that they wouldn't exist without it. Conceived by a wizard whose ingenuity was matched only by his laziness, animated mugs possess a spark of intelligence and autonomy that allow them to provide appropriate libations when needed, even without explicit instructions.

Ironically, with that intelligence come some complications. Awakened mugs become restless when shut up in a cupboard or backpack, and tend to act out if not used regularly. They much prefer to wander freely, or wobble along behind their owner during a journey. Fortunately, they come when called—or, indeed, when they expect their master to be thirsty, whether they've been called or not.

{@b {@i Self-Filling.}}  The awakened mug can magically fill itself with various liquids when asked, or when the mug feels like it. The mug can bring its contents to a boil, nearly freeze it, or completely alter its flavor. Flavor alteration sounds like quite the cash cow for tavern owners, who all quickly learn they don't actually get to pick the flavors. Awakened mugs often develop strange, almost fey senses of humor. With masters who can appreciate such humor, a strong friendship quickly forms.

{@b {@i Mixological Memory.}}  Perhaps the most useful ability of the animated mug is its memory. The mug can recall any drink that has ever been poured into it, and recreate that drink when it refills itself. The mug can't recreate the supernatural elements of magic potions—that would truly be nonsense. But, it can fix you a Cosmopolitan the way you had it that one time, while you were hiding from pit fiends in a cave in the lower planes, and that might be just as impressive.

{@b {@i Feud.}}  Awakened mugs have an entirely irrational hostility toward other animated objects. They will take any opportunity to spill their contents on rugs of smothering, animated suits of armor, and any other objects they perceive as rivals. Their complete lack of actual combat ability makes their aggressive endeavors quite the slapstick show for bar patrons.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Rare

trait.name: Environment
entries: Coastal, Lake, River, Swamp

trait.name: Diet
entries: Insects, Fish

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Easy

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Energetic, Friendly

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The axolotl regains {@dice 1d4} hit points at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hit point. If the axolotl has lost any part of its body but is not killed, including a portion of its brain, it can regrow it during a long rest.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage.

action.name: Alien Surgery
entries: If the yetling is within 5 feet of another creature that died less than a minute ago, it can spend its hit points by doing this, and can make two attacks on its next attack action.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d4 + 2}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute.

Axolotls, or "walking fish," are amphibious creatures native to certain remote mountain lakes. Their strange appearance and energetic disposition has made them popular with collectors far from their native habitats, especially wizards who seek them out as curiosities, companions, and experimental subjects. Some clans of lake-dwelling merfolk breed them as pets, and find they are valuable for trade with land-dwellers.

entries.name: Childlike
entries: It is no accident that axolotls appear cute, or seem to exhibit a youthful energy and curiosity.Though axolotls are amphibians, they never "grow up" and become land-dwelling creatures. Instead, they live their whole lives in a phase that is considered juvenile for other amphibians, and never develop lungs to breathe air. The distinctive frilled organs around an axolotl's head are part of its gills, allowing it to take in more oxygen from the water around it.

entries.name: Regeneration
entries: Axolotls have an astonishing ability to regrow or reattach lost limbs and even damaged organs. This effect is not as rapid as in trolls, but sages who study regeneration find axolotls much easier to work with.

entries.name: Magical Mutation
entries: Most axolotls are brown or pale, but those born near strong magical auras can exhibit a wide range of colors. Mutated axolotls may also grow as large as three feet in length, though they do not typically grow more than one foot long.Some wizards breed axolotls and compete to see who can produce the most striking and outlandish patterns. A plaid or paisley axolotl can fetch a king's ransom in certain circles.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The drow's spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 12}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Fey Ancestry
entries: The drow has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}, and magic can't put the drow to sleep.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the drow has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Cunning Action
entries: On each of its turns, the drow can use a bonus actoin to take the {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, or {@action Hide} actions.

trait.name: Sneak Attack (1/Turn)
entries: The drow deals an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) damage when it htis a target with a weapon attack and has advantage on the attack roll, or when the target is within 5 feet of an ally of the drow that isn't {@condition incapacitated} and the drow doesn't have disadvantage on the attack roll.

trait.name: Special Equipment
entries: The drow wears a {@item token of disguise|BelzorMM}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The drow makes two shortsword attacks.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) poison damage.

action.name: Hand Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour. If the saving throw fails by 5 or more, the target is also {@condition unconscious} while {@condition poisoned} in this way. The target wakes up if it takes damage or if another creature takes an action to shake it awake.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: The drow adds 3 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, the drow must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The captain makes three melee attacks: two with its scimitar and one with its dagger. Or the captain makes two ranged attacks with its daggers.

action.name: Scimitar
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) slashing damage.

action.name: Dagger
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: The captain adds 2 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, the captain must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

reaction.name: Breath Weapon (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: Azzakh exhales destructive energy in a 15-foot line. Each creature in the area of the exhalation must make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 2d6} fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The bai ze's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom. It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material or verbal components:

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Rare

trait.name: Environment
entries: Forest, Grassland, Mountain, Swamp

trait.name: Diet
entries: Compliments, Leaves

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Hard

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Chatty, Wise

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the bai ze moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a ram attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 2 ({@damage 1d4}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 11} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Ram
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) bludgeoning damage.

The bai ze is a bizarre creature, appearing as a small goat with the head of an old man. Its body is lined with rows of eyes, and it bears two large horns that grow from its back. Bai ze act as guides for those in unfamiliar places, openly providing incredibly helpful information.

entries.name: Wellsprings of Knowledge
entries: Bai ze are remarkably well versed in the habits and nature of other fey. While guiding a lost or helpless adventurer, they will sometimes lose themselves in conversation, and wander in circles until they've finished speaking. They encourage listeners to transcribe their knowledge, but only if the bai ze is credited as the source of information.

entries.name: Natural Caretakers
entries: These creatures have innate magic that grants them authority over nature. They are able to foster the growth of small plants, and use this power to slowly expand their domains.

entries.name: Tokens of Pride
entries: Bai ze are very proud of the knowledge they've accumulated, and have a strong desire to spread their image across the world. They will offer a talisman bearing their own image to everyone they encounter. Some of them even proclaim these talismans will ward off nightmares and sickness.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Uncommon

trait.name: Environment
entries: Ruins, Urban

trait.name: Diet
entries: Electricity

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Average

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Chatty

trait.name: Light the Way
entries: The balderdash can use a bonus action to shed bright light in a 30-foot cone, and dim light for an additional 20 feet. The balderdash can dismiss this light as a bonus action.

trait.name: Servitude
entries: If the balderdash's Bond Strength is 15 or higher, it can be commanded to perform a simple task indefinitely. The balderdash can perform simple tasks that a human servant could do, such as cleaning, acting as a guide through familiar areas, or gathering simple goods.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Irritate (1/Day)
entries: The balderdash can use an action on its turn to target one creature within 30 feet of it. If the target can hear the balderdash, the target must succeed on a {@dc 12} Charisma saving throw or have disadvantage on ability checks, attack rolls, and saving throws until the start of the balderdash's next turn.

Balderdashes are a series of constructs created by the Ouranos Agency. Often sold as guides, informants, messengers, and companions, each balderdash is given the same personality. All a balderdash requires to function is a burst of electric energy. With enough power, balderdash units are able to last hundreds of years.

{@b {@i Enthusiastic Personality.}}  Every balderdash is given a very passionate and talkative personality. This initially led to a high demand from wealthy shopkeepers and taverns, who saw their balderdash units as outstanding additions to their business. Ironically, many of them go decades without creatures to talk to. This leads them to express overwhelmingly depressive loneliness in an upbeat and happy tone.

monster.name: Basan
languages: understands Ignan and Draconic but can't speak them

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Very Rare

trait.name: Environment
entries: Forest, Lake, Mountain, River

trait.name: Diet
entries: Ashes, Coal

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Hard

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Cowardly, Stupid

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage.

action.name: Fire Breath (Recharges 5-6)
entries: The basan exhales fire in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw, taking 4 ({@damage 1d8}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Fiery Escape {@recharge 4}
entries: The basan magically teleports in a burst of harmless fire, along with any equipment it is wearing or carrying, up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space it can see.

Basan are extremely rare and enigmatic dragons that strongly resemble roosters. Their bodies are covered in warm feathers, and their bellies are protected by thick, scaly plating. Entirely nocturnal, they spend the cold night in search of food to burn before eating. Rumors state that if you hear one flapping its wings, and attempt to find it, you'll only see a burst of flame as it vanishes.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Very Common

trait.name: Environment
entries: Forest, Mountain, Ruins, Swamp, Underground, Urban

trait.name: Diet
entries: Blood, Fruit, Insects

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Average

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Hardy, Nervous

trait.name: Pathogen Carrier
entries: Once the bat has made a saving throw against the {@condition poisoned} condition, any creature that the bat bites who fails the same saving throw is also {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour. This effect lasts for {@dice 1d4} days on the bat.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw or take 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage.

action.name: Echolocation
entries: The bat emits a screech, and each creature within 5 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw or take 1 Thunder damage.
For the next round, the bat's blindsight range is doubled, and it has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks.

Bats are tiny flying mammals that use their webbed fingers to entirely sustain themselves in the air. Long assumed to be malevolent pests or vampires in disguise, in truth most bats are docile and reclusive. Varying species of bats can range from a few inches long to over 5 feet wide. Their most remarkable ability is echolocation, which allows them to find tiny objects through sonic feedback. Their diet consists of mostly fruits and insects; only a few species actually drink the blood of living creatures.

entries.name: Natural Reservoirs
entries: The main danger bats present is actually the diseases that ride on their backs. As social and mobile creatures, their presence can quickly lead to a widespread illness. However, their bodies have adapted to become immune to a large variety of pathogens.

trait.name: Incubation Period
entries: 20-30 days

monster.name: Bennu
languages: understands Ignan but can't speak it

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Uncommon

trait.name: Environment
entries: Coastal, Desert, Lake, River

trait.name: Diet
entries: Fish, Insects

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Average

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Relaxed, Wise

trait.name: Rejuvenation
entries: The bennu's body turns to ash when it drops to 0 hit points, and its equipment is left behind. The bennu gains a new body after 1 day, regaining all its hit points and becoming active again. The new body forms 5 feet above the ashes, granted the area is unoccupied and not submerged in water.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Fire Breath (Recharges 5-6)
entries: The bennu exhales fire in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw, taking 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Long-legged and long-beaked, a bennu would not look out of place fishing on the banks of many rivers—except that in place of down feathers, the bennu is covered in small tongues of blue flame. These burning birds emerged from a world bathed in fire, but came to the material world to feed in its rivers and lakes. They especially prefer to live by bodies of water in otherwise arid areas, such as oases and desert-feeding rivers.
Bennus have long beaks made of a stone-like material, which they use to solve the dilemma of catching fish to eat without getting wet and dousing their own fire.

entries.name: Fiery Feathers
entries: Besides being strikingly beautiful, a bennu's flames provide its main method of defense. Most terrestrial predators are naturally afraid of fire and give a bennu a wide berth. The flames burn as hot as the core of a bonfire, and in dire struggles the bennu can focus and expel this fire into a wave of deadly heat.

entries.name: Rebirth
entries: When a bennu dies, its body quickly burns away, leaving only ashes behind. The following day, the bennu emerges from the ash and is born into the world again.

The bennu's memories and personality persist, but a bennu sees this rebirth as an opportunity for change. Since the bennu has recently died, there is usually at least one mistake the bennu will resolve not to repeat this time around.
Bennus generally enjoy simple lives, but over many repetitions a bennu eventually decides to try something new, spending one of its plentiful lives traveling far and wide, seeking adventure.

monster.name: Bio #133
languages: understands Common but can't speak it

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Very Rare

trait.name: Environment
entries: Any

trait.name: Diet
entries: Berries, Fruit, Meat

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Very Hard

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Brave, Childish

trait.name: Adaptive Body
entries: If the Bio #133 spends at least one hour touching a creature of certain types, its body physically changes, giving it a unique ability. It can only have one adaptation at a time.

trait.name: Aberration
entries: It becomes purple and rubbery, and can cast levitate on itself at will.

trait.name: Celestial
entries: It turns silver and gains a halo. This halo sheds bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light for an additional 10 feet.

trait.name: Construct
entries: It gains clockwork features and does not require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Dragon
entries: It gains clockwork features and does not require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Elemental
entries: Its body is covered in the related element, and it gains resistance to the appropriate damage type.

trait.name: Ooze
entries: It becomes translucent and gains the Amorphous trait.

trait.name: Plant
entries: Its fur is replaced with leaves, and it gains the False Appearance trait (resembling a shrub).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Bio #133 makes up to two attacks: one bite attack and one spew attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw, taking 7 ({@damage 2d6}) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Spew
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 15/30 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d8}) acid damage.

The incredibly rare Bio #133 resembles a small, fluffy canine with a metal pack of fluorescent green fluid bolted onto its back. Created by an unknown team of scholars, these creatures get their name from the number of tests that led to their existence. Having escaped their creators, Bio #133s now race through new environments, collecting knowledge and physical traits as they travel.

{@b {@i Unstable Biology.}}  Bio #133 is far from a complete project. The tube of fluid on the creatures' back contains an unstable substance that has replaced their blood. This liquid makes its body wildly mutable, even allowing it to change its creature type.

{@b {@i Diverse Experience.}}  The more a Bio #133 learns, the more qualities it is able to manifest. Spending time around ooze allows them to become amorphous, and time spent near water grants them gills. Although they have only recently sprung into existence, some of the most well-traveled ones can use globs of their "blood" to reproduce.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionics)
headerEntries: The biote's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 12}).
It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Rare

trait.name: Diet
entries: Thoughts, Blood, Scat

trait.name: Environments
entries: Space, Underground, Urban

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Very Easy

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Clever, Friendly

action.name: Echoing Scratch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 0} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 slashing damage. At the end of each of its turns, the target must make a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving throw, taking 1 slashing damage on a failure or ending the recurring slashing damage on a success.

These small alien creatures are some of the most ambitious and compassionate companions one can have. A biote's single eye is often considered a manifested metaphor, explaining that the biote has only its master in its sight. One odd feature of the biote is the rest of its facial structure: the more time a biote spends in the service of a single creature, the more it begins to resemble them: its hairstyle, mouth, ears, and jaw reform after enough blood has been consumed.

Some scholars believe that a biote is actually just the floating tail, and that the rest of its body manifests to keep the appendage alive. Their psionic abilities grant them several spells, including the ability to float endlessly through the air. As feeble as their attacks seem to be, a creature lacking wisdom will soon find its injury spreading.
