Because the attacks of a biote have a unique echo that affects its enemies' minds, they are forced to relive the attack until they can overcome it.

entries.name: Unwavering Loyalty
entries: A biote lives its entire physical life with the intent to serve a master. Forming some of the strongest bonds in very short periods of time, they try their best to convey their need for a dependent relationship. In this, biotes are aided by their ability to read the thoughts and emotions of nearby creatures.

entries.name: Dependent Biology
entries: Biotes will die within hours if left alone. For unknown reasons, their bodies rapidly degrade without a master: no amount of food or water will keep them alive. They require three sources of nourishment, the combination of which seems nonsensical: sapient thoughts, small amounts of blood, and scat.

trait.name: Immeasurable Density
entries: The elemental is composed of extremely densely packed matter, forming a crushing field around it. When a creature moves within 10 feet of the elemental or starts its turn within the 10 feet of the elemental, that creature takes 16 ({@damage 3d10}) bludgeoning damage. Additionally, a creature within 10 feet of the elemental must spend 2 feet of movement for every 1 foot it moves away from the it.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The elemental makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 11 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Gravitational Pull (Recharge 4-6)
entries: Each creature within 30 feet of the elemental must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or be pulled up to 15 feet toward it.

A star elemental is a glowing mass of starlight with a vague semblance of a face. They are a strange variant of their fire elemental kin, channeling their energy as light and heat. As they are constructed of luminous plasma, direct contact with a star elemental can be dangerous.

entries.name: Denizens of Space
entries: Rather than occupying any of the elemental planes, star elementals can be found deep in space or adrift in the astral plane.

entries.name: Elemental Nature
entries: Like their other elemental kin, a star elemental doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

entries.name: Death of a Star
entries: As star elementals go through their lives, they gather space dust and fuse it inside their body, providing energy in the form of heat and pressure. When the fuel inside a star elemental begins to run out, the pressure inside the elemental wanes, and the gravitational forces of its accrued stardust eventually collapse in on itself. This process forms an extraordinarily dense point of matter, a black hole elemental. Black hole elementals continue as star elementals do, consuming matter to subsist.

entries.name: Singularity
entries: At the core of a black hole elemental lies a gravitational singularity, a region of nearly infinite density where the laws of space and time are corrupted. Forming around the core, a vaguely humanoid event horizon leeches away any light shined upon the elemental, giving it a darker-than-black appearance. Anything that passes this threshold is crushed by the black hole elemental's incredible gravitational field.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Rare

trait.name: Environment
entries: Underground, Urban, Ruins

trait.name: Diet
entries: Organic Material

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Hard

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Greedy, Relaxed

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The pudding cup can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Corrosive Form
entries: A creature that touches the pudding cup or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 1 acid damage.The pudding cup can eat through 1-inch-thick, nonmagical material that isn't glass or stone over the course of 1 minute.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The pudding cup can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

action.name: Pseudopod
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) bludgeoning damage plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) acid damage.

Originally used as torture devices by drow, black pudding cups are a small and weakened version of their former selves. Still capable of eating through solid materials, these tiny blobs work at a fraction of their natural rate, allowing them to be handled briefly under the right conditions. The few that are kept as pets are concealed in tiny stone or glass cases: the two materials they are unable to eat.

{@b {@i Insatiable Hunger.}}  Albeit shadows of their former selves, their hunger remains beyond measure. Their natural urge to dissolve warm flesh makes them a useful tool in unspeakable interrogations. Dwellers of the world below often create devices that allow pudding cups to enjoy a feast of warm flesh until their victims agree to cooperate.

{@b {@i Adapted Servants.}}  Pudding cups, due to their diminutive state, act compliant to those who are too large to consume. Fed well, or commanded by fire, they can form an almost symbiotic relationship with a creature. Their natural habits will shift to cooperate with an arcane master, as long as their master leads them to food. However, unattended or solitary black pudding cups will seek to consume anything nearby, while searching for a larger mass to join again.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The shoal has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The shoal has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The shoal deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Swarm-Like
entries: The shoal can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny fish.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The shoal can breathe only underwater.

action.name: Bites
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 0 ft., one target. {@h}35 ({@damage 10d6}) piercing damage, or 17 ({@damage 5d6}) piercing damage if the shoal has half of its hit points or fewer.

monster.name: Blessling
languages: understands Celestial but can't speak it

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The blessling's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom. It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material or somatic components:

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Rare

trait.name: Environment
entries: Coastal, Desert, Forest, Grasslands, Mountain, Urban

trait.name: Diet
entries: Berries, Insects, Nuts

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Easy

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Friendly, Generous

These tiny celestial birds wander the mortal and eternal realms alike, seeking to help whoever they can. Many an adventurer has been called back from the brink of death by the chiming of a blessling's song.

A blessling resembles a metallic kiwi, whose head appears to be covered by a brass bell. The bell is actually a natural part of their head, and its vibrations amplify the songs of each blessling. A common myth is that a dying warrior will hear one of two bells; a toll for the dead, or the chime of blessing. As they work to do good in the world, blesslings form strong friendships—both with those they have helped, and with others who share their benevolent perspective. If nothing else, one could assume that blesslings enjoy the safety that companionship brings.

{@b {@i Blessed Bell.}}  A blessling's song sounds like the chiming of small bells backed by a soft, distant choir. Blesslings know several songs that work a variety of helpful magic, from repairing the injured to guiding the lost. They do not only choose to affect the world through magic, however. A blessling knows the healing power of a cheerful song, or an act of kindness.

{@b {@i Immortal but Fragile.}}  Blesslings do not age, and with enough luck a blessling could live until the final day. Sadly, their tiny immortal bodies are anything but durable, and their calling to help creatures in need brings them close to dangerous situations. A blessling will usually keep its distance from situations where it might come to harm, such as active battles, preferring to drift in when the danger is gone and give aid to the survivors. But many are not so lucky, and a single blow could banish the power of the defenseless celestial.

monster.name: Blood Acher
senses: {@b {@i tremorsense 30 ft.}}  (blind beyond this radius, see bloodsight)
languages: understands Infernal but can't speak it

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Common

trait.name: Environment
entries: Mountain, Underground

trait.name: Diet
entries: Blood

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Hard

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Aggressive, Cruel

trait.name: Bloodsight
entries: If a creature that can bleed is damaged within 600 feet of a blood acher, the blood acher learns that creature's location. Until the creature is healed, the blood acher knows the fastest route to the creature, and has advantage on all survival checks made to find them.

trait.name: Life Drain
entries: Whenever a blood acher deals damage to another creature, the blood acher can use a bonus action to heal a number of hit points equal to its Constitution modifier.

action.name: Body Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage. If the target is a medium or smaller creature, it becomes {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 14}).

action.name: Quill
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 30/60 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage.

action.name: Siphon
entries: The blood acher targets one creature it has {@condition grappled}. The target must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw, taking 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

Blood achers are vicious hunters perfectly adapted to drinking the blood of their prey. They are covered with hollow quills through which they extract a victim's blood, sometimes draining a creature entirely in a few seconds. Blood achers are native to the abyssal realms where constant warfare and suffering keeps them fed, but some have migrated to the Material Plane to find less crowded hunting grounds.

Blood achers often make their homes in dangerous, remote locations. They can become dormant for years between feedings, awakening only when they sense a meal nearby. However, they can quickly infest places where blood flows in large quantities, such as slaughterhouses or the lairs of vampire covens.

entries.name: Blood Sense
entries: Blood achers can accurately detect blood, whether inside or outside of a living body, even in tiny amounts. If they perceive a source of blood they will rush towards it, spines forward, in a sort of charging feeding frenzy.

entries.name: Echolocation
entries: Blood achers are blind, except for their blood sense. They roughly perceive their surroundings by scraping and tapping their spines together and sensing the echoes. They use the same sounds to communicate, in the rare situations where blood is plentiful enough for them to cooperate.

entries.name: Harm and Healing
entries: Although one could not ask for a less pleasant companion, some healers have learned to harvest a blood acher's many secretions for medical uses. Blood achers use several different substances to quicken blood flow or slow it, to dull pain or amplify it, depending on what they need for particular prey. "Domesticated" blood achers are best kept in cages and handled with extreme caution.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Uncommon

trait.name: Environment
entries: Forest, Grassland, Swamp

trait.name: Diet
entries: Sunlight

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Hard

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Hardy, Relaxed

trait.name: Sun Charge
entries: For each hour the bloom crawler spends under direct sunlight, it regains {@dice 1d4} hit points.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bloom crawler makes two tendril attacks or one seed spit attack.

action.name: Tendrils
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Seed Spit
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 3} to hit, range 20/40 ft., up to three targets. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage.

The bloom crawler is an unusual plant that bears an uncanny resemblance to a toad. They are strong and hardy creatures that often choose to ignore fights they're capable of winning. Left to itself, a bloom crawler uses its power of locomotion to follow the sun, always staying where the light is most direct. They trample meandering trails through their forests, and unwary travelers may find themselves following a bloom crawler in circles, mistakenly assuming they've found a game trail.

{@b {@i Diverse Diet.}}  Bloom crawlers get nearly all of their energy from sunlight, but as they follow the sun they also graze indiscriminately, swallowing grass and soil alike. They use viney tendrils to smack bugs out of the air around them, devouring anything that sticks to the vines. Oddly, they can't digest the seeds of fruit or other vegetation, and instead carry them alongside its own seeds.

{@b {@i Vegetative Defenses.}}  Being energetic piles of vegetation, bloom crawlers sometimes must defend themselves against creatures that would nibble on them. Instead of using the force of its full body, or its toothy maw, a bloom crawler uses its vine tendrils to rapidly whip enemies. It can also spit its seeds with great force, which is useful in propagating its species but also serves as a weapon that dissuades most threats.

{@b {@i Animal Helpers.}}  Although they can fend off most large herbivores, bloom crawlers often find themselves overwhelmed by insects they simply can't manage. Bloom crawlers encourage birds to visit their leaves to help eat the bugs that vex them, creating a partnership that benefits both. More intelligent creatures have learned to take advantage of this need, learning that the bloom crawler will follow any creature that helps it clean its leaves. Some communities of wood elves have used this trick to gather bloom crawlers into semi-domesticated herds.

monster.name: Bonsai Treant
languages: understands Common and Druidic but can't speak them

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Uncommon

trait.name: Environment
entries: Forest, Mountain, Swamp, Urban

trait.name: Diet
entries: Sunlight

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Hard

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Brave, Quiet

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the bonsai treant remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a small potted tree.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bonsai treant makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Animate Shrub (1/Day)
entries: The bonsai treant magically animates one shrub it can see within 30 feet of it. These shrubs have the same statistics as an awakened shrub, except they have Intelligence and Charisma scores of 1, and they can't speak. An animated shrub acts as an ally of the bonsai treant. The shrub remains animated for 1 hour or until it dies, until the bonsai treant dies or is more than 120 feet from the shrub, or until the bonsai treant takes a bonus action to turn it back into an inanimate shrub. The shrub then takes root if possible.

Cultivated in monastic temples and exotic nurseries, these garden guardians are only a fraction of a normal treant's size. The difficult and lengthy process of creating bonsai treants is a testament to the patience and dedication of those who create them. Despite their diminutive nature, bonsai treants are just as bold and caring as the forest-dwelling titans.

{@b {@i Hidden Protectors.}}  Bonsai treants are content with the bodies they've been given and are capable of empathizing with the patience of their masters. They choose to wander temples and gardens, fostering life new and old throughout the halls. If an intruder threatens their home, they do their best to thwart the invasion or alert their masters.

{@b {@i Insightful Allies.}}  Rarely, these companions can be gifted or sold by their creators. New friends will be quick to discover the creatures' gentle yet zealous passion for life. If an ally disagrees with this perspective, or shows cruel intentions toward others, bonsai treants have been known to simply escape to nearby forests.

monster.name: Boule
languages: understands Primordial but can't speak it

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Very Rare

trait.name: Environment
entries: Ruins, Underground

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Average

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Energetic, Stupid

trait.name: Crystalline Diffraction {@recharge 5}
entries: If the boule takes damage from a spell that does not exceed its maximum hit points, it can use its reaction to reduce the damage by half. Once it does this, it can choose up to two targets within 5 feet of itself. Each target takes damage equal to the damage ignored by the boule, and of the same damage type.

trait.name: Natural Attunement
entries: The boule is aware of the location of any gems within 10 feet of itself.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Light Laser
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range
{@b {@i 30/120 ft.}} , one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d12}) fire damage.

These constructs resemble a living ingot of synthesized crystal. Wizards create boules through a ritual that grows a synthetic crystal and captures a spark of elemental life force to give it intelligence. The result is a roughly humanoid crystal with a dutiful demeanor and even more curious magical properties.

Wizards with boule companions insist that the creatures display unique personalities through their energetic movements. They vibrate when happy, become more dense when sad, and are almost magnetically attracted to objects they find interesting. Left to themselves, boules enjoy playing with light sources, refracting dancing rainbows on the surfaces around them.

{@b {@i Spell Prisms.}}  Boules have the ability to split spells cast on them, or through them, so that spells with one target now have two. Boules made of more rare crystals can also subtly shift the effects of these spells in surprising ways, such as refracting one type of energy into another.
{@b {@i Spell Eaters.}}  Boules enjoy being around magical energies, and even having spells pass through them. They feed by absorbing a portion of this energy.
This makes them natural companions for wizards who think organic familiars require too much attention.
Their disposition seems to depend on both their crystal type and the sort of magical energy they absorb. Boules are always excited by the opportunity to experience unfamiliar spell effects.

Fortunately, given that, their crystalline structure makes them quite durable. It is said that the first boule ever created is still in existence, having served many generations of mages in succession.

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Inertial Armour
entries: The golem is considered to be under the effect of a {@spell mage armor|phb|mage armour} spell. A {@spell dispel magic} spell can remove this effect until the golem's next Short Rest.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The golem's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The golem makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d10 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Mind Blast {@recharge 5}
entries: The golem magically emits psychic energy in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must succeed on a {@dc 13} Intelligence saving throw or be {@condition stunned} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

trait.name: Medium Size
entries: When the Brunling is Medium sized it's CON changes to 12 (+1), it's HP formula changes to {@dice 1d4 + 2} and it's speed becomes 30 ft.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Rare

trait.name: Environment
entries: Forest, Grassland, Underground, Urban

trait.name: Diet
entries: Combustible Material

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Hard*when medium

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Greedy, Moody

trait.name: Body of Fire
entries: The burnling can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide. In addition, any creature that touches the burnling or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 1 fire damage.

trait.name: Illumination
entries: The burnling sheds bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light for an additional 10 feet.

trait.name: Water Weakness
entries: The burnling will instantly die if submerged in more than 1 gallon of water.

action.name: Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) fire damage. If the target is a flammable object, it ignites. The object on fire takes 2 ({@damage 1d4}) damage at the start of the burnling's turn, until someone takes an action to douse the fire, or until the burning moves more than 10 feet from the object.

These tiny elementals resemble humanoid flames small enough to fit on a candle wick. They have small clusters of stones around their bodies, which are among the few things a burnling can't consume. They exist in a wide variety of environments, with their only requirement for survival being fuel.

entries.name: Igneous Hearts
entries: All burnlings are tethered to this world by their hearts: small, igneous stones that rest on or inside their chests. However, this stone is unable to keep them alive, and they must seek out fuel to keep their fires alive. If a burnling fails to keep its fire alive, it can be rekindled by magic fire.

entries.name: Fuel to Flame
entries: Burnlings are born inside of volcanic magma, a mass of igneous stone that is thought to be sentient itself. Taking after their titanic parents, these creatures can grow in size depending on the amount of fuel they have access to. Their hunger also grows in proportion, and as a result both their fuel and greater size don't last long.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Very Common

trait.name: Environment
entries: Coastal, Forest, Grasslands, Mountain, Urban

trait.name: Diet
entries: Blood, Nectar

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Easy

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Creative, Nervous

trait.name: Fey Affinity
entries: If the butterfly's Bond Strength is 10 or higher, their ally can roll a {@dice d4} and add the number rolled to Charisma (Persuasion) checks made to interact with fey.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The butterfly has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on smell.

As delicate as they are beautiful, these simple insects ride waves of scent to their next meal. Some spellcasters with strong connections to the fey prefer butterflies as companions, seeing them as symbols of the vibrant life in their homeland.

trait.name: Lightfooted
entries: The swashbuckler can take the {@action Dash} or {@action Disengage} action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

trait.name: Suave Defense
entries: While the swashbuckler is wearing light or no armor and wielding no shield, its AC includes its Charisma modifier.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The swashbuckler makes three attacks: one with a dagger and two with its rapier.

action.name: Dagger
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Rapier
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage.

monster.name: Captain Bartholomew Blackdagger
languages: the languages it knew in life

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The revenant regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn. If the revenant takes fire or radiant damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the revenant's next turn. The revenant's body is destroyed only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Rejuvenation
entries: When the revenant's body is destroyed, its soul lingers. After 24 hours, the soul inhabits and animates another humanoid corpse on the same plane of existence and regains all its hit points. While the soul is bodiless, a {@spell wish} spell can be used to force the soul to go to the afterlife and not return.

trait.name: Turn Immunity
entries: The revenant is immune to effects that turn undead.

trait.name: Vengeful Tracker
entries: The revenant knows the distance to and direction of any creature against which it seeks revenge, even if the creature and the revenant are on different planes of existence. If the creature being tracked by the revenant dies, the revenant knows.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The revenant makes two fist attacks.

action.name: Fist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature against which the revenant has sworn vengeance, the target takes an extra 14 ({@damage 4d6}) bludgeoning damage. Instead of dealing damage, the revenant can grapple the target (escape {@dc 14}) provided the target is Large or smaller.

action.name: Vengeful Glare
entries: The revenant targets one creature it can see within 30 feet of it and against which it has sworn vengeance. The target must make a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, the target is {@condition paralyzed} until the revenant deals damage to it, or until the end of the revenant's next turn. When the paralysis ends, the target is {@condition frightened} of the revenant for 1 minute. The {@condition frightened} target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, with disadvantage if it can see the revenant, ending the {@condition frightened} condition on itself on a success.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Callous' spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 13}). He can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Firearm Expert
entries: Callous has had extensive practice with firearms, giving him the following benefits:

items: He ignores the loading quality of firearms with which he is proficient.
Being within 5 feet of a hostile creature doesn't impose disadvantage on his ranged attack rolls.
If he makes an attack with a one-handed weapon, he can use a bonus action to attack with a loaded firearm he is holding.

trait.name: Special Equipment
entries: Callous wears {@item gloves of swimming and climbing}. While wearing them, climbing and swimming don't cost him extra movement, and he has a +5 bonus to Strength ({@skill Athletics}) checks made to climb or swim.

action.name: Rapier
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d8 + 1}) piercing damage.

action.name: Pistol
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 3} to hit, range 30/90 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d10 + 1}) piercing damage.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: Callous adds 2 to his AC against one melee attack that would hit him. To do so, Callous must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

Captain Callous is a notorious tiefling pirate captain of The Devil's Fin. He is a direct descendant of {@deity Asmodeus|Faerûnian|scag} himself and is one of the most-feared pirates in the Sea of Swords.
Captain Callous has five potential stat blocks, one for each chapter in which the characters might encounter him.

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "I will become the most feared pirate alive."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "The Devil's Fin is my life and was a gift from {@deity Asmodeus|Faerûnian|scag}. To lose it would be to lose my link to him."

entries.name: Flaw

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Callous' spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 14}). He can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Firearm Expert
entries: Callous has had extensive practice with firearms, giving him the following benefits:

items: He ignores the loading quality of firearms with which he is proficient.
Being within 5 feet of a hostile creature doesn't impose disadvantage on his ranged attack rolls.
If he makes an attack with a one-handed weapon, he can use a bonus action to attack with a loaded firearm he is holding.

trait.name: Lightfooted
entries: Callous can take the {@action Dash} or {@action Disengage} action as a bonsu action on each of his turns.

trait.name: Special Equipment
entries: Callous wears {@item gloves of swimming and climbing}. While wearing them, climbing and swimming don't cost him extra movement, and he has a +5 bonus to Strength ({@skill Athletics}) checks made to climb or swim.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Callous makes three melee attacks or two ranged attacks.

action.name: Rapier
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Pistol
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 30/90 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d10 + 2}) piercing damage.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: Callous adds 2 to his AC against one melee attack that would hit him. To do so, Callous must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

trait.name: Demands of Nessus
entries: At the start of each of Callous' turns, he can choose one ally he can see within 30 feet of him. The chosen ally loses 10 hit points, and Callous regains the same number of hit points. If Callous is {@condition incapacitated}, he makes no choice; instead, the closest ally within 30 feet is the chosen ally.

entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 30/90 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) piercing damage.

entries: Callous targets one creature within 30 feet of him. If the target can hear Callous, the target must succeed on a {@dc 17} Charisma saving throw or have disadvantage on ability checks, attack rolls, and saving throws until the start of Callous' next turn.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The slaad's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 12}). The slaad can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Shapechanger
entries: The slaad can use its action to polymorph into a Small or Medium humanoid, or back into its true form. Its statistics, other than its size, are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The slaad has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The slaad regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hit point.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The slaad makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws or staff. Alternatively, it uses its Hurl Flame twice.

action.name: Bite (Slaad Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw (Slaad Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Staff
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Hurl Flame
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 4} to hit, range 60 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage. The fire ignites flammable objects that aren't being worn or carried.

footer.name: Control Gem
entries: The slaad must obey whoever possesses the gem and is immune to being {@condition charmed} while so controlled.
A {@spell greater restoration} spell cast on the slaad destroys the gem without harming the slaad.

Most slaadi are agents of pure chaos that hail from the Plane of Limbo. When slaadi travel to the Material Plane, they create carnage by transforming humanoids into more of their kind. Years ago, Tentrix's vessel came across a town under attack. The pirate flew into a rage after realising his raid could no longer occur, so kidnapped a slaadi in order to ransom them back. When his first mate was killed before the message could be delivered, Tentrix realised the foolishness of his plan. He then tried to kill the slaad, but his blade hit the control gem embedded in its head which he removed, gaining control over the chaotic creature.

Thenceforth the slaad has obeyed Tentrix, who found he could teach it many things, including how to captain a ship. Eventually, the slaad became a notorious pirate in its own right, adopting the identity of Captain Scummer. Tentrix elevated the creature to pirate lord after Scummer sunk a Flaming Fist vessel chasing his own. Scummer would rather not be controlled by Tentrix but has no ambition to retrieve the control gem himself. If the characters retrieve the gem, the slaad accepts their control.

Captain Scummer looks like a bloated, bipedal, green toad with a gaping maw and heavy brow. Scummer's identity as pirate captain is reflected in its choice of attire; a bright red frock coat. Scummer wields an oar, adorned with fish skulls, as its staff. Although Scummer can shapeshift into humanoid form, it does so only to avoid certain death or when commanded to do so by Tentrix.

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "Spreading chaos can be achieved through my new life as a pirate captain."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "I am controlled by Sea King Tentrix, who has possession of the gem which is bound to my soul."

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "Despite my new identity, I have a tendency to revert back to my chaotic nature."

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Uncommon

trait.name: Environment
entries: Coastal, Forest, Lake, River, Swamp

trait.name: Diet
entries: Leaves, Nuts, Roots

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Easy

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Friendly, Relaxed

trait.name: Peaceful Presence
entries: If the capybara's Bond Strength is 10 or higher, their ally can roll a {@dice d4} and add the number rolled to Wisdom (Animal Handling) checks.

trait.name: Relaxing Aura
entries: If there are more than 10 capybaras within 60 feet of each other, they all benefit from the sanctuary spell.

Capybaras are the world's largest natural rodents, slightly larger even than the giant rats that plague city sewers. However, any sane adventurer would rather encounter a horde of capybaras than even a single feral rat, since capybaras are friendly and harmless.
Capybaras live in large family groups, ranging in size from as few as ten to as many as one hundred capybaras. They enjoy the company of other creatures that approach them peacefully.

{@b {@i Water Rats.}}  Always dwelling near bodies of water, capybaras are excellent swimmers. They are so at home in the water that they can even sleep while submerged, with only their noses above the surface.

{@b {@i Soothing Nature.}}  One legend speaks of a great hunter spirit, who fired an arrow that missed its quarry. The spirit searched for the arrow for days, becoming more and more frustrated as time passed. It was a humble capybara who spoke soothingly to the god, allowing them to relax and think unclouded by frustration. The spirit then made enough arrows to fill a dozen quivers using materials from the forest. Whether or not the tale is true, the rotund and placid capybara exudes a sense of calm that extends to the creatures around it. It is simply hard to stay angry in the company of a capybara.

monster.name: Cat
languages: understands Common but can't speak it

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Very Common

trait.name: Environment
entries: Forest, Mountain, Urban

trait.name: Diet
entries: Fish, Meat

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Average

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Proud, Stinky

trait.name: Keen Senses
entries: The cat has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Lithe Form
entries: Cats are immune to falling damage for up to 60 ft.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage. If the target is a tiny creature, it is also {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 8}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the cat can't bite another target.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 slashing damage.

These small predators have found great enjoyment from domesticating humanoids, acting as gods while they are fed whatever they desire. People of all stations keep them as companions, from proud lords to lonely peasants. The quiet and the bookish tend to especially enjoy their company, as observing their behavior can be enlightening to the attentive.

Some suppose that cats are not intelligent, as they seem incapable of communicating or following any given commands. In actuality, they see all other creatures as simple animals, and find no reason to form meaningful relationships they can't benefit from.

Independent hunters at heart, cats are known for their aloof attitude, even toward creatures they genuinely like. They are often too proud to admit a deep attachment with a non-feline creature, even if they happen to curl up next to that creature to sleep on a regular basis.

{@b {@i Mousers.}}  Cats passionately hunt small animals such as birds, rodents, lizards, and large insects. This makes them useful pets in places where humanoids have trouble keeping vermin under control, like farms, granaries, market stalls, gardens, or anywhere they cause damage. Cats hunt by stealth, relying on their keen hearing and smell to find prey. Their eyes can see in near darkness, and they are most active in the twilight hours.

{@b {@i Risky Agility.}}  Cats have a reputation for getting into trouble with their curiosity, and out of it again with their quick reflexes, guile, and sheer luck. Cats are famous for their ability to land feet-first. A cat that falls more than a few feet will right itself in the air, landing on its feet and rarely suffering any harm, even after falling from great heights. Legend speaks of a wizard who tied two cats together, back-to-back, causing them to rapidly spin in the air to generate power for their rituals.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Ceirean's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 24}, {@hit 16} to hit with spell attacks). Ceirean can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

trait.name: Shapechanger
entries: Ceirean can use its action to polymorph into a Tiny silver fish (swimming speed 30 ft.) or back into its true form. Its statistics are the same in each form, except for the speed change noted. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: Ceirean can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Divine Awareness
entries: Ceirean knows if it hears a lie.

trait.name: Glass Aversion (Fish Form Only)
entries: If Ceirean is sealed within a container made of glass, it is {@condition incapacitated} until it is removed from the container.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Ceirean fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Limited Magic Immunity
entries: Ceirean can't be affected or detected by spells of 6th level or lower unless it wishes to be. It has advantage on saving throws against all other spells and magical effects.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: Ceirean deals double damage to objects and structures.

action.name: Swallow (True Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 16} to hit, reach 5 ft., one Huge or smaller target. {@h}The target is swallowed by Ceirean. A swallowed creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained} and has total cover against attacks and other effects outside of Ceirean. Ceirean can deal 35 ({@damage 10d6}) radiant damage to each swallowed creature of its choice at the start of its turn.

If Ceirean takes 50 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, Ceirean must succeed on a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of Ceirean. If Ceirean dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse by using 10 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

action.name: Spit (True Form Only)
entries: One target swallowed by Ceirean is regurgitated up to 120 feet in a direction of Ceirean's choice and knocked {@condition prone}. If a regurgitated target strikes an object, the target and object each take 3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet the target was regurgitated. If the target is thrown at another creature, that creature must succeed on a {@dc 24} Dexterity saving throw or take the same damage and be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Slam (True Form Only)
entries: Ceirean slams its body down in a 30-foot-cube originating from it. Each creature in the area must succeed on a {@dc 24} Strength or Dexterity saving throw (target's choice) or be knocked {@condition prone} and take 63 ({@damage 10d10 + 8}) bludgeoning damage. On a successful save, the creature takes no damage, isn't knocked {@condition prone}, and is pushed into the nearest unoccupied space outside the area.

action.name: Divine Blessing (3/Day)
entries: Ceirean places a divine boon on one creature it can see within 60 feet of it, choosing one ability. The target has advantage on all ability checks, saving throws, and attack rolls that use that ability for 24 hours, until Ceirean revokes the boon (no action required), or until Ceirean dies. The target also gains an additional benefit based on the while blessed, based on the chosen ability:
{@b Strength.} The target is considered to be a Gargantuan creature for the purpose of determining its carrying capacity and it can't be pushed or knocked {@condition prone}.
{@b Dexterity.} The target's speed is doubled and it can take one reaction on every turn in a combat.
{@b Constitution.} The target it is immune to poison and disease and regains the maximum number of hit points possible from any healing.
{@b Intelligence.} The target automatically detects visual illusions and succeeds on saving throws against them.
{@b Wisdom.} The target can't be {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened} and magically knows if it hears a lie.
{@b Charisma.} The target can cast {@spell command} (save {@dc 24}) without expending a spell slot.

legendary.name: Move
entries: Ceirean moves up to half its speed.

legendary.name: Attack (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Ceirean makes a swallow attack or uses its Slam or Spit.

legendary.name: Healing Pulse (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: Ceirean releases a wave of soothing energy. Each creature of Ceirean's choice within 60 feet of it regains 35 ({@dice 10d6}) hit points and is cured of any poisons or diseases afflicting it.

monster.name: Cerbus
languages: understands Infernal but can't speak it

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Rare

trait.name: Environment
entries: Mountain, Underground

trait.name: Diet
entries: Meat

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Hard

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Lazy, Aggressive

action.name: Infernal Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., up to two targets within 5 feet of each other. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, range 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage.

The deepest vaults of the underworld are watched over by fearsome, three-headed hounds. In places of lesser importance, where three heads would be overkill, a two-headed cerbus is an excellent guardian.

entries.name: Twice the Dog
entries: With its two heads, a cerbus is indeed more vigilant than a typical guard dog. It is not fully twice as vigilant, however. It is a question of the cerbus' priorities: a cerbus' two heads do eat twice as much as a normal dog, sleep twice as much, bark twice as much, and expect twice as many pets for being a good boy.

entries.name: Burning Maws
entries: When an intruder steps too far into the cerbus' territory, the cerbus' heart burns with indignation, and gouts of infernal flame fill its mouth like a furnace. Its barking sends sparks flying and its teeth glow like molten ingots, setting anything that it bites ablaze.

entries.name: Snake-Headed Tail
entries: A cerbus wagging its tail must be approached with caution, as a cerbus' tail is in fact a venomous snake. As with most dogs, the tail is not under the cerbus' conscious control. With twice as many heads to notice it, the cerbus spends considerable time chasing its tail; fortunately, it is immune to its own venom.

Some may observe that the cerbus' snake-tail has a head of its own, and argue that this means cerbuses are properly three-headed, rather than two-headed, dogs. Appropriately enough, large numbers of cerbuses prowl the circles of Hell to which fiends consign the souls of pedants.

monster.name: Chamrosh
languages: understands Celestial but can't speak it

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The chamrosh's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom. It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material or verbal components:

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Uncommon

trait.name: Environment
entries: Forest, Grassland, Mountain

trait.name: Diet
entries: Berries, Birds, Fish

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Average

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Brave, Generous

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d6 - 1}) piercing damage.

Resembling a wolf with the dazzling wings of a tropical bird, the chamrosh circles its forested territory, guarding tender saplings against any danger. Sent to our plane from the celestial realm, each chamrosh is the guardian of a specific forest. They form strong relationships with the forest's denizens, and call upon them when the forest is threatened or abused. The chamrosh protects its domain with its life, while cultivating the forest as a safe haven for all who respect nature.
It is said that the world's first forests were seeded by chamrosh, and the oldest and deepest are still guarded by them. However, it is young forests that are closest to a chamrosh's heart.

{@b {@i Seed Bearer.}}  Each day the chamrosh carries seeds from inside its forest to the forest's edge, planting them and expanding its wooded domain. When a forest is needed elsewhere, the chamrosh will try to carry the first seeds to begin the process. If its home forest is threatened, the chamrosh may seek out druids or other allies of nature and charge them to bear the precious seeds to their intended location.

{@b {@i Power of Nature.}}  A chamrosh has access to some divine magic through the deity that it serves, but it derives the greatest part of its magic from the forests it has created. While within its own forest, the chamrosh are rumored to wield much greater power. Thus, in a chamrosh-tended forest, the rain is always gentle and plentiful, and the magical defenses against intruders of all kinds are always prepared.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Very Rare

trait.name: Environment
entries: Arctic, Mountain, Ruins, Underground, Urban

trait.name: Diet
entries: Meat

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Very Hard

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Aggressive, Cruel

trait.name: Pacify, Never Kill
entries: The chorden is unable to deal lethal damage.

trait.name: Natural Warden
entries: A chorden with a Bond Strength of 13 or higher can be commanded to watch over prisoners. During this time, it has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks made to observe the prisoners.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The chorden makes two attacks: one with its meathook and one with its chain wrap.

action.name: Meathook
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Chain Wrap
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) bludgeoning damage and the target becomes {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 12}).

Chorden are fiendish creatures that derive incredible delight from imprisoning and torturing others. Evil sorcerers and large cities alike have been known to employ a handful of them to watch over prisoners guilty of heinous crimes... or the undeserving. But a chorden knows no morals, only the scraping of their hooked chains and the joys of subjugation.

entries.name: Under Lock, Key, and Chain
entries: The care of a chorden is notoriously difficult to escape. A normal guard would have to wear a key on their belt, but the body of a chorden serves as a portal to a small demiplane that holds hundreds or thousands of keys, all of which only they know the true locations of. In this same space, they contain an endless network of metal chains they use to wrap and bludgeon their prisoners. A few claim to have escaped the care of chordens by coaxing them with meat or the promise of torture on a greater scale.

entries.name: Death Will Not Come For You
entries: A strange complication limits the abilities of a chorden: they are unable to mortally wound anything. Some would see this as a saving grace, but those who have felt the nearly endless pain allowed by this ability would say otherwise. Because of this, a chorden will never watch over an undead creature: they often choose to simply run away at the sight of one.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The drow's spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 12}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Fey Ancestry
entries: The drow has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}, and magic can't put the drow to sleep.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the drow has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Cunning Action
entries: On each of its turns, the drow can use a bonus actoin to take the {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, or {@action Hide} actions.

trait.name: Sneak Attack (1/Turn)
entries: The drow deals an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) damage when it htis a target with a weapon attack and has advantage on the attack roll, or when the target is within 5 feet of an ally of the drow that isn't {@condition incapacitated} and the drow doesn't have disadvantage on the attack roll.

trait.name: Special Equipment
entries: The drow wears a {@item token of disguise|BelzorMM}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The drow makes two shortsword attacks.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) poison damage.

action.name: Hand Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour. If the saving throw fails by 5 or more, the target is also {@condition unconscious} while {@condition poisoned} in this way. The target wakes up if it takes damage or if another creature takes an action to shake it awake.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: The drow adds 3 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, the drow must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

monster.name: Clockwork Buddy
languages: understands Common but can't speak it

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Rare

trait.name: Environment
entries: Ruins, Urban

trait.name: Diet
entries: Elastic Energy (Being wound)

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Easy

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Energetic, Friendly

trait.name: Winding Key
entries: A clockwork buddy's key needs to be wound for 10 minutes each day. If its key is not turned within 24 hours, the clockwork buddy is considered {@condition petrified} until its key is wound. Its weight does not increase during this time.

trait.name: Modular Design
entries: Clockwork buddies are built with removable parts and additions, each one serving a minor function. A standard buddy has one module port, and comes with one module. Ports can be added by certain tinkerers, and modules can be bought for around 10 gp. Removing or adding one of the following parts requires 1 action:

items: {@b {@i Fire Spout.}}  A small tube and vial of lamp oil that replaces a limb. While equipped, the buddy can take the flamethrower action.

{@b {@i Music Spools.}}  While equipped, the buddy can record sound for up to 5 rounds (30 seconds) and play it back perfectly as an action. To remove a recording from a spool requires a DC 10 Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) check. On a failed check the spool becomes unusable.
{@b {@i Wheels.}}  While equipped, the mechanical buddy's movement speed is increased by 15.
{@b {@i Wings.}}  While equipped, the mechanical buddy has a flying speed of 20 feet.
{@b {@i Horn, Lance, Quills, or Spear.}}  While equipped, the mechanical buddy can make spear attacks and gains the charge ability.
{@b {@i Pea Shooter.}}  While equipped, the mechanical buddy can take the bombard action.

trait.name: Charge (Horn, Lance, Quills, or Spear modules only)
entries: If the clockwork buddy moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a spear attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 3 ({@damage 1d6}) slashing damage. If the target is a large or smaller creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 11} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Flamethrower (Fire Spout module only)
entries: The clockwork buddy spews fire in a 15-foot line. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 11} Dexterity saving throw, taking 5 ({@damage 2d4}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Each time the clockwork buddy uses this weapon, roll {@dice 1d6}. On a 1, the oil runs out and must be replaced.

action.name: Spear (Horn, Lance, Quills, or Spear modules only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d8 + 1}) piercing damage.

action.name: Bombard (Pea Shooter module only)
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 3} to hit, range 20/40 ft., up to two targets. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage.

Clockwork buddies are small, intelligent clockwork creatures created as toys by a gnomish craftsman long ago. They come in countless shapes and sizes, from miniature humanoids to tiny dragons. Most are lost, sleeping in ancient ruins or gathering dust in toy shops, mistaken for simpler toys—but winding the creature with a clock key awakens this friendly companion.

{@b {@i Spring-Wound.}}  Every clockwork buddy has a key that winds its mainspring, which provides the power that allows them to move and think. When the spring winds down, the buddy becomes paralyzed and unconscious; when it's wound up again, it awakens as if it had merely taken a short nap, no matter how long it has been dormant.

{@b {@i Ancient Crafts.}}  Gnomish tinkerers today work in the shadow of the unknown genius who created the clockwork buddies. Using techniques unknown to today's masters, one gnome centuries ago made these sentient automatons without resorting to magic, their minds consisting entirely of intricate clockwork. Whenever a clockwork buddy is discovered, artisans and collectors rush to acquire it, hoping to discover its secrets. This gnome's motives can only be guessed from what they gave the world: deathless creatures that blur the line between a toy and a true friend.

{@b {@i Modular Design.}}  A clockwork buddy's limbs can be detached, reconnected, and even swapped with other clockwork buddies. Some buddies are clearly mismatched when discovered, such as a dragon with a music box for a head, a gnome illusionist with wheels in place of legs, or a snuggly rabbit with a flamethrower in place of a tail.

trait.name: Gaseous Form
entries: If the creeper isn't in a moderate wind (at least 10 miles per hour), it can use its action to transform into a Gargantuan cloud of fog, or back into its true form. While in cloud form, its space is heavily obscured, it is weightless, has a flying speed of 10 feet, can hover, and can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. In addition, if air can pass through a space, the creeper can do so without squeezing, and it can't pass through water. It has advantage on Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution saving throws, and it is immune to all nonmagical damage.
If the creeper is ever within a moderate wind (at least 10 miles per hour), it instantly reverts to its true form.

trait.name: Invisible in Water (True Form Only)
entries: The creeper is invisible while fully immersed in water.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The creeper has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Water Form (True Form Only)
entries: The creeper can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. It can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

action.name: Constrict (True Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is Medium or smaller, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 12}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, the creeper tries to drown it, and the creeper can't constrict another target.

reaction.name: Elemental Absorption
entries: When the creeper takes acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder damage, it can gain resistance to the triggering damage type until the end of its next turn, and its next melee attack it hits with before the end of its next turn deal an extra 3 (1d6) damage of the triggering type. Additionally, each creature that starts its turn within the creeper's space before the end of the creeper's next turn takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) damage of the triggering type.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Uncommon

trait.name: Environment
entries: Coastal

trait.name: Diet
entries: Fruits, Meat, Nuts

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Average

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Clever, Hardy

trait.name: Powerful Claws
entries: The coconut crab has advantage on Strength (Athletics) checks.

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: The coconut crab has weak gills, and can survive underwater for 1 hour.

trait.name: Fall Resistance
entries: The coconut crab is immune to falling damage for up to 30 feet.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d8 + 1}) bludgeoning damage.

Coconut crabs are surprisingly large tropical island dwellers, capable of growing up to 3 feet long. True to their name, they have adapted to climbing palm trees and knocking down coconuts, their preferred food. Their claws are large and strong enough to open coconuts, which is terrifying.

{@b {@i Landbound.}}  Coconut crabs need a moist environment in order to breathe, but except for laying eggs and hatching they live their entire lives on dry land. In fact, they can only survive in water for about a day before suffocating. As long as they have a wet place to rest and moisten their gills, coconut crabs can dare most environments.

The sharklike sahuagin prize coconut crabs as a delicacy, although they must leave the ocean depths to harvest them. Some coastal communities have learned to farm coconut crabs, to offer them as tribute and buy off sahuagin raiding parties.

{@b {@i Tough Shell.}}  Coconut crabs are larger than most other crabs and their shells are especially thick. They are so well armored that they can fall from surprising heights without being harmed. This is useful for a crab that spends so much time climbing trees. These crabs also have an impressive natural life span of up to 60 years.

{@b {@i Fruit Snatchers.}}  In places that value their coconut harvests, coconut crabs are known as "robber crabs." Coconut crabs have surprisingly strong senses of smell, which make it difficult to hide food from their determined claws. Mischievous folk have been known to train the greedy grabbers to seek out other prey, such as unattended purses, helping the robber crab more fully embody its nickname.

trait.name: Colony Resistance
entries: The coelenite has advantage on saving throws against spells and magical effects that target only it.

trait.name: Limited Amphibiousness
entries: The coelenite can breathe air and water, but it needs to be submerged at least once every 4 hours to avoid suffocating.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage, or 5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage if the coelenite has half of its hit points or fewer. A target hit by the attack is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 12}). The coelenite has two claws, each of which can grapple one target.

A coelenite (pronounced {@i SEE-len-ite}) is a roughly humanoid coral-like creature made of hundreds of thousands of tiny organisms no larger than a pebble. The tiny creatures that make up a coelenite are brightly coloured and amorphous, but when they group together in a colony they harden like coral and take on a more structured form. These bodies have crushing claws akin to those of a giant crab and almost impenetrable armour. In addition, their colonial nature makes them resistant a wide variety of spells and conditions.

entries.name: Water Dependant
entries: Despite their tough exoskeleton, the interior of a coelenite colony is amorphous and mushy. This interior requires a near constant supply of water to remain hydrated. Many sailors claim that the easiest way to kill a coelenite is to lure it inside a cabin and lock it in overnight.

entries.name: Mass Minds
entries: Should enough coelenites come together, they can produce an intelligence above that of a regular colony. These mass minds are capable of commanding other coelenite colonies and even manifesting magical effects. Luckily, if enough of the organisms that form the mass mind are killed, it loses these cognitive qualities.

trait.name: Colony Resistance
entries: The coelenite has advantage on saving throws against spells and magical effects that target only it.

trait.name: Colony Resistance
entries: If the coelenite has half its hit points or fewer its Intelligence score drops to 5 (-3), it can't use its Innate Spellcasting, Limited Telepathy, or Psychic Crush.

trait.name: Limited Amphibiousness
entries: The coelenite can breathe air and water, but it needs to be submerged at least once every 4 hours to avoid suffocating.

trait.name: Limited Telepathy
entries: The coelenite can magically tarnsmit simple messages and images to any creature within 60 feet of it that can understand a language. This form of telepathy doesn't allow the receiving creature to telepathically respond unless that creature is a coelenite.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionics)
headerEntries: The coelenite's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 12}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage, or 6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage if the coelenite has half of its hit points or fewer. A target hit by the attack is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}). The coelenite has two claws, each of which can grapple only one target.

action.name: Psychic Crush {@recharge 5}
entries: The coelenite targets one creature that it can sense within 60 feet of it. The target must make a {@dc 12} Intelligence saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) psychic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

A coelenite (pronounced {@i SEE-len-ite}) is a roughly humanoid coral-like creature made of hundreds of thousands of tiny organisms no larger than a pebble. The tiny creatures that make up a coelenite are brightly coloured and amorphous, but when they group together in a colony they harden like coral and take on a more structured form. These bodies have crushing claws akin to those of a giant crab and almost impenetrable armour. In addition, their colonial nature makes them resistant a wide variety of spells and conditions.

entries.name: Water Dependant
entries: Despite their tough exoskeleton, the interior of a coelenite colony is amorphous and mushy. This interior requires a near constant supply of water to remain hydrated. Many sailors claim that the easiest way to kill a coelenite is to lure it inside a cabin and lock it in overnight.

entries.name: Mass Minds
entries: Should enough coelenites come together, they can produce an intelligence above that of a regular colony. These mass minds are capable of commanding other coelenite colonies and even manifesting magical effects. Luckily, if enough of the organisms that form the mass mind are killed, it loses these cognitive qualities.

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: While out of water, the octopus can hold its breath for 1 hour.

trait.name: Underwater Camouflage
entries: The octopus has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made while underwater.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The octopus can breathe only underwater.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The octopus makes four tentacle attacks.

action.name: Tentacle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 25 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 18}). Until the grapple ends, the octopus can't use this tentacle on another target. The octopus has eight tentacles.

action.name: Tentacle Slam
entries: The octopus slams creatures {@condition grappled} by it into each other or a solid surface. Each creature must succeed on a {@dc 18} Strength saving throw or take 22 ({@damage 4d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage and be {@condition stunned} until the end of the octopus' next turn. On a successful save, the target takes half the bludgeoning damage and isn't {@condition stunned}.

action.name: Ink Cloud (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: A 30-foot-radius cloud of ink extends all around the octopus if it is underwater. The area is heavily obscured for 1 minute, although a significant current can disperse the ink. After releasing the ink, the octopus can use the {@action Dash} action as a bonus action.

Larger even than the {@creature giant octopus}, a colossal octopus grows to the size of a fishing boat and lives in the darkest depths of the ocean. Many colossal octopi serve as the emissaries of krakens, exploring waters beyond the territory of the master and reporting back. It's said that a colossal octopus can pull the mast out of a ship from beneath the hull, but that seeing on and survival is a blessing from the gods.

entries.name: Ship Sinkers
entries: Colossal octopi are renowned for sinking even large ships, using their powerful tentacles to tear apart hulls, rip siege weaponry from their bases, and fling crew members across the deck with ease. Sailors typically utter prayers to {@deity Umberlee|Faerûnian|scag} or other gods of the ocean to protect them from the beasts while out at sea.

monster.name: Combat Training Construct

resist.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine

languages: understands Deep Speech and Undercommon but can't speak

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The helmed horror has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Spell Immunity
entries: The helmed horror is immune the following spells: {@spell cone of cold}, {@spell ice storm}, {@spell lightning bolt}.

trait.name: Shove
entries: The helmed horror can {@action shove} a creature within 5 feet of it as a bonus action.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The helmed horror makes two longsword attacks.

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) slashing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) psychic damage, or 9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) slashing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) psychic damage if used with two hands.

trait.name: Brave
entries: The commodore has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

trait.name: Captain's Command (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: The commodore can use a bonus action on its turn to call out to up to three creatures it can see within 60 feet of it. Each creature can use its reaction to take the Attack (one weapon attack only), Dash, Dodge, or Use an Object action.

trait.name: Tactical Teamwork (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: When the commodore succeeds on a saving throw against an effect that targets at least one other creature within 30 feet of it, it can cause up to three creatures targeted by the same effect to automatically succeed on the saving throw.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The commodore can make two melee attacks.

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) slashing damage, or 8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) slashing damage if used with two hands to make a melee attack.

action.name: Heavy Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 3} to hit, range 100/400 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d10 + 1}) piercing damage.

action.name: Leadership (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: For 1 minute, the commodore can utter a special command or warning whenever a nonhostile creature that it can see within 30 feet of it makes an attack roll or a saving throw. The creature can add a d4 to its roll provided it can hear and understand the commodore. A creature can benefit from only one Leadership die at a time. This effect ends if the commodore is incapacitated.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Common

trait.name: Environment
entries: Coastal, Desert, Grasslands, Mountain

trait.name: Diet
entries: Lizards, Rodents

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Average

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Energetic, Impulsive

trait.name: Keen Senses
entries: The compsognathus has advantage on
Perception (Wisdom) checks that rely on hearing and smell.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The compsognathus has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the compsognathus's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage.

These slender dinosaurs rarely grow more than three feet long, about the size of a turkey or a large chicken. Composognathuses, or "compys" as some rangers affectionately call them, make their temporary nests around landmarks such as a tree or a boulder. Occasionally they choose a large creature as this landmark, and follow that creature around if it tolerates them. As they roam they return to familiar sites that proved safe, including creatures that they remember being friendly.
{@b {@i Speedy.}}  Compys' long legs carry them surprisingly fast. This helps them catch even the twitchiest prey and outrun most creatures that would hunt them.
Compys normally live and hunt in groups of several dozen. Instead of working together to take down larger prey, they fan out and scour an area for small creatures like mice and lizards.

{@b {@i Alarm Critters.}}  Compys react to almost any new creature by hopping up and down and chirping loudly. If it runs away, they chase it; if it chases them, they run. As a result, a pack of compys—or even a single one—can make reliable guard dogs of a sort. Anyone who sleeps near a compy nest can rest easy, knowing nothing will come close without the compys waking them up.

{@b {@i Lucky Lizards.}}  Humanoid tribes who live where dinosaurs roam often see compys as bringers of good fortune. Meeting a herd of compys is certainly a better stroke of luck than encountering almost any other kind of dinosaur.

trait.name: Archer's Eye (3/Day)
entries: As a bonus action, the archer can add {@dice 1d10} to its next attack or damage roll with a longbow or shortbow.

trait.name: Create Star Mote
entries: As a bonus action, the archer can place a mote of starlight in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of it. This mote emits dim light in a 5-foot radius, and lasts for 1 minute. It can place up to 6 motes.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The archer makes two attacks with its longbow.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) force damage.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) force damage.

action.name: Detonate Star Mote
entries: The archer can cause any number of motes it created within 60 feet of it to explode. Each creature within 5 feet of a mote must make on a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw or take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) radiant damage. A creature in the area of more than one mote burst is affected only once.

action.name: Starline
entries: The archer can form strands of starlight between all motes it created within 60 feet of it. If two motes are separated by a barrier or other solid object, the strand between them will not form. If a strand passes through a creature, that creature must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw, taking 5 ({@damage 1d10}) radiant damage for each mote placed on a failed save. Once the creature uses this action, all the motes it placed disappear.

When creatures of myth are slain, the gods or other celestial powers sometimes deem it fitting to memorialize them in the sky as constellations. Typically drawn from myths and legends, creatures who become constellations are blessed by the higher powers.

Constellate creatures maintain the same personalities as they did in life, whether that be the person a of a brave hunter or a menacing lion. In places of concentrated cosmic energy, or when their mythos is heavily invoked, these creatures will often return to the mortal realm, either to defend the area or to warn travelers.

All constellate creatures gain similar features, appearing as swarms of small stars connected by threads of starlight, and gain resistance to mundane weaponry, astral attacks, and the ability to manipulate starlight motes. Gifted with this power, constellate creatures are able to set traps using these starlight motes, piercing through unsuspecting victims with thin strands of light.
An abberation, beast, humanoid, giant, or monstrosity can become a constellate creature. When a creature becomes constellate, it retains all its statistics except as noted below.

entries.name: Senses
entries: The creature gains darkvision with a radius of 60 feet.

entries.name: Resistances
entries: The creature gains resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks if does not already have these resistances.

entries.name: Astral Attacks
entries: The creature's weapon attacks deal force damage instead of their normal type.

entries.name: Languages
entries: If the creature can speak, it learns Celestial in addition to any other languages it knows.

entries.name: Create Star Mote
entries: As a bonus action, the creature can place a mote of starlight in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of it. This mote emits dim light in a 5-foot radius, and lasts for 1 minute. It can place a number of motes up to twice its challenge rating (minimum of 2).

entries.name: New Action: Detonate Star Mote
entries: The creature can cause any number of motes it created within 60 feet of it to explode. Each creature within 5 feet of a mote must make on a Dexterity saving throw or take 2d6 radiant damage. A creature in the area of more than one mote burst is affected only once. The DC for this saving throw is equal to 8 + the creature's proficiency bonus + the creature's Constitution modifier.

entries.name: New Action: Starline
entries: The creature can form strands of starlight between all motes it created within 60 feet of it. If two motes are separated by a barrier or other solid object, the strand between them will not form. If a strand passes through a creature, that creature must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking 1d10 radiant damage for each mote placed on a failed save. Once the creature uses this action, all the motes it placed disappear. The DC for this saving throw is equal to 8 + the creature's proficiency bonus + the creature's Constitution modifier.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The lion has advantage on Wisdom (perception) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Pact Tactics
entries: The lion has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the lion's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the lion moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the lion can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.

trait.name: Running Leap
entries: With a 10-foot running start, the lion can long jump up to 25 feet.

trait.name: Create Star Mote
entries: As a bonus action, the lion can place a mote of starlight in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of it. This mote emits dim light in a 5-foot radius, and lasts for 1 minute. It can place up to 2 motes.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) force damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) force damage.

action.name: Detonate Star Mote
entries: The lion can cause any number of motes it created within 60 feet of it to explode. Each creature within 5 feet of a mote must make on a {@dc 11} Dexterity saving throw or take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) radiant damage. A creature in the area of more than one mote burst is affected only once.

action.name: Starline
entries: The lion can form strands of starlight between all motes it created within 60 feet of it. If two motes are separated by a barrier or other solid object, the strand between them will not form. If a strand passes through a creature, that creature must make a {@dc 11} Dexterity saving throw, taking 5 ({@damage 1d10}) radiant damage for each mote placed on a failed save. Once the creature uses this action, all the motes it placed disappear.

When creatures of myth are slain, the gods or other celestial powers sometimes deem it fitting to memorialize them in the sky as constellations. Typically drawn from myths and legends, creatures who become constellations are blessed by the higher powers.

Constellate creatures maintain the same personalities as they did in life, whether that be the person a of a brave hunter or a menacing lion.
