entries: The rusalka can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Aqua Step (Recharge 6)
entries: As a bonus action, the rusalka can teleport to an unoccupied location within 30 feet of her, provided that both the space she's teleporting from and her destination are in or at least touching water. The destination need not be within line of sight.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The rusalka has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The rusalka makes two attacks with her hair.

action.name: Hair
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) slashing damage. If the target is Medium or smaller, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 10}) and pulled to within 5 feet of the rusalka. The rusalka can have up to three creatures {@condition grappled} in this way at a time.

action.name: Constrict
entries: Each creature grappled by the rusalka's hair must make a {@dc 14} Strength saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage and becomes {@condition restrained} until the start of the rusalka's next turn or until the grapple ends. On a successful save, a creature takes half as much damage and isn't {@condition restrained}.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The sahuagin has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

trait.name: Limited Amphibiousness
entries: The sahuagin can breathe air and water, but it needs to be submerged at least once every 4 hours to avoid suffocating.

trait.name: Shark Telepathy
entries: The sahuagin can magically command any shark within 120 feet of it, using a limited telepathy.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The sahuagin makes a Spit Poison attack. It then makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its claws or net.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 2d4 + 1}) piercing damage.

action.name: Net
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 3} to hit, range 5/15 ft., one Large or smaller creature. {@h}The target is {@condition restrained}. A creature can use its action to make a DC 10 Strength check to free itself or another creature in a net, ending the effect on a success. Dealing 5 slashing damage to the net (AC 10) frees the target without harming it and destroys the net.

action.name: Spit Poison
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 15/30 ft., one creature. {@h}The target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour. If the saving throw fails by 5 or more, the target is also {@condition unconscious} while {@condition poisoned} in this way. The target wakes up if it takes damage or if another creature takes an action to shake it awake.

If you think a sahuagin is a terrifying beast, be glad you've never met a raider, or ryethi, as they are known. These sea devils look similar to their un-mutated kin save for their red colouration, elongated claws, and the poison glands which hang down below their muscular throats.
A ryethi is capable of spitting a potent poison that is easily absorbed through humanoid skin. One mouthful of the bright orange poison is enough to knock a grown warrior unconscious.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The sahuagin has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

trait.name: Limited Amphibiousness
entries: The sahuagin can breathe air and water, but it needs to be submerged at least once every 4 hours to avoid suffocating.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The sahuagin has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Shark Telepathy
entries: The sahuagin can magically command any shark within 120 feet of it, using a limited telepathy.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The sahuagin makes two melee attacks: one with its tentacles and one with its claws or spear.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) slashing damage.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) piercing damage, or 5 ({@damage 1d8 + 1}) piercing damage if used with two hands to make a melee attack.

action.name: Tentacles
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d8 + 1}) psychic damage. If the target is the same size or smaller than the sahuagin, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 11}). The target must also succeed on a {@dc 12} Intelligence saving throw or be {@condition stunned} until the grapple ends.

action.name: Extract Brain
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one {@condition incapacitated} humanoid {@condition grappled} by the sahuagin. {@h}45 ({@damage 10d8}) psychic damage. If this damage reduces the target to 0 hit points, the sahuagin kills the target by extracting and devouring its brain.

entries.name: Illithid Hybrid Template
entries: A {@filter beast, humanoid, giant or monstrosity|bestiary|type=beast;humanoid;giant;monstrosity} can become an illithid hybrid. When a creature becomes an illithid hybrid, it retains all its statistics except as noted below.

entries.name: Senses
entries: The illithid hybrid gains {@sense darkvision} with a radius of 120 feet.

entries.name: Languages
entries: The illithid hybrid speaks Deep Speech in addition to any other languages it knows, and gains telepathy out to a range of 120 feet.

entries.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The illithid hybrid gains advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

entries.name: New Action: Tentacles
entries: If the creature had a bite attack, it loses that attack. The illithid hybrid gains a tentacle attack with an attack bonus of the creature's Intelligence modifier + its proficiency bonus. The tentacles deal psychic damage equal to the illithid hybrid's Intelligence modifier plus additional psychic damage depending upon its size.

If the target is the same size or smaller than the illithid hybrid, it is {@condition grappled} (escape DC equal to 10 + Strength modifier). The target must also succeed on a {@dc 12} Intelligence saving throw or be {@condition stunned} until the grapple ends.

entries.name: New Action: Extract Brain
entries: The illithid hybrid makes an attack roll with the same bonus as the Tentacles attack against one {@condition incapacitated} humanoid grappled by the illithid hybrid. The attack deals 5 × the damage dictated by the table above. If this damage reduces the target to 0 hit points, the illithid hybrid kills the target by extracting and devouring its brain.

trait.name: Limited Telepathy
entries: The satellite can magically communicate simple ideas, emotions, and images telepathically with any creature within 100 feet of it that can understand a language.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The satellite has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Shell Smash (Recharges after a Long Rest)
entries: The satellite forcefully bursts its shell. Each creature within 5 feet of the satellite must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes 7 ({@damage 3d4}) bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. After using this, the satellite's armor class becomes 11 and its flying speed increases to 50 feet.

action.name: Gleam (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: The satellite shines brightly. Each creature within 5 feet of the satellite must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw be {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn.

reaction.name: Intercept Attack
entries: When a creature the satellite can see within 5 feet of it is hit by an attack, the satellite can swap places with the creature and become the target of the attack instead.

entries.name: Pact of the Chain Option
entries: At 3rd level, a warlock gains the Pact Boon feature. The satellite is an additional familiar option available to warlocks of the {@class Warlock|PHB|The Nebula|The Nebula|ATLAS} patron who select the Pact of the Chain.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Uncommon

trait.name: Environment
entries: Desert, Grasslands

trait.name: Diet
entries: Meat, Rodents

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Hard

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Energetic, Quiet

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the savannah tatzelwurm moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a bite attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 12} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Running Leap
entries: With a 10-foot running start, the savannah tatzelwurm can long jump up to 25 feet.

action.name: Poison Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The savannah tatzelwurm exhales poison in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw, taking 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) slashing damage.

A feared hunter of remote savannas, these tatzelwurms are smaller and swifter than their mountain-dwelling cousins. Taking features from both hunting snakes and cheetahs, they can run down and launch themselves at almost any prey. They prefer to kill quickly with a single bite, rarely hunting game that might notice them or fight back. Most frighteningly, savanna tatzelwurms are nearly silent, even when moving at full speed. Their cry, when they make a sound, is a piercing hiss.

{@b {@i Transient Attachments.}}  Savanna tatzelwurms are territorial, annually coming together to mate and raise young before separating again. In their solitary periods they can form connections with members of other species who they do not consider threats. It is uncommon for savanna tatzelwurms to hunt humanoids, and some may even befriend one if the promise of consistent prey is made. Expert hunters may spend years watching a tatzelwurm, learning from a master of its craft, and some barbarian tribes hold up savanna tatzelwurms as their totem. Young hunters may prove themselves by seeking out a tatzelwurm and surviving the encounter.

{@b {@i Threads of History.}}  Many scholars have entertained possible ways that these creatures came to be. The most common assumption ties them to crafty wizards that grafted animals together, forming dangerous hunters on a whim. Others have examined their scale formation and shedding, noting exceptional similarities between tatzelwurms and dragons. This connection is reinforced by the authority these creatures have over their homes, and the fear they incite in the hearts of those that live near them.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The troll has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The scrag can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Aquatic Regeneration
entries: The scrag regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn if it is fully submerged in water. If the scrag takes acid or fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the scrag's next turn. The scrag dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The troll makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

variant.name: Loathsome Limbs
entries: Whenever the troll takes at least 15 slashing damage at one time, roll a {@dice d20} to determine what else happens to it:

items.name: 1–10:
items.entry: Nothing else happens.

items.name: 11–14:
items.entry: One leg is severed from the troll if it has any legs left.

items.name: 15–18:
items.entry: One arm is severed from the troll if it has any arms left.

items.name: 19–20:
items.entry: The troll is decapitated, but the troll dies only if it can't regenerate. If it dies, so does the severed head.

entries: If the troll finishes a short or long rest without reattaching a severed limb or head, the part regrows. At that point, the severed part dies. Until then, a severed part acts on the troll's initiative and has its own action and movement. A severed part has AC 13, 10 hit points, and the troll's Regeneration trait.
A severed leg is unable to attack and has a speed of 5 feet.

A severed arm has a speed of 5 feet and can make one claw attack on its turn, with disadvantage on the attack roll unless the troll can see the arm and its target. Each time the troll loses an arm, it loses a claw attack.

If its head is severed, the troll loses its bite attack and its body is {@condition blinded} unless the head can see it. The severed head has a speed of 0 feet and the troll's Keen Smell trait. It can make a bite attack but only against a target in its space.

The troll's speed is halved if it's missing a leg. If it loses both legs, it falls {@condition prone}. If it has both arms, it can crawl. With only one arm, it can still crawl, but its speed is halved. With no arms or legs, its speed is 0, and it can't benefit from bonuses to speed.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The sea cub can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The sea cub has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The sea cub has advantage on an attack roll against a cub if at least one of the sea cub's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Swimming Leap
entries: With a 10-foot swimming start, the sea cub can long jump out of or across the water up to 15 feet.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 1} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 ({@damage 1d4 - 1}) piercing damage.

A sea lion is a fearsome monster with the head and forepaws of a lion and the lower body and tail of a fish. These creatures frequent temperate oceans and prey on anything from small fish to humanoids. These ferocious predators grow to a length of 15 feet and are highly territorial, attacking anything that trespasses on their hunting grounds with ire.
Baby sea lions are called sea cubs and are quite popular as pets among fishing communities. If trained properly, the sea cubs can serve as protectors of fishing boats when they grow up.
They're quite cute when they're young, but you won't like them when they're older, and they certainly won't let you dump them down the privy.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: Tentrix can breathe air and water.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Tentrix's spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 15}, {@hit 7} to hit with spell attacks). He can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

1e: {@spell armor of agathys|phb|armour of agathys} (3rd level)

action.name: Thunderous Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}27 ({@damage 5d10}) thunder damage.

action.name: Handaxe
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft. and range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) slashing damage.

action.name: Voice of the Kraken (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: Slarkrethel speaks through Tentrix with a thunderous voice audible within 300 feet. Creatures of Tentrix's choice that can hear Slarkrethel's words ({@language Primordial|phb}) must succeed on a {@dc 15} Charisma saving throw or be {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A {@condition frightened} target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

legendary.name: Handaxe
entries: Tentrix makes one handaxe attack.

legendary.name: Thunder Stride (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Tentrix teleports to an unoccupied space he can see within 30 feet. Immediately after he disappears, a thunderous boom sounds, and each creature within 10 feet of the space he left must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw, taking 16 ({@damage 3d10}) thunder damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

legendary.name: Cast a Spell (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: Tentrix casts a spell from his list of prepared spells, using a spell slot as normal.

Hailing from Purple Rocks, Sea King Tentrix is a kraken priest working for Slarkrethel who has amassed the Black Armada. Tentrix coordinated the attacks on the Sword Coast after receiving a message from Slarkrethel, and eagerly awaits the rewards promised to him. Tentrix doesn't know that Slarkrethel has been replaced by Zellix'Phor, but knows the kraken lairs in Ascarle. Tentrix cares little for his life, believing the kraken can bring him back from death, but threats to his floating lair crack his stern exterior. If his lair is threatened he reveals information. Tentrix's link with Slarkrethel, and therefore Zellix'Phor, means the elder brain can use an action to deal 90 psychic damage to Tentrix, killing him instantly. Zellix'Phor does this if Tentrix is about to reveal the location of Ascarle.
Tentrix is brutal, brash, and uncaring. He's travelled across Faerûn and knows the its oceans like the back of his hand. He is arrogant, and believes himself undefeatable.

Tentrix is transformed beyond his human form. Tentacles that hang from his face like a twitching, fleshy beard. His eyes ooze ink down his face in staining streams. He wears a flowing leather overcoat and a tricorn hat. Tentrix is rarely seen without his familiar, a {@creature homunculus} named Filch.
{@i This is a lengthier description of Sea King Tentrix's background and personality, changed to the above in an update.}
oldEntries: Hailing from Ulf of Thuger on Trisk, the northernmost of the Purple Rocks, Sea King Tentrix is a kraken priest who works directly for the kraken, Slarkrethel. Since leaving Trisk, Tentrix has amassed a huge cult of followers, most of whom are pirates that serve on the Black Armada. Tentrix coordinated the attacks on the Sword Coast after receiving a telepathic message from Slarkrethel. Tentrix is excited to be taking the fight to the mainland and eagerly awaits the rewards promised to him by the kraken. Tentrix doesn't know that Slarkrethel has been replaced by Zellix'Phor, but he's aware of the Ruins of Ascarle, where Slarkrethel lairs.

Tentrix tries to keep his knowledge secret from everyone, never revealing the full story. Tentrix cares not for his own life, believing the kraken has the ability to bring him back from beyond the grave, but threats to his floating lair crack his stern exterior. If his lair is threatned, he begins to reveal information. Unfortunately, Tentrix's direct link with Slarkrethel, and therefore Zellix'Phor, means the kraken can use an action to deal 90 psychic damage to Tentrix, killing him instantly. Zellix'Phor does this if Tentrix is about to reveal the location of Ascarle.

Tentrix behaves as a pirate king; he is brutal, brash and uncaring. He has devoted his life to worshipping Slarkrethel, gaining a cutthroat reputation, and amassing the nastiest crew of pirate lords he could muster. He's travelled throughout Faerûn to these ends and knows the world's oceans like the back of his hand. Tentrix is inflated with importance, exceedingly arrogant and believes himself undefeatable.

Like most kraken priests, Tentrix has been transformed beyond his human form. He has a face of tentacles that hang down like a twitching, fleshy beard. His eyes ooze ink down his face in staining streams. He wears a flowing leather overcoat and a tricorn hat. Tentrix is rarely seen without his familiar, a {@creature homunculus} named Filch.

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "I seek to bring glory to Slarkrethel, and in doing so become the deadliest pirate known to the Sword Coast."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "My crew are my kin. Mess with them and you mess with me."

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "My reputation has gone to my head; I believe myself undefeatable."

monster.name: Sea Spawn
languages: understands Aquan and Common but can't speak

trait.name: Limited Amphibiousness
entries: The sea spawn can breathe air and water, but needs to be submerged in the sea at least once a day for 1 minute to avoid suffocating.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The sea spawn makes three attacks: two unarmed strikes and one with its Piscine Anatomy.

action.name: Unarmed Strike
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Piscine Anatomy
entries: The sea spawn has one or more of the following attack options, provided it has the appropriate anatomy:

items.name: Bite.
items.entry: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

items.name: Coral Armour.
items.entry: The sea spawn increases its AC to 14.

items.name: Coral Club.
items.entry: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

items.name: Electric Lash.
items.entry: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 bludgeoning damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) lightning damage.

items.name: Flash Lure {@recharge 4}.
items.entry: Each creature within 5 feet of the sea spawn that can see it must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition blinded} until the end of the sea spawn's next turn.

items.name: Pincer.
items.entry: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) bludgeoning damage and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}) if it is a Large or smaller creature. Until this grapple ends, the sea spawn can't use its Pincer on another target.

items.name: Poison Quills.
items.entry: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d6}) poison damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

items.name: Secrete Poison.
items.entry: The next creature that hits the sea spawn takes 5 ({@damage 2d4}) poison damage.

items.name: Sword Arm.
items.entry: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) slashing damage.

items.name: Tentacle.
items.entry: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 12}) if it is a Medium or smaller creature. Until this grapple ends, the sea spawn can't use this tentacle on another target.

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: The sea turtle can hold its breath for 1 hour.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage.

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: The seluchin can hold its breath for 30 days.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the seluchin fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Lightning Aversion
entries: If the seluchin takes lightning damage, it must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or become stunned until the start of its next turn. The DC for this saving throw is equal to half the lightning damage the seluchin took.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The seluchin has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The seluchin deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Swimming Leap
entries: With a 60-foot swimming start, the seluchin can jump up to 60 feet out of a body of water. When it surfaces as part of such a jump, it creates rolling waves that propagate out around it. Each creature in the water within 120 feet of the seluchin must succeed on a {@dc 24} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Whirlpool Dive
entries: If the seluchin dives at least 120 feet straight down into a body of water, it forms a whirlpool in a 120-foot radius centered on the surface of the water around it, which lasts until the start of the seluchin's next turn. Each creature in the area must make a {@dc 24} Strength saving throw. On a failed save, a creature is pulled up to 60 feet toward the center of the whirlpool and becomes {@condition restrained} by the whirlpool. On a successful save, a creature is pulled 30 feet toward the center of the whirlpool and isn't {@condition restrained}. If a creature reaches the center of the whirlpool, it is also pulled 60 feet underwater.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The seluchin can use its Frightful Presence. It then makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its tail. It can use its Swallow instead of its bite.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 16} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}30 ({@damage 5d8 + 8}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 18}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the seluchin can't bite another target.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 16} to hit, reach 30 ft., one target. {@h}26 ({@damage 4d8 + 8}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 24} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each creature of the seluchin's choice that is within 120 feet of the seluchin and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the seluchin's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Swallow
entries: The seluchin makes one bite attack against a Large or smaller creature it is grappling. If the attack hits, the target takes the bite's damage, the target is swallowed, and the grapple ends. While swallowed, the creature is blinded and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the seluchin, and it takes 56 (16d6) acid damage at the start of each of the seluchin's turns. If the seluchin takes 60 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the seluchin must succeed on a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the seluchin. If the seluchin dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse by using 30 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

action.name: Primal Roar (Recharge 5-6)
entries: The seluchin emits a world-rending roar. Each creature within 120 feet of the seluchin that can hear the roar must make a {@dc 24} Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 45 ({@damage 10d8}) thunder damage and becomes {@condition stunned}. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage and isn't {@condition stunned}. A {@condition stunned} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If the seluchin is at the surface of a body of water, its roar creates a wave that functions as per the tsunami spell (save {@dc 24}) appearing in a space adjacent to the seluchin. The wave produced by the roar is not magical, and the seluchin doesn't need to maintain concentration on it.

legendary.name: Tail Attack
entries: The seluchin makes one tail attack.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The seluchin moves up to half its speed.

legendary.name: Chomp (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The seluchin makes one bite attack or uses its Swallow.

monster.name: Shava the Damned

resist.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't silvered

languages: the languages it knew in life

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The deathlock's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The deathlock is a 10th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 17}, {@hit 9} to hit with spell attacks). It regains its expended spell slots when it finishes a short or long rest. It knows the following warlock spells:

trait.name: Special Equipment
entries: Shava wields a {@item +3 rod of the pact keeper}, and wears a {@item ring of evasion} and a {@item ring of swimming} (included in her statistics).

trait.name: Turn Resistance
entries: The deathlock has advantage on saving throws against any effect that turns undead.

action.name: Deathly Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d6 + 3}) necrotic damage).

action.name: Grave Bolts
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 9} to hit, range 120 ft., one or two targets. {@h}18 ({@damage 4d8}) necrotic damage. If the target is Large or smaller, it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or become {@condition restrained} as shadowy tendrils wrap around it for 1 minute. A {@condition restrained} target can use its action to repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on itself on a success.

reaction.name: Ring of Evasion (3/Day)
entries: When Shava fails a Dexterity saving throw, she can use her reaction to succeed on that saving throw instead.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Uncommon

trait.name: Environment
entries: Arctic, Coastal, Lake, River, Underground

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Average

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Brave, Hardy

action.name: Restock
entries: The shingle exerts energy to regain stones it has lost. It collects {@dice 1d4} stones within 10 feet of it, and regains a number of hit points equal to the stones collected.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Stone Fling
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 3} to hit, range 15/30 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) bludgeoning damage.
Resembling an animated pile of pebbles, these tiny stone warriors literally hurl themselves into battle.

entries.name: Enemies to Slavers
entries: Shingles were first created in a desolate and cavernous world, when enslaved humanoids harnessed arcane magic to enlist the stones as allies against their captors. The shingles' creators are now long dead, and the empire that held them has been ground into dust. No new shingles have been created since that first battle, but shingles do not age or die unless they are violently destroyed. Each shingle remembers the first liberation war, and still feels an unbreakable hatred for any who enslave others. They have wandered far from their place of origin in search of new tyrants to overthrow, and new allies in their never-ending fight.

entries.name: Avalanche Allies
entries: Although they are brave and will fight alone if they must, shingles are strongest in large groups. A small army of shingles is a strange terror to behold, as if the earth itself is waging a spontaneous war of liberation. If they can't find other shingles to help them, they will find other freedom-loving creatures to travel with.

entries.name: Golem Smashers
entries: Shingles feel a special sympathy for the elemental spirits trapped within golems. They attempt to destroy golems wherever they find them, in order to free the spirits that are bound to animate them.

Although a single shingle is not strong enough to take on a golem by itself, it will seek out allies before attempting what it views as a rescue mission. Those who create golems should also beware, for the shingles see them as no better than slavers and will deal with them accordingly if they can.

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The shoggoth can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Maddening Wailing
entries: The shoggoth emits a constant, hideous wailing. Each creature that starts its turn within 20 feet of the shoggoth and can hear the wailing must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw.

On a failure, the creature can't take reactions until the start of its next turn and rolls a {@dice d8} to determine what it does during its turn. On a 1 to 4, the creature does nothing. On a 5 or 6, the creature takes no action or bonus action and uses all of its movement to move in a randomly determined direction. On a 7 or 8, the creature makes a melee attack against a randomly determined creature within its reach or does nothing if it can't make such an attack.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The shoggoth can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Unfathomable Form
entries: When a creature that can see the shoggoht starts its turn within 30 feet of the shoggoth, it must make a {@dc 14} Charisma saving throw. A creature that fails the saving throw is driven insane by the nightmarish form of the shoggoth, and suffers a {@table short-term madness|dmg} effect. A target that succeeds on the saving throw is immune to the Unfathomable Form of all shoggoths for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The shoggoth makes two tentacle attacks. If both attacks hit a Medium or smaller target, the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 13}), and the shoggoth uses its Engulf on it.

action.name: Tentacle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d10 + 3}) bludgeoning damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) psychic damage.

action.name: Engulf
entries: The shoggoth engulfs a Medium or smaller creature {@condition grappled} by it. The engulfed target is {@condition blinded}, {@condition restrained}, and unable to breathe, and it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw at the start of each of the shoggoth's turns or take 16 ({@damage 3d10}) psychic damage. If the shoggoth moves, the engulfed target moves with it. The shoggoth can only have one creature engulfed at a time.

action.name: Gaseous Transformation
entries: The shoggoth transforms into acidic gas or reverts to its true form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying is also transformed. It reverts back to its true form if it dies.

While in mist form, the shoggoth is {@condition incapacitated}. It has a flying speed of 20 feet, can hover, and can pass through any space that isn't airtight. It has advantage on Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution saving throws, and is immune to nonmagical damage.

While in gas form, the shoggoth can enter a creature's space and stop there. Each time that creature starts its turn with the shoggoth in its space, the creature must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Borne of the malice of Elder Evils, a shoggoth is a manifestation of Far Realm insanity and unadulterated hatred. These unfathomable creatures take myriad forms, but all seem to retain similar features; their bodies can flow around beings like ooze or turn into an acidic gas, they emit a constant, maddening wailing, and their touch is death.

entries.name: Summoned Madness
entries: A shoggoth is not a being that occurs naturally on the material plane. Their kind are found in the void between the stars, deep in the Far Realm. Cultists of certain antediluvian societies have discovered a method through which a shoggoth can be bought to the Material Plane, though even they are cautious to do so.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Very Rare

trait.name: Environment
entries: Grassland, Mountain, Space

trait.name: Diet
entries: Everything

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Very Hard

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Cruel, Proud

action.name: Create Young
entries: The shub breaths out a primordial fog that spawns {@dice 1d4} young. A young is a tiny aberration with an AC of 12, 1 hit point, and a flying speed of 15. They have a +2 to attack and deal 1 necrotic damage. On the shub's turn, it can use a bonus action to command any young within 30 feet of it to attack one enemy of its choice. A shub can have up to 10 young.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage and 4 ({@damage 1d8}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Ram
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 2d4 + 1}) bludgeoning damage.

Shubs are small outsiders resembling red-furred bovine, with a few unsettling differences. Their mouths are lined with razor-sharp teeth, two curled horns take the place of their eyes, and a network of twisted tusks protrude from their backs. Wherever they go they are shrouded in a thin, otherworldly mist. They live isolated lives, often choosing locations with no canopy above them and remaining there until an outside force compels them to leave.

entries.name: True Omnivores
entries: Shubs have strong digestion that allows them to eat almost anything, such as poisonous plants, bone, wood or pleasant memories. When a shub leaves an area, one can be sure that the domain they leave behind is completely devoid of all organic and fluid material, and is now nothing but flat, cracked earth.

entries.name: A Thousand Young
entries: Shubs are all children of a single eternal mother. In imitation of her, they can all create their own smaller, fleeting spawn. These "young" are clouds of tiny, needle-like creatures which the shub can summon to flit about in a protective cloud around it. These creatures quickly live their alien lives and die in the space of an hour. Whether they create their own young during this time, even more minuscule and fleeting, is a mystery.

entries.name: Sure-Footed
entries: Shubs have a supernatural sense of balance. They can stand upright on near-vertical surfaces, inverted surfaces, and surfaces that only exist outside of three-dimensional space. As such, they are equally often found leaping from place to place on remote mountaintops, in rolling grasslands, and in the howling darkness between the stars.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Rare

trait.name: Environment
entries: Forest, Urban

trait.name: Diet
entries: Energy

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Very Hard

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Cowardly, Quiet

trait.name: Natural Stealth
entries: While in dim light or darkness, the silhouette can take the Hide action as a bonus action.

trait.name: Sunlight Weakness
entries: While in sunlight, the silhouette has disadvantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

action.name: Shadow Drain
entries: While standing in the shadow of a creature, the silhouette can use its action to try and drain the creature's energy. The target creature must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or take 3 ({@damage 1d6}) necrotic damage. A creature killed by this ability has a 20% chance of becoming a silhouette.

These undead beings emerge from the shadows of other creatures the moment they cross over into the next life. Unlike most undead, a silhouette is not intrinsically hostile to the living. Instead, it is a mostly harmless echo of the original creature.

{@b {@i Lifeless Imitation.}}  A silhouette resembles a smaller, pitch-black version of the creature from which it spawned. They generally go through the same sort of actions that their "original" would, apparently unaware that they have no soul fueling them. Their shapes and mannerisms resemble their originals so closely that it's easy to identify who a given silhouette came from.

The first silhouettes manifested from the bodies of creatures that crossed into a darker world, and died without ever truly understanding themselves. The energy of this phenomenon has spread across the Material Plane, and now affects creatures seemingly at random. Some creatures choose to keep silhouettes as low-risk companions, as a shadowy undead puppy has fewer needs than a living one.

{@b {@i Life Draining.}}  Silhouettes feed by unconsciously draining the life of living creatures they come close to. They are light feeders, and do not seriously weaken most healthy creatures. In self-defense, they use this ability more aggressively to weaken an attacker.

{@b {@i Sunlight Aversion.}}  Silhouettes fear direct sunlight. Their shadowy presence cannot persist under the divine daylight, and they slowly become gray silhouettes over the course of an hour before fading to dust. Their allies must provide solutions to this problem, such as umbrellas or carrying boxes.

monster.name: Skeleton Crew
languages: understands all languages it spoke in life but can't speak

trait.name: Horde
entries: The crew can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the horde can move through any opening large enough for a Medium skeleton. Additionally, the crew is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Reactive
entries: The crew can take one reaction on every turn in combat.

trait.name: Horde Turn Resistance
entries: The crew has advantage on saving throws against any effect that turns undead. Additionally, the crew can be affected by the Destroy Undead feature regardless of CR limits, but has advantage on the saving throw against it and is not destroyed on a failed save. Instead, it takes radiant damage equal to 10 × the cleric's level on a failed save, or half as much damage on a success.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The crew makes four attacks, or two attacks if the crew has half its hit points or fewer.

action.name: Cutlass
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Pistol
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 30/90 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d10 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Volley
entries: The crew fires a simultaneous barrage of pistol shots. Each creature in a 30-foot cone must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 44 ({@damage 8d10}) piercing damage, or 22 ({@damage 4d10}) piercing damage if the crew has half its hit points or fewer. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Rare

trait.name: Environment
entries: Coastal, Grassland, Lake, Space

trait.name: Diet
entries: Spaghetti

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Average

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Creative, Lazy

trait.name: Enigmatic Nature
entries: The skinti is immune to scrying and to any effect that would sense its emotions, read its thoughts, or detect its location.

action.name: Noodle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Meatball
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 2} to hit, range 15/30 ft., one target. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d4}) acid damage.

The Skinti is a floating mass of otherworldly matter that, for some reason, bears an uncanny resemblance to spaghetti and meatballs. Perhaps one of the most enigmatic creatures in all the known planes, what little is known about these aberrations only begs more questions.

entries.name: Talented Artisans
entries: The most common act performed by a skinti is painting landscapes. Oftentimes, travelers who see the skinti as omens will offer them easels and painting supplies in attempts to appease them. Without these materials, the skinti will either clear an area of dirt and create a canvas of grass, dirt, and what resembles tomato sauce. However, their painting skills when working with tools has gone unrivaled for eons.

entries.name: Alien Flavor
entries: A common test conducted by unfamiliar adventurers is to taste the flesh of a skinti.Oddly enough, it seems as though the skinti cares not if it is eaten or left alone. However, those foolish enough to eat and digest portions of a skinti will find the taste comparable to warm, moldy garbage with a SHU of 90,000. The following indigestion and expulsion of the material has similar features.

entries.name: Quietly Waiting
entries: No skinti has ever expressed a need or desire for anything but paint, even including food. The few scholars that dedicate attention to skintis have drawn the conclusion that these creatures are waiting for something. The dread that follows speculation is best laid to rest, for sanity's sake alone.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Very Rare

trait.name: Environment
entries: Ruins, Space, Underground, Urban

trait.name: Diet
entries: Blood, Brain Matter, Meat

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Very Hard

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Energetic, Aggressive

action.name: Latch On
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one medium or smaller creature. {@h}The creature is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 12}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, {@condition blinded}, and at risk of suffocating. While grappling a creature this way, the skull tick is also {@condition restrained}. In addition, at the start of each of the target's turns, the target takes 2 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claim Host
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, one creature the skull tick is latched on to. {@h}4 ({@dice 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage. If the target is reduced to 0 hit points, the skull tick kills the target by taking control of their brain. As long as the skull tick is attached to this body, it can control the body and gains the same statistics as a zombie. It can choose to detach itself as an action. The skull tick dies if the zombie is slain while it is attached.

Most people, if they encountered a shambling, half-dead figure with a skull-like spider attached to its face, would run away. If they better understood the nature of the creature they saw, however, they would run even faster.
With six scuttling legs, the odious parasites known as skull ticks get their names from their uncanny resemblance to humanoid skulls, and their parasitic nature. Alone, they are quick and aggressive.
They are seldom seen separate from a host, however. When actively parasitizing a victim, a skull tick looks like a macabre mask.

entries.name: Body Thief
entries: A skull tick attaches to the head of a humanoid host, smothering the creature and slowly draining its blood. The skull tick takes control of the dying body, observing the world through a pair of eyes in its back, and directing the host to a safe location to be fed upon. A humanoid claimed by a skull tick looks and behaves much like a zombie. The host slowly becomes desiccated as the parasite feeds on its blood. While the hosts' movements are mostly slow and aimless, the skull tick can direct it to defend itself. If it manages to subdue a potential host, it will abandon its current host in favor of the "fresher" victim.

entries.name: Horrific Reproduction
entries: As it feeds, a skull tick lays its eggs in the host body.In a few weeks the young skull ticks hatch and devour whatever's left of the host from the inside out.The adult tick and its brood then set out in different directions to search for new victims.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionics)
headerEntries: The soth's innate spellcasting ability is intelligence (spell save {@dc 14}).
It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Very Rare

trait.name: Environment
entries: Space, Urban

trait.name: Diet
entries: Dreams

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Hard

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Devious, Quiet

When intelligent creatures first emerged in the mortal realm, many beings sought to influence them to good or to evil. One great fiend, remembered as the Corruptor and other names that must not be spoken, was barred from the Material Plane in order to protect its inhabitants. Unable to influence mortals directly, the Corruptor created the soth to spread its evil.

entries.name: Orbs of Evil Influence
entries: Soth appear as a variety of floating spheres, each one seemingly made of some chaotic ichor.Though they are silent, and can seldom be seen to act, they exert a malignant influence on the creatures around them.There are six types of soth, each of which pursues a different type of evil.Whatever their aims, soth's influence takes similar forms: they can read and influence the thoughts of nearby creatures, provoke terrible nightmares, command bodies to rise, and alter the development of the unborn to suit their cursed nature.

entries.name: Tham Soth
entries: Provokes violence and sows discord between friends.It glows with a lurid red light.

entries.name: Chag Soth
entries: Separates creatures from the gods, undermining faith and working against divine magic. Its light is deep indigo-violet, almost invisible.

entries.name: Gam Soth
entries: {@b {@i Provokes gluttony and insatiable hunger.}} It pulses with a sickly orange light.

entries.name: Gol Soth
entries: Provokes the love of wanton destruction, and especially of fire. It burns with yellow light like from a festering sun.

entries.name: Thag Soth
entries: {@b {@i Creates crushing sadness.}} Its light is a flat and pallid green.

entries.name: Nehe Soth
entries: Provokes silence, muteness, isolation, and the keeping of secrets. It shines with blue light that is painful to the eye.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Uncommon

trait.name: Environment
entries: Desert, Mountain, Swamp, Underground

trait.name: Diet
entries: Insects, Lizards

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Average

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Brave, Proud

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) piercing damage.

action.name: Stinger {@recharge 3}
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d8 + 1}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 9} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for one minute. If the {@condition poisoned} target is Small or Tiny, it is {@condition paralyzed}; if the {@condition poisoned} target is Medium or larger, its movement speed is reduced by 15. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the condition on itself on a success.

It's unknown what possessed the first adventurer to try to domesticate a giant scorpion, but after many generations of breeding they eventually managed it. Sovereign scorpions are a more companionable breed of giant scorpion, with just enough intelligence to train. Though they are fearsome in appearance, their venom is weaker than that of many smaller scorpion species.

{@b {@i Paralytic Venom.}}  The sovereign scorpion's sting is not directly fatal to most creatures. When hunting, they use their venom to paralyze small prey so that they can consume it later. Larger creatures may find that the venom slows them down without paralyzing them completely. A trained sovereign scorpion will not harm a creature it has stung, leaving the victim for its master to deal with—an important safeguard, in case the master is the one stung.

{@b {@i Defenders.}}  Sovereign scorpions are not aggressive, at least if they are fed regularly, but they will fight fiercely to protect the hand that feeds them. This makes them effective (as well as intimidating) bodyguards.

{@b {@i Feral Sovereigns.}}  The kind of people who keep sovereign scorpions as pets also tend to have high mortality rates, which has led to many domesticated sovereign scorpions being released into the wild. Wild sovereign scorpions have adapted to a wide range of habitats, from deserts to swamps.

Sovereign scorpions in the wild tend to become territorial and aggressive. Rather than driving off smaller scorpions in the area, they gather them to aid in defending their territory. In fact, feral sovereign scorpions often rule over small "kingdoms," teeming with scorpions of many different sizes. These regions become extremely dangerous, but when the sovereign dies the smaller scorpions abandon the area.

trait.name: Spacefaring
entries: The jellyfish doesn't need to breathe.

trait.name: Illumination
entries: The jellyfish sheds dim light in a 5-foot radius.
High in the sky, miles above the atmosphere, a number of creatures have developed specialized traits that allow them to survive in otherwise inhospitable environments.

entries.name: Deep Space Drifters
entries: Floating high above the atmosphere, tiny space jellyfish flutter about in the dark, casting their dim light like tiny stars. They, like the space squid, gather and consume space dust for energy. An unfortunate side effect of their diet is the propensity to glow, making them easily visible targets for hungering space squids.
When a space jellyfish reaches maturity, it attaches itself to a large chunk of debris and becomes a space polyp. Using the energy gathered from space dust, it slowly produces more space jellyfish.

trait.name: Spacefaring
entries: The polyp doesn't need to breathe.

trait.name: Illumination
entries: The polyp sheds dim light in a 10-foot radius.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The polyp makes {@dice 1d4} star mote attacks.

action.name: Star Mote
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 2} to hit, range 30 ft., one target. {@h} 3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) force damage.
High in the sky, miles above the atmosphere, a number of creatures have developed specialized traits that allow them to survive in otherwise inhospitable environments.

entries.name: Deep Space Drifters
entries: Floating high above the atmosphere, tiny space jellyfish flutter about in the dark, casting their dim light like tiny stars. They, like the space squid, gather and consume space dust for energy. An unfortunate side effect of their diet is the propensity to glow, making them easily visible targets for hungering space squids.
When a space jellyfish reaches maturity, it attaches itself to a large chunk of debris and becomes a space polyp. Using the energy gathered from space dust, it slowly produces more space jellyfish.

trait.name: Spacefaring
entries: The dragon doesn't need to breathe.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The squid makes two attacks, only one of which can be a beak attack.

action.name: Tentacles
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the squid can't use its tentacles on another target.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 15 ft., one creature that is {@condition grappled} by the squid, {@condition incapacitated}, or {@condition restrained}. {@h}17 ({@damage 3d8 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Plasma Cloud (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: A 20-foot-radius cloud of scorching plasma extends all around the squid. The area is heavily obscured for 1 minute, although a wind of moderate or greater speed (at least 10 miles per hour) can disperse the cloud. When the cloud appears, each creature in it must make a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes 13 ({@damage 3d8}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A creature must also make this saving throw when it enters the spell's area for the first time on a turn or ends its turn there. After releasing the cloud, the squid can use the {@action Dash} action as a bonus action.
High in the sky, miles above the atmosphere, a number of creatures have developed specialized traits that allow them to survive in otherwise inhospitable environments.

entries.name: Dust and Debris
entries: Without typical sources of sustenance, some space creatures have developed a peculiar diet. Chief among these is the space squid, which manages to subsist on a diet of space dust, supplemented with space jellyfish. It generates energy through a combined process of fission and fusion, breaking apart the dust and reforming it in order to create energy. In a pinch, it can expel its meal as a cloud of hot plasma, allowing it to scorch predators and escape from harm.

trait.name: Spacefaring
entries: The whale doesn't need to breathe.

trait.name: Keen Sight
entries: The whale has advantage on Wisdom (perception) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 33 ({@damage 6d8 + 6}) piercing damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw or be swallowed by the whale. A swallowed creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the whale, and it takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) fire damage at the start of each of the whale's turns.

If the whale takes 30 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the whale must succeed on a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the whale. If the whale dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse by using 20 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.
High in the sky, miles above the atmosphere, a number of creatures have developed specialized traits that allow them to survive in otherwise inhospitable environments.

entries.name: Cosmic Hunters
entries: Another species of ecological significance in space is the gargantuan space whale, the primary predator of the space squids. Unlike the squid, space whales do not have a method of converting space dust into energy, and thus resort to hunting space squids and other rare cosmic creatures for food.

entries.name: Astrambergris
entries: This diet of space squids results in a build-up of the squids' indigestible beaks within the space whales' intestinal tracts. Over the course of many years, these beaks merge with chemicals within the whale's innards, forming into a lump of stony substance called astrambergris. This substance, produced solely from the guts of the rare space whales, is mysterious and extraordinarily valuable. It is touted to have uses in powerful elixirs and potions, and is highly sought after by alchemists and magicians alike.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the reef remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from an ordinary coral reef.

trait.name: Limited Spell Barrier
entries: An invisible aura forms a 10-foot-radius barrier around the reef for as long as it lives. Spells of 3rd level or lower can't affect creatures or objects within the barrier, and the area within the barrier is excluded from the areas affected by such spells.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The reef can breathe only underwater.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The squid can breathe only underwater.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage.

action.name: Ink Cloud (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: A 20-foot-radius cloud of ink extends all around the squid if it is underwater. The area is heavily obscured for 1 minute, although a significant current can disperse the ink. After releasing the ink, the squid can use the Dash action as a bonus action.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Very Common

trait.name: Environment
entries: Coastal, Desert, Forest, Grasslands, Mountain, River, Ruins, Urban

trait.name: Diet
entries: Fruit, Nuts

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Average

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Energetic, Moody

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage.

Squirrels are small, tree-climbing rodents with distinctive, fluffy tails. They are especially lively in spring, when they can be seen chasing each other up and down trees, or leaping from one branch to another.

{@b {@i Urbanites.}}  Squirrels are a common sight in humanoid cities, wherever trees line the street or parks provide a green space within city walls. Such urban squirrels have no fear of humanoids, acting with sizable boldness and aggression. They may even approach citizens to beg for food, or outright steal belongings they take interest in.

{@b {@i Hidden Treasure.}}  Squirrels gather edible nuts in the fall and bury them, laying away stashes of food to help them through the winter. They have no compunctions about stealing another squirrel's hidden nuts, a habit they use to make up for how often they forget where they've buried their own nuts. Squirrels have a keen sense for where something has been buried, and a strong compulsion to dig it up again and see what it is. As a result, some treasure hunters adopt them as mascots.

{@b {@i Treetop Spies.}}  Squirrels have keener eyes than most other rodents. When they see a predator or other threat, they give a chittering call that alerts other animals in the area. When a hunter finds the forest strangely empty, they often have the squirrels' vigilance to thank. Skilled elven rangers often cultivate spy networks among squirrels in order to gather news of comings and goings in the forest.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the star devourer fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Spacefaring
entries: The star devourer doesn't need to breathe.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The star devourer has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The star devourer deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Astral Hide
entries: Any time the star devourer is targeted by a {@spell magic missile} spell, a line spell, or a spell that requires a ranged attack roll, roll a {@dice d6}. On a 4 to 6, the star devourer is unaffected, and the spell disappears into a void on its hide.

trait.name: Death Burst Nova
entries: When the star devourer dies, it explodes, and each creature within 600 feet of it must make a {@dc 20} Dexterity saving throw, taking 70 ({@damage 20d6}) fire damage and 70 ({@damage 20d6}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. After the explosion, the star devourer's body becomes a dense spherical black hole, 5 feet in diameter. Each creature within 120 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 20} Strength saving throw or be pull into the black hole and take 70 ({@damage 20d6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The star devourer can use its Frightful Presence. It then makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its tail. It can use its Swallow instead of its bite.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h} 49 ({@damage 6d12 + 10}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 20}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the star devourer can't bite another target.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h} 43 ({@damage 6d10 + 10}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed a {@dc 20} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each creature of the star devourer's choice within 120 feet of it and is aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 20} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, with disadvantage if the star devourer is within line of sight, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the star devourer's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Swallow
entries: The star devourer makes one bite attack against a Huge or smaller creature it is grappling. If the attack hits, the target takes the bite's damage, the target is swallowed, and the grapple ends. While swallowed, the creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the star devourer, and it takes 28 ({@damage 8d6}) bludgeoning damage and 28 ({@damage 8d6}) fire damage at the start of each of the star devourer's turns.

If the star devourer takes 60 damage or more in a single turn from a creature inside it, the star devourer must succeed on a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the star devourer.

action.name: Inhale (Recharge 4-6)
entries: The star devourer pulls creatures and objects alike towards its mouth. Each creature within a 60-foot cone originating from the star devourer must make a {@dc 20} Strength saving throw or be pulled up to 30 feet toward it. If a creature comes within 10 feet of the star devourer, the star devourer can immediately make a bite attack at it.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The star devourer makes one tail attack.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The star devourer moves up to half its speed.

legendary.name: Chomp (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The star devourer makes one bite attack or uses its Swallow.

A mythical creature from the depths of space, the star devourer is a titan that consumes all forms of matter to fill its never-ending hunger. Denizens of space shudder when the stars flicker, for fear of its arrival. Constantly wandering from meal to meal, a star devourer has no lair.

entries.name: Ancient Abomination
entries: No one knows how the star devourer came to be, and it is unknown whether it is a singular entity or merely a member of a terrifying species. It has been witnessed throughout the ages as a harbinger of darkness, crushing distant stars in a path of destruction across the sky. Astronomers have observed vast pockets of darkness in the night sky, unexplained by their calculations or science, that ultimately have been attributed to the maw of this monstrous creature.

trait.name: Stardust Form
entries: The elemental can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing. In addition, the elemental can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. The first time it enters a creature's space on a turn, or if a creature starts its turn within the elemental's space,  that creature takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) fire damage.

trait.name: Illumination
entries: The elemental sheds bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The elemental makes two touch attacks.

action.name: Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) radiant damage.

action.name: Gleam (Recharge 4-6)
entries: Each creature within 30 feet of the elemental must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, a target takes 13 ({@damage 3d8}) radiant damage and is {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn. On a success, a target takes half as much damage and is not {@condition blinded}.

A star elemental is a glowing mass of starlight with a vague semblance of a face. They are a strange variant of their fire elemental kin, channeling their energy as light and heat. As they are constructed of luminous plasma, direct contact with a star elemental can be dangerous.

entries.name: Denizens of Space
entries: Rather than occupying any of the elemental planes, star elementals can be found deep in space or adrift in the astral plane.

entries.name: Elemental Nature
entries: Like their other elemental kin, a star elemental doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

monster.name: Star Elemental Myrmidon
languages: one language of its creator's choice

trait.name: Illumination
entries: The myrmidon sheds bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The myrmidon's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The myrmidon makes three morningstar attacks.

action.name: Morningstar
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Radiant Strikes (Recharge 6)
entries: The myrmidon uses Multiattack. Each attack that hits deals an extra 5 ({@damage 1d10}) radiant damage.

A star elemental is a glowing mass of starlight with a vague semblance of a face. They are a strange variant of their fire elemental kin, channeling their energy as light and heat. As they are constructed of luminous plasma, direct contact with a star elemental can be dangerous.

entries.name: Denizens of Space
entries: Rather than occupying any of the elemental planes, star elementals can be found deep in space or adrift in the astral plane.

entries.name: Elemental Nature
entries: Like their other elemental kin, a star elemental doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

entries.name: Myrmidon
entries: Elemental myrmidons are elementals conjured and bound by magic into ritually created suits of plate armor. In this form, they possess no recollection of their former existence as free elementals. They exist only to follow the commands of their creators.

Though star elemental myrmidon bear several resemblances to the {@race starforged|ATLAS}, they spring into existence already possessing sentience, but unable to act against the commands of their creators.

trait.name: Brave
entries: The knight has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

trait.name: Dwarven Resilience
entries: The stonewarden has advantage on saving throws against poison.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The knight makes two melee attacks.

action.name: Morningstar
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7  ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Heavy Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 2} to hit, range 100/400 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d10}) piercing damage.

action.name: Leadership (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: For 1 minute, the knight can utter a special command or warning whenever a nonhostile creature that it can see within 30 feet of it makes an attack roll or a saving throw. The creature can add a {@dice d4} to its roll provided it can hear and understand the knight. A creature can benefit from only one Leadership die at a time. This effect ends if the knight is {@condition incapacitated}.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: The knight adds 2 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, the knight must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

trait.name: Gale Step
entries: When the stormcaller moves for the first time on its turn, it can double its speed until the end of the turn. If it moves at least 10 feet straight toward a target and then hit it with a weapon attack before the end of the turn, the attack deals an extra 4 ({@damage 1d8}) thunder damage. Once it uses this ability, the stormcaller can't use it again until it moves 0 feet on one of its turns.

trait.name: Stormy Stealth
entries: While in heavy rain, falling snow, mist, or other water-based phenomena, the stormcaller can take the Hide action as a bonus action, and can attempt to hide even if it is only lightly obscured.

trait.name: Cyclone Burst (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: When the stormcaller uses its Gale Step, it can release a burst of wind around it. Each creature within 10 feet of the stormcaller must succeed on a {@dc 12} Strength saving throw or take 9 (2d8) thunder damage and be pushed up to 10 feet away from the stormcaller and knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The stormcaller makes two attacks.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage.

reaction.name: Rain Shield
entries: The stormcaller adds 2 to its AC against one ranged attack that would hit it. To do so, the stormcaller must see the attacker and must be in light or heavy precipitation.

trait.name: Rarity
entries: Very Rare

trait.name: Environment
entries: Desert, Forest, Ruins, Swamp, Urban

trait.name: Diet
entries: Insects, Meat, Blood

trait.name: Taming Difficulty
entries: Hard

trait.name: Suggested Personality
entries: Aggressive, Cruel

action.name: Cry of Guilt {@recharge 5}
entries: The strix lets out a long cry, proclaiming trouble to all who hear it. Every creature within 30 feet of it that can hear the strix must make a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, they take 5 ({@damage 2d4}) psychic damage and become {@condition frightened} until the end of their next turn.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) slashing damage.

Strix, known to some as witch owls, are bad omens. Congregating in ruins, these birds fly out to places where terrible luck is about to befall someone, gazing on from a distance. Their wide, piercing eyes and dismal gray plumage are a baleful sight. If you see one looking at you, it is probably already too late.

{@b {@i Flesh Eaters and Blood Drinkers.}}  Strix are carnivores. Though they can subsist on unfortunate rodents and smaller birds, they most enjoy the blood of intelligent creatures. They can hunt if they have to, descending silently on their prey, but much prefer to let bad luck do the work for them.

{@b {@i Ill Omens.}}  Strix do not cause misfortune themselves. They are merely drawn to impending misfortune in the same way carrion birds are drawn to death. At least, this is the consensus among those whose findings on the creatures have survived; a surprising number of sages have found their papers on the strix knocked into the fireplace, left by a window during a freak rainstorm, or torn apart by feral cats. Whatever the cause of these misfortunes, it is not clear whether strix feed on intelligent creatures' suffering or simply enjoy it.

Some spellcasters, especially those who cast hexes or look into the future, decide it is better to have this ominous bird perched on your shoulder than gazing at you from afar. Such sages who choose a strix for a companion tend to have extraordinarily good luck, at least compared to everyone else around them.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The sunken herald is a 5th-level spellcaster. The sunken herald's spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 13}, {@hit 5} to hit with spell attacks). The sunken herald knows the following spells, which are sorcerer spells for it:

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The sunken herald deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Quicken Spell (2/Day)
entries: The sunken herald casts a spells it knows that has a casting time of 1 action as a bonus action.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 1} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) slashing damage.

action.name: Freakish Graft
entries: The herald warps the flesh of its hand around one object that it's holding. The herald can't be disarmed of the object or drop it.

trait.name: Flooded Lunges
entries: The sailor doesn't need to breathe, and is immune to the effects of being underwater at a depth greater than 100 feet.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the sailor remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a normal corpse.

trait.name: Reckless
entries: At the start of its turn, the sailor can gain advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls it makes during that turn, but attack rolls against it have advantage until the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Relentless (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: If the sailor takes 20 damage or less that would reduce it to 0 hit points, it is reduced to 1 hit point instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The sailor makes two melee attacks.

action.name: Maul
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Spectral Chains
entries: The sailor sends a spectral chain out toward a creature it can see within 30 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or have its speed halved until the start of the sailor's next turn and be pulled up to 15 feet toward the sailor.

reaction.name: Retaliating Chains
entries: When a creature hits the sailor with an attack while within 5 feet of it, the sailor can cause spectral chains to wrap around the target. The target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be {@condition restrained} until the end of the sailor's next turn.

trait.name: Star Dance
entries: If the swarm uses its Enchanting Pirouette on its turn, it can take the {@action Dodge} action as a bonus action.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny {@creature dancing star}. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The swarm makes 3 ({@dice 1d6}) star mote attacks, or 2 ({@dice 1d4}) star mote attacks if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer.

action.name: Star Mote
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 4} to hit, range 60 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) force damage.

action.name: Enchanting Pirouette {@recharge 5}
entries: The swarm sways in a sensational dance. Each creature within 30 feet of the dancing star must succeed on a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition charmed} for 1 minute. The swarm has advantage on attacks against the {@condition charmed} target. A creature can repeat this save at the end of its turn, ending the effect on a success. The effect also ends for an affected creature if it takes any damage or if someone else uses an action to shake the creature out of its stupor.
Under the pale light of the moon, in quiet forest groves, small fey creatures shimmer and sway. More jovial than their aggressive sprite kin, dancing stars are creatures of constant energy.

entries.name: Forest Tricksters
entries: These dancing stars are innate pranksters, stopping at nothing for their amusement, but laughing and singing the entire way. Dancing stars lure wanderers in with their delightful songs, only to bewitch the pour souls or rob them blind.

entries.name: Fey Outcasts
entries: Though jovial and bewitching, the dancing stars' antics have a tendency to draw the ire of other fey creatures. As such, dancing stars usually live in communities of their own, on the boundaries of fey territory.

entries.name: Social Beings
entries: Dancing stars often come together in large groups, throwing parties and laughing together as a swarm. When working together, individual stars can play off of one another, putting on even more enchanting performances. As a group, the charm of the dancing stars is amplified.

trait.name: Swarm
