subclassFeature.name: Stardust Magic
entries: At 6th level, you gain the ability to bring objects into creation using stardust. You can expend hit points from your cloud to cast a warlock spell you know at its lowest level without expending a spell slot. The number of hit points expended equals 10 times the spell's level.

Additionally, while your Shimmering Cloud has more than 0 hit points, you can expend 1 hit point from the cloud as a bonus action to coalesce stardust and create an inanimate object in your hand or on the ground in an unoccupied space within the cloud. This object can be no larger than 3 feet on a side and weigh no more than 10 pounds, and its form must be that of a nonmagical object that you have seen. The object is visibly magical, radiating dim light out to 5 feet, and vanishes after 1 hour.

subclassFeature.name: Gaseous Evasion
entries: At 10th level, you learn to dissipate and reform your body in order to avoid harm. When you are hit with an attack from an attacker you can see, you can use your reaction to become amorphous gas and negate the damage. Until the start of your next turn, you remain as gas and have resistance to all damage.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Star Formation
entries: At 14th level, you learn to materialize your patron's powers in the creation of a new star. Choose a point within 60 feet you can see. A miniature star bursts into existence at the chosen point. Each creature within 30 feet of the star when it first appears must make a Constitution saving throw against your warlock spell save DC. On a failed save, a creature takes 6d10 radiant damage and is blinded for 1 minute. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn't blinded. At the end of each of its turns, the target can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on a success.

The star shines for one minute, and provides bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet. Creatures within 30 feet of the star have disadvantage on saving throws against your warlock spells.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: The Pact of Betrayal
entries: The pact of betrayal subclass delves into the treacherous nature of Hell and the art of deception. Warlocks who follow this path gain the ability to manipulate and deceive others through illusions, charms, and enchantments. They can sow discord among enemies, compel others to betray their allies, and even mimic the appearance and abilities of those they encounter in Hell, blurring the line between truth and falsehood.

subclassFeature.name: Illusory Veil
entries: At 1st level, you gain the ability to manipulate the perceptions of others through the art of illusion. You learn the minor illusion cantrip, which doesn't count against your number of cantrips known. Additionally, when you cast the minor illusion cantrip, you can make it affect up to a 10-foot cube instead of a 5-foot cube. Furthermore, you have advantage on saving throws against illusions and can see through magical illusions as if they were transparent.

subclassFeature.name: Soul of Deceit
entries: At 6th level, your connection to Hell grants you the ability to twist the truth and deceive others effortlessly. You gain expertise in the Deception skill. Additionally, you can use your bonus action to force a creature within 30 feet of you to make a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the creature believes your next statement as absolute truth, regardless of how outlandish or contradictory it may seem.

subclassFeature.name: Pact Deceiver
entries: At 10th level, you have honed your ability to mimic others, becoming a master of disguise. As an action you adopt the appearance of any humanoid creature you have seen, or a specific individual you know about, for 1 hour. This transformation is an illusion, but it is so convincing that it withstands physical inspection. You gain advantage on Charisma (Deception) checks made to pass as the creature you are imitating, and any physical features, such as height and weight, can be altered to match the creature you are impersonating. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Betrayal's Embrace
entries: At 14th level, you can tap into the essence of betrayal itself, enabling you to turn allies against each other. When you hit a creature with an attack, you can use your reaction to force another creature within 30 feet of you to make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the target must use its reaction to immediately make a melee weapon attack against a creature of your choice, other than itself, that it can see within its reach. The target has advantage on the attack roll, and if it hits, it deals an additional 3d6 psychic damage. You can use this feature once per short rest. You may expend any spell slot to gain a use of this feature.

subclassFeature.name: School of Astronomy
entries: The observation of the stars and celestial bodies of the greater universe is known as astronomy, with wizards who practice this tradition being known as astronomers. They study the different properties of the stars, and learn to create their own miniature celestial bodies.

entries.name: Astrological Augury
entries: When you choose this tradition, at 2nd level, you can study the stars to gain knowledge on a variety of subjects.

When you finish a long rest, you choose one skill of your choice from any of the following: Arcana, History, Religion, or Nature. You gain proficiency with that skill, or if you already have proficiency in the skill, your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make with that skill, until the end of your next long rest.

entries.name: Spell Stars
entries: Also, at 2nd level, you can conjure forth stars when you cast a spell of 1st level or higher. When you do so, you choose an unoccupied space within range of the spell, and a spell star appears at the point for 1 minute. The spell star provides bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light for an additional 10 feet. You can have a number of spell stars at once equal to half your wizard level. While you are within 60 feet of a spell star, you can cast spells as though you were in the spell star's space.

Additionally, you can use your bonus action to cause any number of spell stars within 60 feet of yourself explode. Each creature within 5 feet of a spell star must make on a Dexterity saving throw against your wizard spell save DC or take {@damage 2d6} radiant damage. A creature in the area of more than one spell star burst is affected only once.

subclassFeature.name: Realign
entries: At 6th level, you learn to shift your stars as you desire. As a bonus action on your turn, you can move a spell star within 60 feet of you up to 30 feet in any direction. If you ram the spell star into a creature, that creature must make a Dexterity saving throw against your wizard spell save DC. On a failed save, the creature takes {@damage 2d6} radiant damage and the spell star disappears.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Constellation
entries: Starting at 10th level, you can channel magic between your stars as if they were portals. When you cast a spell with an area of effect that includes one of your spell stars, you can choose another spell star within 60 feet of you to carry the effect. Each creature within 10 feet of the chosen spell star is also affected by your spell.

subclassFeature.name: Constellate
entries: At 14th level, you can channel your arcane energy to create a constellation in an instant. As an action, you can expend a spell slot of 1st level or higher to create a number of spell stars equal to the slot level, placing each star at a point you can see within 60 feet of you.

subclassFeature.name: School of Blood Magic
entries: The observation of the stars and celestial bodies of the greater universe is known as astronomy, with wizards who practice this tradition being known as astronomers. They study the different properties of the stars, and learn to create their own miniature celestial bodies.

subclassFeature.name: Corrupting Cantrips
entries: Starting at 2nd level, your understanding of blood magic allows you to taint your cantrips with dark and malevolent energy. At 2nd level, when you cast a wizard cantrip that deals damage, you can choose to infuse it with the essence of blood magic. If the cantrip deals damage, the target must make a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the target suffers an additional effect based on the cantrip's damage type:

entries.name: Acid
entries: The target's skin corrodes and weakens, reducing its AC by 1 until the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Cold
entries: The target's blood chills, and it suffers a 1d4 penalty on its next weapon attack roll before the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Fire
entries: The target's flesh burns and festers, causing it to take an additional 1d4 fire damage at the start of its next turn.

entries.name: Lightning
entries: The target's nervous system is disrupted, causing it to suffer 1d4 penalty on Dexterity saving throws until the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Poison
entries: The target's blood becomes toxic, and it suffers 1d4 penalty on Constitution saving throws before the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Psychic
entries: The target's mind is overwhelmed by disturbing visions, and it suffers 1d4 penalty on Intelligence saving throws before the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Thunder
entries: The target's eardrums rupture, and it suffers 1d4 penalty on Wisdom saving throws before the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Infusion
entries: Starting at 6th level, you gain the ability to harness your blood magic to enhance your spells. When you cast a spell of 5th level or lower, you may sacrifise hit points equal to 5 times the spell's level in order to cast it at one level higher. However, you cannot use this feature if doing so would reduce you to less than 1 hit point.

Furthermore, when you sacrifice hit points using this feature, you gain Blood Points equal to the amount of hit points lost. As a bonus action, you can expend Blood Points equal to half your maximum hit points to create a spell slot of a level up to your proficiency modifier. Your Blood Points are lost upon completing a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Vital Surge
entries: Starting at 10th level, your mastery over blood magic allows you to harness the vitality within your own veins, unleashing it in times of need. When you cast a spell of 1st level or higher, you can choose to empower it with healing essence. If you do, roll a number of d6s equal to the level of the spell slot used. You regain hit points equal to the total rolled on the dice, and each creature of your choice within 30 feet of you regains hit points equal to half the total rolled (rounded down).
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short rest.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Bond
entries: At 14th level, you learn how to forge a powerful connection between your allies and their blood. As an action, you can choose a number of willing creatures you can see within 30 feet of you, up to a maximum equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of one). For the next minute, any hit points lost by one of the bonded creatures are divided equally among all other bonded creatures (rounded up). This feature ends early for a creature if the duration expires, if that creature is separated by more than 300 feet, or if you become unconscious or die.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: School of Hydromancy
entries: As a member of the School of Hydromancy, you focus your study on magic that conjures and manipulates water. Though detractors of this school believe it to be an overly specialized area of study, hydromancy spells actually cover a wide selection of the eight traditional schools of magic. Hydromancers can use their spells to protect themselves and their allies, disperse and destroy their foes, or do many other tasks. Though members of this school are most often sought out by shipmasters or the lords of coastal settlements, they can be found working in an array of diverse occupations and in varied environments.

subclassFeature.name: Hydromancy Savant
entries: Beginning when you select this school at 2nd level, the gold and time you must spend to copy a spell that has the {@filter hydromancy|spells|subschool=hydromancy 30 feet;hydromancy 60 feet;hydromancy 120 feet;hydromancy 150 feet;hydromancy 180 feet} tag into your spellbook is halved.

subclassFeature.name: Aqueous Magic
entries: Beginning at 2nd level, you can use magic leftover from your spells to conjure shallow pools of water. When you cast a spell of 1st level or higher using a spell slot, you can create one of these pools centered on a point on the ground that you can see within 30 feet of you. The pool manifests as a 1-inch-deep layer of water on the ground. It covers a 10-foot-radius for a 1st-level spell slot, and the radius increases by 5 feet for each slot level higher than 1st. The pool lasts for 1 minute, and stays in the location it was created for its entire duration, even on inclines or if subjected to strong winds.

If you start your turn standing in one of these pools of water, your speed is increased by 10 feet until the end of the turn. Also, while standing in one of these pools you are aware of any hidden or {@condition invisible} creatures within 10 feet of you that are also standing within a pool conjured by this feature.
These pools count as bodies of water for your hydromancy spells, and pools that intersect count as the same body of water.

subclassFeature.name: Watery Transposition
entries: Starting at 6th level, when you cast a hydromancy spell of 1st level or higher and utilize the spell's hydromancy radius, you can choose to teleport to the point that you chose to cast the spell from. You teleport after the spell is cast.
You can use this feature twice. You regain all expended uses of it when you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Command
entries: At 10th level, you add the {@spell conjure elemental|PHB} spell to your spellbook if it is not there already. If the spell is already in your spellbook, you add a wizard spell of your choice with the hydromancy tag instead. You can cast {@spell conjure elemental|PHB} without expending a spell slot. When you do so, you summon a {@creature water weird|MM} rather than one of the spell's normal options (the DM has the creature's game statistics). The {@creature water weird|MM} can be bound to one of the pools you create with your Aqueous Magic feature, or bound to a regular body of water.
Once you cast {@spell conjure elemental|PHB} in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest, though you can still cast it normally using an available spell slot.

If you use {@spell conjure elemental|PHB} to summon a {@creature water elemental|MM} or {@creature water weird|MM}, the spell has a casting time of 1 action, and the summoned creature disappears if your concentration is broken rather than becoming hostile to you.

subclassFeature.name: One with the Waves
entries: Starting at 14th level, the pools created with your Aqueous Magic feature become imbued with stronger magic. While you stand within one of these pools, you gain the following benefits:

items: You gain a +2 bonus to your AC.
You gain advantage on Constitution saving throws.
You are aware of any hidden or {@condition invisible} creatures that are also standing within a pool, regardless of distance.

entries: {@u Draconic Revenant of Eternal Wisdom}

The Draconic Revenants of Eternal Wisdom are imbued with the profound spiritual insight and the serene calmness of their draconic ancestors. Their scales softly glow in serene shades of green, blue, or violet.

entries.name: Spiritual Affinity
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being charmed or frightened.

entries.name: Sage's Breath
entries: Instead of exhaling destructive energy, you can use your Draconic Breath feature to heal all affected friendly creatures instead.

entries.name: Guardian of Knowledge
entries: You gain proficiency in the Insight skill. Additionally, once per short rest, you can gain advantage on one Wisdom (Insight) or Wisdom (Perception) check.
{@u Draconic Revenant of Shadowed Ice}

The Draconic Revenants of Shadowed Ice embody the chilling might of their icy draconic lineage. Their scales glisten with shades of blue and white, and their movements are marked by an otherworldly grace.

entries.name: Cold Affinity
entries: You have resistance to cold damage.

entries.name: Frozen Endurance
entries: When you use your Draconic Breath, you can choose one creature that failed its saving throw to take 2d6 additional cold damage.
{@u Draconic Revenant of the Undying Flame}

The Draconic Revenants of Undying Flame are infused with the fiery essence of their dragon ancestors. Their scales shimmer with hues of red and orange, and they possess an intense presence that draws others towards them.

entries.name: Fire Affinity
entries: You have resistance to fire damage.

entries.name: Burning Resurgence
entries: When you use your Draconic Breath, you gain temporary hit points equal to your Constitution modifier + your proficiency bonus. These temporary hit points last for 1 hour or until depleted.
{@u Dwarf Bloodline}
Half-Fiends of the Dwarf Bloodline are infused with the resilience and endurance of their dwarven heritage, augmented by their fiendish nature.

entries.name: Dwarven Resilience
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against poison and resistance to poison damage.

entries.name: Infernal Fortitude
entries: You have an innate ability to tap into your fiendish heritage to gain hit points. Once per long rest, as a bonus action, you can expend a number of hit dice up to your character level to regain hit points equal to the total rolled plus your Constitution modifier.
{@u Elf Bloodline}
Half-Fiends of the Elf Bloodline embody the graceful and enigmatic qualities of their elven ancestors combined with the infernal essence within them.

entries.name: Fey Ancestry
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being charmed, and magic cannot put you to sleep.

entries.name: Wings of the Fallen
entries: You have bat-like wings that enable you to glide through the air. When falling, you take no damage from the first 20 feet, and you can move horizontally up to 5 feet for every 10 feet descended.
{@u Human Bloodline}
Half-Fiends of the Human Bloodline possess a unique blend of mortal versatility and fiendish charm.

entries.name: Infernal Legacy
entries: You learn the thaumaturgy cantrip. When you reach 3rd level, you can cast the hellish rebuke spell once per day as a 2nd-level spell. When you reach 5th level, you can also cast the darkness spell once per day. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells.
{@u Ashenborn}
The Ashenborn Hellforged are agile and elusive.

entries.name: Agile Warrior
entries: You have proficiency in the Acrobatics skill.

entries.name: Counter Attack
entries: Whenever a creature within reach misses you with an attack, you may make a melee weapon attack against that creature as a reaction.
{@u Cindersoul}
The Cindersoul Hellforged possess an innate charisma and captivating presence.

entries.name: Infernal Charm
entries: You have proficiency in the Persuasion skill.

entries.name: Fiery Presence
entries: As an action, you can release a burst of infernal energy. Each creature of your choice within 10 feet of you must make a Charisma saving throw against a DC equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier. On a failed save, the creature takes 1d12 fire damage, and its speed is reduced to 0 until the start of your next turn. Once you use this feature, you must complete a short or long rest before using it again. This damage increases by 1d12 at 6th, 13th and 18th level.
{@u Obsidianborn}
The Obsidianborn Hellforged embody strength and fortitude.

entries.name: Obsidian Fortitude
entries: You have proficiency in Athletics skill checks.

entries.name: Seething Fury
entries: When you are reduced to half your hit points or fewer, and as a reaction, you may activate this feature to make your melee weapon attacks deal an additional 1d4 damage for 1 minute. Once you use this feature, you must complete a long rest before using it again.
{@u Malenti}

entries.name: Elven Appearance
entries: You look identical to a sea elf in every way. A creature can discern your true nature with an Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) check. The DC equals 8 + your Charisma modifier + your proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Natural Spy
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Deception} skill.

Malenti are a sahuagin mutation that look identical sea elves, and are frequently used as spies by the sahuagin. These sahuagin blend perfectly into sea elf society, where they can coordinate sahuagin attacks.
{@u Sea Devil}

entries.name: Bloody Assault
entries: When you damage a creature with an attack or spell and the creature has half its hit points or less, you can cause the attack or spell to deal extra damage to the creature. The extra damage equals your level. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.
Sea devils are the most common sahuagin; piscine, ferocious creatures with shark-like teeth in their gaping maws. They are sanguine, vicious brutes with an appetite for humanoid flesh.
{@u Umbraheart Subrace}

The Umbraheart subrace of the Shadowborn embodies the deep connection to darkness and shadow, drawing strength from the darkest corners of their heritage. They possess an uncanny affinity for manipulation and control over the shadows that envelop them.

entries.name: Shadow Veil
entries: As a bonus action, you can shroud yourself in an ephemeral veil of shadows. This grants you advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks until the start of your next turn. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Shadowmeld
entries: You have the ability to blend with shadows, making it difficult for others to notice your presence. When you are in an area of dim light or darkness, you can take the Hide action as a bonus action.
{@u Umbralstride Subrace}

The Umbralstride subrace of the Shadowborn embodies swiftness and agility, harnessing the essence of shadows to enhance their mobility. They possess the ability to traverse through the darkness with remarkable speed, becoming shadows themselves.

entries.name: Shadow Step
entries: As a bonus action, you can magically teleport up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space you can see that is in dim light or darkness. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Shadowy Swiftness
entries: Your base walking speed increases to 35 feet. Additionally, you can move through nonmagical difficult terrain made of shadows or darkness without expending extra movement.
{@u Shadowcaster}
The Shadowcasters are Umbral Elves who have honed their mastery of illusion magic. They possess an innate understanding of the intricacies of the mind and the art of deception.

entries.name: Eldritch Veil
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being charmed. Additionally, when you deal psychic damage with a spell, you can add your Charisma modifier to the damage roll of that spell.

entries.name: Shadow Manipulation
entries: You learn the Darkness spell, which you can cast once per day without requiring any material components. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell.
{@u Umbralblade}

The Umbralblades are Umbral Elves who have embraced their connection to darkness and sharpened their skills as warriors. They are adept at utilizing their natural agility and the shadows to their advantage, becoming formidable combatants.

entries.name: Shadow Step Mastery
entries: When you use your Shadow Step racial ability, you can choose to teleport an additional 10 feet as part of the same bonus action.

entries.name: Shadow Weapon Training
entries: You gain proficiency with martial weapons. Additionally, while you are wielding a weapon on each hand, you can score a critical on a roll of 19 or 20.

table.name: Bond Strength Table
rows: {@optfeature  Bonus Hit Die|SCoC}, {@optfeature Friends Till the End|SCoC}

table.name: Brawl Mishaps
table.caption: Brawl Mishaps
rows: A {@creature thug|MM} comes charging in from an adjacent room and slams a ship's wheel over the head of a character, dealing 11 ({@damage 2d10}) bludgeoning damage on a hit.

A stray flagon flies through the air and hits One-Eyed-Bill the {@creature wereshark|BelzorMM} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}), who transforms into a human-shark hybrid and attacks whoever is closest.
A hulking {@creature Half-Ogre (Ogrillon)|mm|half-ogre} pirate slams a pair of rogues into one of the tavern's walls, causing it to give way entirely. The brawl then spills out into the street.

One of the lamps lighting the tavern is smashed, and the burning oil spills onto a platter of drinks, starting a serious fire in a 10-foot-square. A creature in the fire takes 11 ({@damage 2d10}) fire damage and ignites, taking 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage at the start of each of their turns. The fire can be doused with an action and spreads at the DM's discretion.

The rotted base of the main mast gives way as a thug is thrown at it, and slides into the room through the ceiling. Each creature in a 5-foot-wide, 30-foot-long line must make a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw or take 16 ({@damage 3d10}) bludgeoning damage.

Someone throws a smoke bomb into the crowd which explodes in a ten-foot-radius, dealing 2 ({@damage 1d4}) force damage to anyone in the area. The area then fills with thick black smoke, heavily obscuring a 15-foot-sphere of the tavern.

table.name: Madness of Slakrethel
colLabels: Flaw (lasts until cured by a {@spell wish} spell)
rows: "I adorn myself with fish skeletons, wash in sea water, and wear clothes of matted seaweed."
"I have been contacted by Slarkrethel, who speaks to me through my dreams."
"I am convinced I must immerse myself in salt water every eight hours or I will die."
"Defeating Slarkrethel is my only aim. Nothing will stand between me and my goal."
"I only eat raw fish and seaweed."
"I pick at my skin constantly, trying to find the scales and suckers that I know are underneath."
"The ocean terrifies me; being on the coast gives me jitters, being submerged would kill me."
"I am convinced that the Kraken Society are hunting me, and their agents watch me always."
"I see writhing tentacles in the shadows. They are horrors of the deep that want to devour me."
"I can't take anything seriously. The more serious the situation, the funnier I find it."
"Human sacrifice is the only way to appease the kraken, Slarkrethel."

table.name: Mutations Table
table.caption: Mutations Table
rows: The colour of the target's hair, eyes, and skin become blue, purple, pink, or patterned.
The target's eyes push out of its head at the end of stalks.
The target's hands grow claws, which can be used as {@item dagger|phb|daggers}.
One of the target's legs grows longer than the other, reducing its walking speed by 10 feet
The target's eyes become beacons, filling a 15-foot cone with dim light when they are open.
A pair of leathery wings sprout from the target's back, granting it a flying speed of 30 feet
The target's ears tear free from its head and scurry away; the target is {@condition deafened}.
Two of the target's teeth turn into oversized, blunt tusks.
The target's skin becomes scabby, granting it a +1 bonus to AC but reducing its Charisma by 2 (to a minimum of 1)
The target's arms and legs swap, preventing the target from moving unless it crawls.
The target's arms become tentacles with fingers on the ends, increasing its reach by 5 feet.
The target's legs grow incredibly long and springy, increasing its walking speed by 10 feet.
The target grows a whip-like tail, which it can use as a {@item whip|phb}.
The target's eyes turn black, and it gains {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 120 feet.
The target swells, tripling its weight.
The target becomes skeletal, halving its weight.
The target's head doubles in size.
The target's ears become wings, giving it a flying speed of 5 feet.
The target's body becomes unusually brittle, causing the target to have vulnerability to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.
The target grows another head, causing it to have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}, {@condition frightened}, or {@condition stunned}.

table.name: Random Encounters
rows: 39-{@footnote 45|This value is duplicated in the source.}
{@footnote 45|This value is duplicated in the source.}-46
footnotes: {@note Due to the limitations of 5etools' engine, the following table is not interactive. However, you can use this {@dice d100} to save some typing, or one of the environment-specific tables in the column headings.}

footnotes.name: Aldani
entries: The characters are shadowed by {@dice 1d4} {@creature aldani (lobsterfolk)|Toa|aldani} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}), which are noticed by any character with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 12 or higher. The aldani don't communicate with others unless they must, and they won't fight unless the characters refuse to take a bribe to leave the area. The aldani aid the characters only if they're offered something of great value in return–for example, an offer to drive off a pack of predatory sahuagin encroaching on their territory.

footnotes.name: Ankheg
entries: A group of {@dice 1d3} {@creature ankheg|mm|ankhegs} bursts up from beneath the ground to ambush the characters. Any character without {@sense tremorsense|MM} is surprised by the attack. Ankhegs prefer Small creatures, which they grab with their mandibles and drag back underground to consume.

footnotes.name: Bandits
entries: A marauding gang of bandits confronts the party. The gang consists of a {@creature bandit captain} and {@dice 3d6 + 2} {@creature bandit|mm|bandits}, all wearing cloaks and mounted on {@creature riding horse|mm|riding horses}. There is a {@chance 25} chance that the bandits attack without provocation. Otherwise, the captain promises not to attack in exchange for a toll (no less than 100 gp worth of treasure). If the characters pay up, the captain bids them a safe journey before departing peacefully.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Each bandit carries a pouch containing {@dice 1d10} gp. The bandit captain's pouch holds {@dice 2d10} gp and {@dice 1d6} gems worth 100 gp each.

footnotes.name: Barbarians
entries: The characters encounter a group of {@dice 2d6 + 2} {@creature tribal warrior|mm|tribal warriors}, led by a {@creature berserker}. If the encounter occurs during the day, the barbarians are prowling the countryside while hunting wild game; if the encounter occurs at night, they are camped.

entries.name: The North
entries: If this encounter occurs in The North, the characters encounter an Uthgardt Barbarian tribe, led by an {@creature Uthgardt shaman|SKT} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}) with an additional {@creature berserker} bodyguard.

entries.name: Sea or Coast
entries: If the encounter occurs at sea or on the coast, the characters encounter {@dice 1d3} {@item longship|BelzorMM|longships}, each with ten {@creature berserker|mm|berserkers} and thirty {@creature tribal warrior|mm|tribal warriors} aboard. One of the {@creature berserker|mm|berserkers} serves as the captain. These hostile, bloodthirsty Northfolk raiders hail from Gundarlun, the Korinn Archipelago, Tuern, or the Whalebones. The {@item longship|BelzorMM|longships} have a speed of 3 miles per hour. If the vessel the characters are in moves at least as fast, the characters can flee from the barbarians and avoid an altercation.

footnotes.name: Blood Hawks
entries: A vicious kettle of {@dice 2d4+2} {@creature blood hawk|mm|blood hawks} attacks the party from above. These crimson raptors are fearless and attack large creatures without second thought. The hawks target already injured characters or those who look weaker than the rest of the party.

footnotes.name: Coelenites
entries: The characters are attacked by {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature coelenite|BelzorMM|coelenites} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}) who try and pull them down into the water and drown them. The {@creature coelenite|BelzorMM|coelenites} try to avoid leaving the ocean if possible but foray onto the shore or climb aboard boats to pursue their prey.

entries.name: Higher Levels
entries: If the characters are 4th level or higher, replace one of the {@creature coelenite|BelzorMM|coelenites} with a {@creature coelenite mass mind|BelzorMM} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}). The {@creature coelenite|BelzorMM|coelenites} telepathically threaten the characters with drowning unless they provide a tribute of food. The {@creature coelenite|BelzorMM|coelenites} can be appeased with food (four day's supply per coelenite in the group). Otherwise, they attack.

footnotes.name: Dolphins
entries: The characters spot a pod of {@dice 3d4} {@creature dolphin|vgm|dolphins} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}). If the characters are above the surface of the water, they notice the beautiful creatures leaping between the waves. They are naturally inquisitive and might come within 10 feet of the boat to take a look.

A {@creature dolphin|vgm} that is successfully {@condition grappled}, caught in a {@item net|phb}, or otherwise prevented from escaping can be trained as a mount by a character with proficiency in {@skill Animal Handling} who spends a few hours a day working with the mammal. At the end of 1 week, the character makes a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check. On a success, the dolphin becomes a willing mount for any humanoid.

footnotes.name: Druid
entries: The characters encounter a {@creature druid} who might be a member of the Emerald Enclave or simply devoted to protecting a certain area of wilderness. Most druids are happy to give guidance on traversing their lands, provided the characters are respectful of the environment on their travels. There is a {@chance 50} chance that the druid is accompanied by an animal companion. Two sample druids are presented below, but you can create others.

Jillian Leafgather (NG female lightfoot halfling) is a member of the Emerald Enclave accompanied by her massive, relentlessly slobbering {@creature mastiff}, Bungo. Jillian despises animal cruelty, and even considers insulting animals verbally to be intolerable. She knows a few shortcuts around the Sword Mountains and Neverwinter Wood, which she happily shares with characters in need. The shortcuts allow characters to move at a fast pace without any penalties.

Orsik Oakenheim (CE male mountain dwarf) is wild and rugged. He believes that the wilds should overtake civilisation, and all folk should go back to living as nomadic tribes in the wilderness. He wears a huge fur coat and trapper hat which conceals eight {@creature twig blight|mm|twig blights}. Orsik happily converses with characters, but if he deems them too involved with society, he tries to orchestrate their deaths. This can be achieved by sending characters into dangerous terrain such as scree slopes, {@trap quicksand} or predator territory. He also sends his {@creature twig blight|mm|blights} to steal things from the characters such as identification papers, faction emblems or {@item holy symbol|phb|holy symbols}.

footnotes.name: Elves
entries: A band of {@dice 3d6} wood elves offers to escort the party through the forest, steering the characters around the elves' hidden settlements. If they accept the offer, the characters have no hostile encounters while passing through the forest. If the characters refuse, the elves offer no further assistance and disappear into the woods. The elves use the {@creature wood elf|skt|scout} statistics, with the {@footnote following changes|Included in the linked statblock.}:

items: The elves are chaotic good.
Their speed is 35 feet, and they can attempt to {@action hide} even when they are in an area only lightly obscured by foliage, heavy rain, falling snow, mist, and other natural phenomena.
They have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}, and magic can't put them to sleep.
They have darkvision out to a range of 60 feet.
They speak Common and Elvish.

entries.name: Sea
entries: If this encounter occurs at sea, the characters encounter {@dice 3d6} friendly sea elf {@creature scout|mm|scouts}. These elves might be from Tir faoi Thoinn, Iumathiashae, or Waterdeep. They know the location of all the Island Kingdoms and underwater locations. Characters can hire a sea elf guide for 1 gp a day.

There is a {@chance 10} chance that one of the aquatic elves is a {@creature malenti|BelzorMM} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}); a sahuagin born with a mutation that makes it resemble an aquatic elf. The malenti spies on the characters as best it can and reports back to its sahuagin allies when it can about their movements and plans. This information eventually makes its way to the Colony of Zellix'Phor and could be used to set up an ambush with one of the mind flayers when the characters made port.

footnotes.name: Floating Debris
entries: The characters notice something floating one hundred feet away. A successful DC 16 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check reveals the nature of the debris. Roll a {@dice d6}:

items.name: 1–3.
entries: Barrels and crates.

items.name: 4–5.
entries: Shattered wooden planks.
Chests.

entries.name: Barrels and Crates
entries: Bobbing on the waves are {@dice 4d4} crates and {@item barrel|phb|barrels} filled with goods. These may contain alcohol, {@item rations (1 day)|phb|rations}, rope or other basic items typically found aboard ships.

entries.name: Shattered Wooden Planks
entries: Planks of shattered wood float atop the ocean. Clearly, these are remnants of a ship which has been recently attacked and perhaps destroyed. There is a {@chance 50} chance that a pirate ship is nearby (see "Pirate Ship" in this section).

entries.name: Chests
entries: Mostly sunk beneath the water's surface are {@dice 1d4} {@item chest|phb|chests}. These must have been jettisoned from another vessel. The {@item chest|phb|chests} are locked and keyless and require a successful DC 14 Dexterity check with {@item thieves' tools|phb} or a successful DC 16 Strength check to open. Inside are valuable items worth 100 gp, such as money, gems, candlesticks, jewellery and the like. There is a {@chance 10} chance that the chest contains a more expensive item worth 250 gp, such as a gemstone or {@table 250 gp art objects|dmg|art object}. This could be replaced with a magic item (roll once on {@table Magic Item Table A} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

footnotes.name: Ghost Ship
entries: A merchant ship appears on the horizon but appears to be drifting very slowly. A successful DC 16 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check reveals that the deck is empty, and the ship appears to be adrift.

If the characters decide to board the ship, they discover that it is entirely empty. There is a {@chance 50} chance that they can salvage useful items from the vessel such as {@item rations (1 day)|phb|rations}, alcohol, rope and the like.

entries.name: Haunted
entries: There is a {@chance 50} chance that the ship is haunted by the dead crew. If so, there are {@dice 3d4} {@creature ghost|mm|ghosts} aboard the ship who lash out at characters that disrespect the ship by stealing, breaking into cabins etc. If characters can calm the ghosts by offering them eternal rest, they reveal that their ship was attacked by mutated pirates. They had piscine features, such as shark jaws, crab claws, and pufferfish spines. Any of the crew who resisted the creatures were killed and those who remain were taken aboard as hostages.

entries.name: Repeat
entries: If this encounter occurs again, consider replacing the {@creature ghost|mm|ghosts} with {@creature specter|mm|specters} or {@creature poltergeist|mm|poltergeists} who cannot be brought to an eternal rest.

footnotes.name: Giant Boar
entries: The characters encounter a {@creature giant boar} chasing down a portly halfling. Unless they intervene, the halfling is caught and gored to death by the beast. The halfling's name is Nerrywill Underbarrow (NG male stout halfling {@creature commoner} with a {@item dagger|phb}, proficiency with {@item cook's utensils|phb} and the additional skill: {@skill Perception} {@dice 1d20+4|+4}). If the characters save his life, the tubby fellow pledges himself to the party for as long as he is helpful. He's a great chef and has a remarkably good eye. He keeps all his possessions in his pack and is willing to travel to the ends of the earth (and beyond) with his saviours.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Nerrywill carries a battered brass {@item spyglass|phb} engraved with his initials (850 gp), and a {@item backpack|phb} containing a {@item dagger|phb} (2 gp) and {@item cook's utensils|phb} (1 gp).

footnotes.name: Giant Crab
entries: A {@creature giant crab} scuttles out from a kelp forest or coastal cave and attacks a random character. The target is surprised unless they have a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 14 or higher. The crab attempts to {@action grapple} the character, then drop overboard with them and drown them (see "{@quickref Suffocating||2}" in chapter 8 of the {@i Player's Handbook}). If the encounter occurs at sea, the crab claws its way up the hull to ambush the character.

entries.name: Higher Levels
entries: If the characters are above 4th level, consider using a {@creature hulking crab|SKT} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}).

footnotes.name: Giant Lightning Eel
entries: A {@creature giant lightning eel|tftyp} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}) shoots out from a coral reef or rocky crevasse to attack a random character. The character targeted by the eel is surprised unless they have a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 13 or higher.

footnotes.name: Giant Octopus
entries: A {@creature giant octopus} shows some curiosity in the characters. The intelligent animal uses its dextrous tentacles to search their backpacks for food or curious treasures that it can steal away to its hoard. So long as the characters don't attack it, the octopus is not hostile. If the octopus finds a {@item rations (1 day)|phb|ration} or shiny treasure on the characters, it attempts to steal it. The octopus makes a Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) check against the characters passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}). If the octopus succeeds, it steals the item and swims back to its lair.

entries.name: Higher Levels
entries: If the characters are above 5th level, consider using a colossal octopus ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}).

footnotes.name: Giant Sea Horses
entries: The characters encounter {@dice 1d4} friendly {@creature giant sea horse|mm|giant sea horses}. Like their smaller kin, giant sea horses are shy, colourful fish with elongated bodies and curled tails. These creatures are often trained as mounts by aquatic elves.

A giant sea horse that is {@condition grappled}, caught in a {@item net|phb}, or otherwise prevented from escaping can be trained as a mount by a character with proficiency in {@skill Animal Handling}. At the end of 1 week with the animal, the character makes a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check. On a success, the giant sea horse becomes a willing mount for any humanoid.

footnotes.name: Giant Shark
entries: A {@creature giant shark} surges through the water toward the party and attacks a random character. The size of the creature makes it impossible to miss, and the characters each have a turn to try and flee or {@action hide} before it arrives and attacks. Giant sharks are 30 feet long and utterly fearless.

entries.name: Ships
entries: If this encounter occurs while the characters are on a ship, the giant shark attacks whatever vessel the characters are on. These enormous fish are capable of sinking smaller ships but are just as likely to ram larger ones to try and knock unsuspecting crew overboard. If the shark rams the ship, and characters on deck must make a DC 16 Dexterity saving throw or be thrown overboard.

footnotes.name: Giant Spider
entries: The characters are ambushed by a {@creature giant spider}.

entries.name: Forest
entries: The {@creature giant spider} drops down from the canopy above onto a random character. The character is surprised unless they have a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 17 or higher.

entries.name: Mountain
entries: A random character inadvertently blunders into the spider's {@hazard webs|dmg|web} (see "{@book Dungeon Hazards|dmg|5|Dungeon Hazards|0}" in chapter 5 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}). The spider quickly emerges from a concealed cave to gather its dinner

entries.name: Sea
entries: Whilst travelling through an area of low visibility, such as a rocky crevasse or a coral reef, a random character is attacked by a {@creature giant spider} with a swim speed of 30 ft. The character is surprised unless they have a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 17 or higher.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: If the characters succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check, they can track back to the spider's lair; a sheltered cave covered in sticky webs with corpses hanging from the ceiling. There is a {@chance 25} chance that one of these corpses has a magic item, determined by rolling on {@table Magic Item Table B} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

footnotes.name: Goblinoids
entries: A typical goblin patrol or hunting party consists of a {@creature goblin boss} leading {@dice 2d6 + 3} {@creature goblin|mm|goblins}. Goblins tend to have their own territories which they seldom leave. Goblins prefer to hunt at night and lay low in ambush positions during the day.

A night encounter with goblins involves an attack on the characters' camp. A character standing watch with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 16 or higher detects the goblins moving into attack positions and can rouse the rest of the party. If no one on watch notices the goblins, all characters are surprised.

If this encounter occurs while the characters are traveling during the day, any characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 16 or higher spots the tell-tale signs of an ambush: disadvantageous terrain coupled with an eerie silence not normal for the environment.

Goblins bargain for their lives if captured. If the characters can force or coerce a vow of cooperation from goblin prisoners, they will serve as guides. Goblins in their home territory have the following additional skill: {@skill Survival} {@dice 1d20+1|+1}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The gang of goblins have amassed 50 gp of assorted goods from ambushing travellers.

entries.name: Higher Levels
entries: If the characters are above 4th level, there is a {@chance 50} chance that the goblins are led by {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature bugbear|mm|bugbears} and the {@creature goblin boss} is replaced by a {@creature bugbear chief}. When under the command of bugbears, goblins do not flee unless all the bugbears are killed.

footnotes.name: Harpies
entries: A beautiful song carries in on the wind toward the party. Flying toward them are {@dice 1d4 + 2} {@creature harpy|mm|harpies}. As soon as the {@creature harpy|mm|harpies} are within 300 feet, they use their luring song to try and charm the characters. The {@creature harpy|mm|harpies} attempt to lure any enthralled characters into dangerous terrain such as scree slopes or overboard a ship. {@creature Harpy|mm|Harpies} might also pair up to {@action grapple} a character and fly off with them to their lair. {@creature Harpy|mm|Harpies} typically lair in isolated caves accessible only by climbing, such as rocky outcroppings, clifftops or skerries.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Each harpy has a {@chance 25} chance of wearing some basic jewellery worth 50 gp, such as a silver necklace or bronze anklet.

footnotes.name: Hill Giants
entries: A band of {@dice 1d3} {@creature hill giant|mm|hill giants} is searching for homesteads to pillage or bands of travellers to capture. The giants hurl rocks at any small folk they see. {@creature Hill giant|mm|Hill giants} are dim creatures and are easily tricked by misdirection and illusions. Characters might even be able to slip past a group of them while they argue with each other about who has the biggest belly, or whose feet smell the worst.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The giants carry a sack with them which contains a bundle of mundane items such as wagon wheels, tombstones, beehives and casks of ale. There is {@chance 25} chance that the bag also contains Garrin Brandybrush (NG male Stout halfling {@creature commoner} with 0 hit points), three cats stolen by accident from a nearby farm, or one {@creature boar} to which the giants have tied half a dozen humanoid skulls.

footnotes.name: Iceberg
entries: Floating in the ocean is an iceberg. Whilst this may not be troublesome on a clear day, it can be dangerous when unnoticed, such as at night or in heavy fog.

If a collision with the iceberg seems imminent, have everyone aboard the vessel make a DC 15 group Dexterity check to avoid hitting the berg. If the group check succeeds, the collision is avoided. Otherwise, the ship takes {@damage 10d10} bludgeoning damage from the collision, and everyone aboard must make a DC 10 Strength or Dexterity saving throw to avoid falling overboard.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Large icebergs are often home to monsters that favour an arctic environment. There is a {@chance 25} chance that the iceberg has one {@creature frost giant}, one {@creature young remorhaz}, {@dice 2d4} {@creature winter wolf|mm|winter wolves} or {@dice 2d6+2} {@creature ice mephit|mm|ice mephits} living on it.

entries.name: No Ice?
entries: If it doesn't make sense for ice to be where your characters are exploring, you could swap the berg for a rocky island, a coral reef, an abandoned warship, or a magical iceberg.

footnotes.name: Kelpie
entries: A hypnotic {@creature kelpie|tftyp} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}), an intelligent, aquatic plant that resembles a pile of seaweed, tries to lure one of the characters to their death. The {@creature kelpie|tftyp} can take the form of a {@filter Small, Medium or Large beast or humanoid|bestiary|size=S;M;L|type=beast;humanoid}, and uses this to its advantage, posing as a desirable creature such as a giant sea horse, or a stranded commoner drowning in rough seas.

footnotes.name: Killer Whales
entries: The party is attacked by a pod of {@dice 1d4 + 2} {@creature killer whale|mm|killer whales} who surge toward them through the water. If the characters are on a vessel that couldn't be capsized by the orcas, they simply notice them hunting not far from the ship.

footnotes.name: Knight
entries: The Order of the Gauntlet is taking strides to deal with the pirate threat. The characters encounter a {@creature knight} of the order mounted on a {@creature warhorse} clad in {@item chain mail|phb} {@item barding|phb} (AC 16). There is a {@chance 50} chance that the {@creature knight} has a squire–a {@creature guard} mounted on an unarmoured {@creature warhorse}. Two sample knights are presented below.

Marcheon Amander Chilcott (LG non-binary Illuskan human {@creature knight} of {@deity Tyr|Faerûnian|scag}) is a gallant yet ferocious Knight of the Merciful Sword who prefers to reform rather than destroy criminals. Chilcott and her squire recently raided a smuggler's cove filled with pirates and captured their leader, Captain Uthak 'Nightbringer' Katho-Olavi (NE male goliath {@creature berserker}). Nightbringer is an immensely tall goliath, covered in wave tattoos and bound with three pairs of {@item manacles|phb}. Marcheon Chilcott asks the characters to escort the captain to the nearest settlement while she heads back to the cove to ensure it is securely boarded up.

Lady Luciette Falconcrown (NG female Chondathan human {@creature knight} of {@deity Helm|Faerûnian|scag}) is a member of the Order of the Gilded Eye from Helm's Hold. Lady Falconcrown believes that evil should be actively sought out and punished before it has a chance to rear its ugly head. She wears a golden gauntlet emblazoned with a weeping eye on her right hand which marks her allegiance. Lady Falconcrown is currently searching for Zhentarim agents who she believes should be held accountable for their faction's misdemeanours. She asks the characters to give up anyone they know who is affiliated with the Black Network and tells them to take her to the traitors, so she can personally deliver them to justice.

footnotes.name: Kraken Sighting
entries: A huge shadow passes beneath the vessel on which the party sail. A successful DC 16 Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) or Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check allows characters to realise that the form is a {@creature kraken}. It pays no attention to the ship unless attacked by the crew.
Obviously, any crew members who notice the beast are be terrified, fleeing into the belly of the ship, muttering prayers or climbing up rigging.

If you wish, the kraken could be {@creature Slarkrethel|SKT} (see {@adventure chapter 5|BelzorMM|9} for his full statistics). This gives the characters the chance to realise that not all is well with the kraken, thanks to the exposed brain, which is actually Zellix'Phor the {@creature elder brain|vgm}.

footnotes.name: Kraken Society Cultists
entries: The characters encounter a sullen group of {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature spy|mm|spies} or {@creature cultist|mm|cultists} wearing grey hooded cloaks, led by a {@creature cult fanatic} wearing a purple robe over a {@item breastplate|phb} (AC 16) embossed with a kraken design. These minor agents of the society are on a mission to gather information about merchant movements, explore unmapped coastline, sabotage Lord's Alliance ships or hire pirate crews. These low-ranking members of the cult have no idea that they are genuinely working for a kraken, and certainly have no idea that said kraken has been dominated by an elder brain.

A character can determine that the cultists are members of the Kraken Society with a successful DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check. The cultists pass by unless they are attacked, in which case they retaliate with lethal force. Only the {@creature cult fanatic} leader knows what their specific mission is, and if the characters question them, Zellix'Phor can use an action on its turn to telepathically deal 40 psychic damage to them, enough to kill them instantly.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Each cultist carries a pouch containing {@dice 1d10} gp. The leader's ornamented {@item breastplate|phb} is worth 450 gp, and they carry a pouch containing {@dice 2d10} gp and {@dice 1d4} gems worth 50 gp each. At the DM's discretion, the cultists could be carrying correspondence or maps pertaining to the characters' quests to help get them moving in the right direction.

footnotes.name: Lycanthropes
entries: Depending on where the characters are exploring, they come across one or more lycanthropes. The lycanthropes might be initially encountered in their animal, hybrid, or humanoid form depending on the focus of the encounter.

entries.name: Coast, Sea & Underwater
entries: The characters encounter a {@creature wereshark|BelzorMM} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}) hunting during the day or camping at night. Weresharks are loners and tend to be rude or hostile. If a {@creature wereshark|BelzorMM} gets a taste for humanoid flesh, it takes great mental fortitude to oppress the urge to kill.

entries.name: Forest
entries: The characters encounter a pack of {@dice 1d4} {@creature werewolf|mm|werewolves}. During the day the werewolves are relaxing in a cave, at night they are hunting. If encountered as a pack, the {@creature werewolf|mm|werewolves} are docile but angry if disturbed. If encountered alone, the {@creature werewolf} is a violent outcast.

entries.name: Grassland
entries: A sounder of {@dice 2d4} {@creature wereboar|mm|wereboars} have established a settlement of ramshackle huts and tents. They are ill-tempered brutes who delight in spreading their lycanthropic curse. They might trick characters into staying with them overnight before attacking, or simply charge.

entries.name: Hills/Moors
entries: A lone {@creature werebear} in animal form watches the party as they travel through its territory. The lycanthrope protects its territory against monstrous and humanoid intrusion. If it deems the party a danger, it might attack them to fend them off. If the party is passing through without causing much harm, the {@creature werebear} might approach them in human form to investigate their intentions.

entries.name: Road/Trail
entries: A pack of {@dice 2d4 + 2} {@creature wererat|mm|wererats} is migrating from one town to the next. These folk are often moved on from city to city when their nocturnal activities become evident. {@creature wererat|mm|Wererats} are always on the look out for new recruits. The {@creature wererat|mm|wererats} have 200 gp of stolen art objects.

footnotes.name: Manticore
entries: A {@creature manticore} attacks the party from its aerial vantage point, trying to kill a random character with its tail spikes and carry them back to its lair to devour. The {@creature manticore} may flee from battle if wounded, only to return the next day to continue to harass the characters. If the characters are incapable of killing the monstrosity, it happily offers to leave them be if they offer it a sacrifice or tribute. Anything worth less than 100 gp seriously offends the creature, who flies into a rage and wildly attacks. Each {@creature manticore} has its own malicious personality and might refer to itself as the Scourge of Gundarlun or a similar title.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Characters can track the {@creature manticore} back to its lair with a successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check. Normally a cave in a cliff face or mountainside, the lair contains 300 gp of coins and gems and has a {@chance 25} chance of containing {@dice 1d3} magic items, determined by rolling on {@table Magic Item Table C} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

footnotes.name: Mephits
entries: The characters might encounter {@creature dust mephit|mm|dust mephits}, {@creature ice mephit|mm|ice mephits}, {@creature mud mephit|mm|mud mephits}, or {@creature steam mephit|mm|steam mephits} (each appearing as a group of {@dice 2d6}). The mephits don't attack unless they outnumber the characters two to one, but they're reluctant to be helpful unless they themselves are outnumbered.

entries.name: On Land
entries: The characters encounter a {@creature draft horse} pulling a {@item wagon|phb}. Accompanying the {@item wagon|phb} are {@dice 1d6 - 1} people (use the {@creature commoner} stat block unless otherwise noted below). If the die result indicates that no one is present, it means the drivers are either missing or dead, leaving the horse and {@item wagon|phb} unattended. If one or more people are present, assume that they are guiding the {@item wagon|phb} toward the nearest settlement. The encounter might be one of the following:

items: Friendly furriers transporting {@dice 2d4} bundles of animal pelts worth 50 gp per bundle.
Friendly peddlers transporting {@dice 3d6} ten-gallon kegs of dwarven ale worth 5 gp each.
Friendly, dirt-poor musicians looking for a tavern; the wagon holds their instruments and gear.
Hostile {@creature bandit|mm|bandits} (NE Illuskan humans) posing as friendly traders, transporting a stolen wagon laden with foodstuffs to their encampment.
A family fleeing their coastal village in the wake of rumours of pirate attacks; the wagon contains their food and their mundane belongings.

A friendly merchant transporting {@dice 2d4} {@creature pig|skt|pigs} worth 3 gp each; any other persons present are Zhentarim {@creature guard|mm|guards} (N humans of various ethnicities) hired to ward off bandits.

Friendly Zhentarim mercenaries (NG human {@creature veteran|mm|veterans} of various ethnicities) transporting thirty {@item longsword|phb|longswords} (worth 15 gp each) and fifty {@item shortsword|phb|shortswords} (worth 10 gp each) to a Zhent merchant waiting for them in the nearest settlement.

entries.name: At Sea
entries: The characters encounter {@item sailing ship|BelzorMM} or {@item cog|BelzorMM} boat crewed by {@dice 2d6 + 10} people (use the {@creature commoner} stat block unless otherwise noted below). The ship is headed for the nearest safe port. The encounter might be one of the following:

items: Friendly scrimshanders transporting {@dice 2d4} boxes of scrimshaw worth 50 gp per box.
Friendly mercers transporting {@dice 2d4} rolls of fine elven silk worth 100 gp per bundle.
Haughty, incredibly rich spice merchants with a hold full of pouches of {@item cinnamon|phb}, {@item saffron|phb}, {@item pepper|phb}, and {@item salt|phb} worth 15 gp a pouch.
Hostile pirates (NE Northlander {@creature bandit|mm|bandits}) in a stolen ship posing as friendly traders to lure in potential victims.
A family fleeing their coastal village in a {@item rowboat|BelzorMM} in the wake of rumours of pirate attacks; the boat contains their food and other mundane belongings.
Five friendly merchants transporting timber for boat building; any other persons present are Zhentarim {@creature guard|mm|guards} (N humans of various ethnicities) hired to ward off pirates.

Friendly Zhentarim mercenaries (NG {@creature veteran|mm|veterans} of various ethnicities) transporting thirty {@item longsword|phb|longswords} (worth 15 gp each) and fifty {@item shortsword|phb|shortswords} (worth 10 gp each) to a Zhent merchant waiting for them in the nearest port.

footnotes.name: Merfolk
entries: Emerging from the depths are a group of {@dice 2d6 + 2} {@creature merfolk} traders. These peaceful, water-dwelling folk come to the surface in order to trade with passing ships. They don't value gold but instead delight in useful magical items or metal weapons that they lack the ability to craft. In return, they can offer treasures of the deep such as {@item pearl|dmg|pearls}, necklaces, and armour made of corals, glowing jellyfish in glass jars and magic potions. They may also have strange artifacts that they have scavenged from the depths such as parts of the crash-landed Illithid ship. Crew members often become infatuated with {@creature merfolk} and go on about them for days after the encounter.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The merfolk group carry treasures worth 250 gp. There is a {@chance 50} chance that they carry {@dice 1d4} magic items, determined by rolling on {@table Magic Item Table A} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

footnotes.name: Merrow
entries: The characters encounter {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature merrow} in the depths. They hunt humanoids in fishing vessels or on the coast. Their main tactic is to harpoon creatures into the water and drown them, taking their corpses down to underwater grottoes to feed. There is a {@chance 25} chance that the merrow have {@dice 1d4} {@creature merfolk} prisoners with them, bound in thick kelp rope. The {@creature merfolk} are from a nearby settlement where the characters could take refuge should they choose to free the prisoners.

footnotes.name: Mountain Lion
entries: A muscular {@footnote mountain {@creature lion|mm}|There is no 'mountain lion' anywhere in this book or other officially-published material. The generic lion has been linked instead.} pounces on the smallest character in the party and attempts to drag them off to its nearby den. The character is surprised unless they have a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 16 or higher.

footnotes.name: Nereid
entries: The characters encounter a {@creature nereid|tftyp} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}); a fey creature of otherworldly beauty. There is a {@chance 50} chance that the neried is good aligned and can help guide the characters through the next leg of their journey or point them in the direction of a previously unknown location. An evil aligned nereid convinces the characters into believing that they are good before using their drowning kiss and aquatic invisibility to launch a deadly surprise attack.

footnotes.name: NPC in the Water
entries: Clinging to a piece of flotsam, a floating tree trunk or barrel is a stranded individual who can foreshadow future events and give the characters information about events happening within the Realms if they are saved. The  could be anyone the DM chooses, but examples of potential characters are listed below:

Renk (NE male half-orc {@creature thug}) is a pirate from a ship called 'The Horizon Treader'. He bargains for his life with information about pirate activity along the Sword Coast and the Island Kingdoms. If rescued, he clams up straight away. A successful DC 12 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check is enough to get him talking again. The check can be made with advantage if Renk's life is put at risk.
Renk knows that his captain answered to a pirate-king, raiding the ships and villages that they choose. He also knows that the pirates are trying to take prisoners rather than treasure or goods.

items: Alethra Alnor (LG female Illuskan human {@creature noble}) is a merchant from a ship named 'Mirar's Bounty'. She hails from Luskan. Normally their trade is protected thanks to Ship Kurth (see "{@book Luskan|scag|2|Luskan|0}" in chapter 2 of the {@i Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide} for more information on the Ships of Luskan). She tells the characters that Luskan has remained relatively untouched by the pirate raids thanks to the protection of the Ships, but those who trade further abroad cannot be protected. This fate befell her ship, Mirar's Bounty, which was sunk near the Moonshae Isles. As well as information, Alethra rewards each player with a {@item moonstone} (50gp each).

Urth Stormaxe (CN male Northlander human {@creature berserker}) is a native of Tuern, a violent island filled with vicious raiders. Urth claims his longship was sunk by sahuagin who seemed possessed with great intelligence.

footnotes.name: Ogres
entries: The characters hear loud, deep voices and spot {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature ogre|mm|ogres} from a safe distance away. The big dummies are lost and trying to find their way home. The characters catch them in the middle of a loud argument about which direction they should go and can easily avoid the {@creature ogre|mm|ogres} or take them by surprise.

footnotes.name: Orcs
entries: The characters come across {@dice 3d6 + 2} {@creature orc|mm|orcs}. There is a {@chance 25} chance that these orcs have prisoners in tow. A sample group of prisoners is presented here, but you can create others.

The prisoners are {@dice 1d4 + 2} rock gnome {@creature commoner|mm|commoners} belonging to the Frackle clan. The oldest among them is a barmy old tinker named Nissanab 'Fizzlebang' Frackle. The {@creature orc|mm|orcs} smoked out the Frackle burrow and captured these family members as they tried to flee. The prisoners are smoke-stained and coughing. The Frackles have managed to create rudimentary firearms, including a {@item pistol} which the lead {@creature orc} has stolen, though he only has 5 bullets. Fizzlebang has a pouch of 25 additional bullets. For more information on firearms and explosives, see chapter 9, "{@book Dungeon Master's Workshop|dmg|9|Firearms|0}," of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: If the characters escort the Frackles back to their burrow, the gnomes are reunited with the members of their family who avoided capture. One of them rewards the party with a family heirloom (a magic item) hidden in the burnt remains of the family home. Roll on {@table Magic Item Table F} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} to determine the item.

footnotes.name: Passing Warship
entries: There is a {@chance 50|50%} chance of this {@item warship|BelzorMM} being friendly or hostile. Friendly {@item warship|BelzorMM|warships} include vessels from Neverwinter, Waterdeep, Baldur's Gate or Gundarlun. Hostile ships might come from Luskan, Tuern, Purple Rocks or other Northlander Isles.

Ships from major cities along the Sword Coast take the form of {@item galley|BelzorMM|galleys} or {@item warship|BelzorMM|warships} crewed by {@creature guard|mm|guards} or {@creature veteran|mm|veterans}. Those from island kingdoms are typically {@item longship|BelzorMM|longships} crewed by {@creature tribal warrior|mm|tribal warriors} or {@creature berserker|mm|berserkers}.

footnotes.name: Pirate Ship
entries: A ship sailing a black flag appears on the horizon. Panic begins to spread through the crew as word gets around that pirates have been sighted. As the speedy ship begins to gain on the characters' vessel, characters can attempt to avoid combat, but if that fails they have to fight the raiders hand-to-hand.

entries.name: Skill Challenge
entries: The characters must succeed on three DC 15 checks before failing three checks in order to out-navigate and escape the pirates. Allow any reasonable skill to be used, such as the following examples:

items: Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check to row the ship and help it gain speed.
Dexterity check to wrangle the sails into a new position.
Constitution check to row at top speed despite burning muscles.
Intelligence check to calculate the best angle of escape.
Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check to keep an eye on the trajectory of the pirate ship.
Charisma ({@skill Performance}) check to inspire the rest of the crew.

entries: If the characters fail three checks before succeeding on three, the pirates catch up.

Pirates typically crew {@item sailing ship|BelzorMM|sailing ships}, which require a crew of twenty; a mixture of {@creature bandit|mm|bandits}, {@creature thug|mm|thugs}, {@creature swashbuckler|vgm|swashbucklers}, and {@creature berserker|mm|berserkers}. Once within 120 feet of the character's ship, the pirates unleash a volley of {@item heavy crossbow|phb} {@item crossbow bolt|phb|bolts} and {@item javelin|phb|javelins}. These are connected to ropes which allow them to anchor the two ships together. It then takes three group actions for the pirate crew to draw the two ships together. At this point, the pirate crew storm and board the characters' ship using planks, ropes, and {@item grappling hook|phb|grappling hooks}. Melee combat ensues on deck.

There is a {@chance 20|20%} chance that the crew of the ship are peppered with {@creature sea spawn|BelzorMM} and {@creature deep scion|vgm|deep scions}. They are there on behalf of the Kraken Society, who are being manipulated by Zellix'Phor the {@creature Elder Brain|vgm}.

If the party are all knocked {@condition unconscious} by the pirates, they do not kill them. Instead, the party awakens a day later in shackles in the hull of the pirate ship. Give them plenty of chances to escape, but if they cannot, have the pirate ship attacked by a friendly {@item warship|BelzorMM} who liberate the characters.
{@adventure Appendix D|BelzorMM|14|Example Ships & Crew} gives some examples of other ships, potential captains, treasure items and pirate companies or affiliations.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: As well as their ship, each pirate crew has a cargo of treasure and possibly captured slaves. See {@adventure Appendix D|BelzorMM|14|Ship Treasure|0} for more details or roll on the "{@table Treasure Hoard: Challenge 0—4}" table in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

footnotes.name: Ranger
entries: The characters encounter a helpful ranger; a member of the Emerald Enclave or simply a wilderness wanderer. The ranger is happy to serve as a guide or source of information. There is a {@chance 50} chance that the ranger has a {@creature riding horse}, one or more beast companions, or both. A ranger with neither travels alone on foot. Two sample rangers are presented below, but you can create others:

Berri (CG female firbolg {@creature scout}) can cast {@spell detect magic} and {@spell disguise self}. She only appears to characters that are lost or in desperate need. She initially appears as an elf to avoid revealing her true identity, but if the characters are kind, she reveals her true form. Berri always carries dried fruit in small cloth parcels which she might leave for desperate adventurers. She also makes sure to carry a bundle of vials filled with an invigorating alcoholic draft which puts a drinker under the effects of a {@spell bless} spell for 1 hour.

Throkk Ampleford (CN male half-orc {@creature archer|vgm} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12})) is an incredible game hunter who has been living on The High Moor for the past decade. He was born in Neverwinter, but outcast because of his orcish heritage. Throkk has a pet {@creature hawk} named Streak who's catches rabbits and squirrels. Throkk has the additional skill: {@skill Survival} {@dice 1d20+5|+5}. He can use his knowledge of the local area to help characters hunt. Throkk also loves to fletch and crafts arrows for the characters as a gift before they part ways.

footnotes.name: Ruins
entries: The adventurers come across a small ruin; the remains of a wizard tower, a dilapidated dwarven mine, an abandoned goblinoid fort, a destroyed aquatic elf city beneath the waves, or a sunken ship. If the characters camp here, and the ruins are not already occupied (see below), they can finish a long rest with no chance of an encounter.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: There is a {@chance 50} chance the ruins are inhabited; {@creature sahuagin baron} on the coast, {@dice 1d4 - 1} {@creature owlbear|mm|owlbears} in the forest, {@dice 2d4} of {@creature centaur} in grasslands, an {@creature ettin} in hills or moors, a {@creature nothic} by the roadside, or {@dice 1d4 - 1} {@creature sea lion|tftyp|sea lions} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}) underwater.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: If the ruins are home to a creature, there is treasure within. If not, there is still a {@chance 50} chance that the ruins contain treasure. Roll a {@dice d20}:

items.name: 1–10.
items.entry: A humanoid skeleton clad in rusted armour holding a {@item silvered weapon|phb|silvered, nonmagical weapon} (your choice) with {@dice 1d4} magic items in a mouldy satchel (roll on {@table Magic Item Table A} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

items.name: 11–15.
items.entry: A humanoid corpse clutching a weapon (your choice) and a pouch containing {@dice 3d4} 50 gp gems.

items.name: 15–17.
items.entry: A smashed {@item chest|phb} containing a dozen battered books, {@dice 1d4} {@item trinket|phb|trinkets} (see chapter 5, "{@book Equipment|phb|6|Trinkets}" of the {@i Player's Handbook}) and {@dice 1d4} magic items (roll on {@table Magic Item Table B} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

items.name: 18–19.
items.entry: A monster hoard containing {@dice 2d6} 50 gp gems and {@dice 1d4} magic items (roll on {@table Magic Item Table C} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).
A slain adventurer atop a monster hoard containing {@dice 3d4} 50 gp gems and {@dice 1d4} magic items (roll on {@table Magic Item Table D} in chapter 7 on the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

footnotes.name: Sahuagin
entries: The party encounter a gang of {@dice 2d4 + 2} {@creature sahuagin} accompanied by {@dice 1d4 + 2} {@creature hunter shark|mm|hunter sharks}. There is a {@chance 20} chance that the hunting party is led by a {@creature sahuagin priestess} or a {@creature sahuagin raider|BelzorMM} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}). The {@creature sahuagin} attempt to throw characters into the water where the {@creature hunter shark|mm|sharks} viciously maul them. {@creature Sahuagin} have a hatred for elves, and always attack elven characters first if possible.

The sea devils have been stirred up by the influence of Zellix'Phor. Previously, the {@creature sahuagin} had little to do with Slarkrethel but since the discovery of the nautiloid crash, things have changed. Pieces of strange mind flayer technology have made their way into the hands of the {@creature sahuagin}, who have distributed it throughout their tribes, spreading the influence of the elder brain. The sea devils may carry with them {@item spear|phb|spears} made of strange metal, foreign tablets with {@language Qualith|vgm} inscriptions, or even weapons created by the illithid for them (see {@book Volo's Guide to Monsters|vgm|0|Mind Flayers: Scourge of Worlds}).
{@creature Sahuagin} carry exotic weapons adorned with pearls, coral and other naturally beautiful items. Each weapon is worth twice its normal value.
entries.name: Treasure

footnotes.name: Salty Sea Dogs
entries: Whilst travelling the high seas, the party encounter an NPC (or group thereof) who provide the chance for roleplay, gaining allies, making enemies, or gathering information:

entries.name: Flotsam & Jetsam
entries: (CN male and female {@creature goblin|mm|goblins}) This pair of {@creature goblin|mm|goblins} have fashioned themselves a barely seaworthy vessel from an old {@item barrel|phb}, using a tablecloth for a sail. They both have the additional skill: {@skill Sleight of Hand} {@dice 1d20+6|+6} and are kleptomaniacs. The {@creature goblin|mm|goblins} can become steadfast allies, who happily accompany the crew rather than remain in their dangerous little boat. They are also willing to "... swashbuckle..." alongside the characters but might not be able to resist pinching a particularly shiny piece of treasure from them should the opportunity arise.

entries.name: Anka
entries: (NN female {@creature anka|BelzorMM|ogre} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12})). Previously the first mate of the notorious Captain Callous, {@creature Anka|BelzorMM} made her last dim-witted mistake upon 'The Devil's Fin' and was forced to walk the plank by the captain. The characters encounter her 'starfished' on her back in the water, desperately trying to stay afloat. {@creature Anka|BelzorMM|Anka's} left arm has been replaced with a huge anchor which is slowly dragging her down. If saved, {@creature Anka|BelzorMM} temporarily allies with the characters, helping them track Captain Callous. Despite this, a successful DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check by Captain Callous causes her to come back to his side.

entries.name: T'zen'lix
entries: (LE male {@creature neogi|vgm}). T'zen'lix is an alien, spiderlike creature from the Astral Plane that accidently ended up here after stowing away on the nautiloid. When it crashlanded, 'Lix managed to enslave a farmer from Gundarlun and escape. Since then, 'Lix has been on a whirlwind ride discovering that wanton control over living beings often ends in sticky situations. 'Lix mostly wants to get back to the Astral Plane and joins together with the characters if they can help him achieve this goal. 'Lix doesn't think twice about mind controlling the characters to alleviate even the smallest of stresses for himself.

entries.name: Mei Ling
entries: (LE female {@creature vampire} with a swim speed of 30 ft.) Mei Ling is a vampire who lives in the underwater ruins of Narino, north of Mintarn.
