Normally their trade is protected thanks to Ship Kurth (see "{@book Luskan|scag|2|Luskan|0}" in chapter 2| of the {@i Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide} for more information on the Ships of Luskan). She tells the characters that Luskan has remained relatively untouched by the pirate raids thanks to the protection of the Ships, but those who trade further abroad cannot be protected. This fate befell her ship, Mirar's Bounty, which was sunk near the Moonshae Isles. As well as information, Alethra rewards each player with a {@item moonstone} (50gp each).

Urth Stormaxe (CN male Northlander human {@creature berserker}) is a native of Tuern, a violent island filled with vicious raiders. Urth claims his longship was sunk by sahuagin who seemed possessed with great intelligence.

footnotes.name: Passing Warship
entries: There is a {@chance 50|50%} chance of this {@item warship|BelzorMM} being friendly or hostile. Friendly {@item warship|BelzorMM|warships} include vessels from Neverwinter, Waterdeep, Baldur's Gate or Gundarlun. Hostile ships might come from Luskan, Tuern, Purple Rocks or other Northlander Isles.

Ships from major cities along the Sword Coast take the form of {@item galley|BelzorMM|galleys} or {@item warship|BelzorMM|warships} crewed by {@creature guard|mm|guards} or {@creature veteran|mm|veterans}. Those from island kingdoms are typically {@item longship|BelzorMM|longships} crewed by {@creature tribal warrior|mm|tribal warriors} or {@creature berserker|mm|berserkers}.

footnotes.name: Pirate Ship
entries: A ship sailing a black flag appears on the horizon. Panic begins to spread through the crew as word gets around that pirates have been sighted. As the speedy ship begins to gain on the characters' vessel, characters can attempt to avoid combat, but if that fails they have to fight the raiders hand-to-hand.

entries.name: Skill Challenge
entries: The characters must succeed on three DC 15 checks before failing three checks in order to out-navigate and escape the pirates. Allow any reasonable skill to be used, such as the following examples:

items: Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check to row the ship and help it gain speed.
Dexterity check to wrangle the sails into a new position.
Constitution check to row at top speed despite burning muscles.
Intelligence check to calculate the best angle of escape.
Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check to keep an eye on the trajectory of the pirate ship.
Charisma ({@skill Performance}) check to inspire the rest of the crew.

entries: If the characters fail three checks before succeeding on three, the pirates catch up.

Pirates typically crew {@item sailing ship|BelzorMM|sailing ships}, which require a crew of twenty; a mixture of {@creature bandit|mm|bandits}, {@creature thug|mm|thugs}, {@creature swashbuckler|vgm|swashbucklers}, and {@creature berserker|mm|berserkers}. Once within 120 feet of the character's ship, the pirates unleash a volley of {@item heavy crossbow|phb} {@item crossbow bolt|phb|bolts} and {@item javelin|phb|javelins}. These are connected to ropes which allow them to anchor the two ships together. It then takes three group actions for the pirate crew to draw the two ships together. At this point, the pirate crew storm and board the characters' ship using planks, ropes, and {@item grappling hook|phb|grappling hooks}. Melee combat ensues on deck.

There is a {@chance 20|20%} chance that the crew of the ship are peppered with {@creature sea spawn|BelzorMM} and {@creature deep scion|vgm|deep scions}. They are there on behalf of the Kraken Society, who are being manipulated by Zellix'Phor the {@creature Elder Brain|vgm}.

If the party are all knocked {@condition unconscious} by the pirates, they do not kill them. Instead, the party awakens a day later in shackles in the hull of the pirate ship. Give them plenty of chances to escape, but if they cannot, have the pirate ship attacked by a friendly {@item warship|BelzorMM} who liberate the characters.
{@adventure Appendix D|BelzorMM|14|Example Ships & Crew} gives some examples of other ships, potential captains, treasure items and pirate companies or affiliations.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: As well as their ship, each pirate crew has a cargo of treasure and possibly captured slaves. See {@adventure Appendix D|BelzorMM|14|Ship Treasure|0} for more details or roll on the "{@table Treasure Hoard: Challenge 0—4}" table in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

footnotes.name: Sahuagin
entries: The party encounter a gang of {@dice 2d4 + 2} {@creature sahuagin} accompanied by {@dice 1d4 + 2} {@creature hunter shark|mm|hunter sharks}. There is a {@chance 20} chance that the hunting party is led by a {@creature sahuagin priestess} or a {@creature sahuagin raider|BelzorMM} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}). The {@creature sahuagin} attempt to throw characters into the water where the {@creature hunter shark|mm|sharks} viciously maul them. {@creature Sahuagin} have a hatred for elves, and always attack elven characters first if possible.

The sea devils have been stirred up by the influence of Zellix'Phor. Previously, the {@creature sahuagin} had little to do with Slarkrethel but since the discovery of the nautiloid crash, things have changed. Pieces of strange mind flayer technology have made their way into the hands of the {@creature sahuagin}, who have distributed it throughout their tribes, spreading the influence of the elder brain. The sea devils may carry with them {@item spear|phb|spears} made of strange metal, foreign tablets with {@language Qualith|vgm} inscriptions, or even weapons created by the illithid for them (see {@book Volo's Guide to Monsters|vgm|0|Mind Flayers: Scourge of Worlds}).
{@creature Sahuagin} carry exotic weapons adorned with pearls, coral and other naturally beautiful items. Each weapon is worth twice its normal value.
entries.name: Treasure

footnotes.name: Salty Sea Dogs
entries: Whilst travelling the high seas, the party encounter an NPC (or group thereof) who provide the chance for roleplay, gaining allies, making enemies, or gathering information:

entries.name: Flotsam & Jetsam
entries: (CN male and female {@creature goblin|mm|goblins}) This pair of {@creature goblin|mm|goblins} have fashioned themselves a barely seaworthy vessel from an old {@item barrel|phb}, using a tablecloth for a sail. They both have the additional skill: {@skill Sleight of Hand} {@dice 1d20+6|+6} and are kleptomaniacs. The {@creature goblin|mm|goblins} can become steadfast allies, who happily accompany the crew rather than remain in their dangerous little boat. They are also willing to "... swashbuckle..." alongside the characters but might not be able to resist pinching a particularly shiny piece of treasure from them should the opportunity arise.

entries.name: Anka
entries: (NN female {@creature anka|BelzorMM|ogre} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12})). Previously the first mate of the notorious Captain Callous, {@creature Anka|BelzorMM} made her last dim-witted mistake upon 'The Devil's Fin' and was forced to walk the plank by the captain. The characters encounter her 'starfished' on her back in the water, desperately trying to stay afloat. {@creature Anka|BelzorMM|Anka's} left arm has been replaced with a huge anchor which is slowly dragging her down. If saved, {@creature Anka|BelzorMM} temporarily allies with the characters, helping them track Captain Callous. Despite this, a successful DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check by Captain Callous causes her to come back to his side.

entries.name: T'zen'lix
entries: (LE male {@creature neogi|vgm}). T'zen'lix is an alien, spiderlike creature from the Astral Plane that accidently ended up here after stowing away on the nautiloid. When it crashlanded, 'Lix managed to enslave a farmer from Gundarlun and escape. Since then, 'Lix has been on a whirlwind ride discovering that wanton control over living beings often ends in sticky situations. 'Lix mostly wants to get back to the Astral Plane and joins together with the characters if they can help him achieve this goal. 'Lix doesn't think twice about mind controlling the characters to alleviate even the smallest of stresses for himself.

entries.name: Mei Ling
entries: (LE female {@creature vampire} with a swim speed of 30 ft.) Mei Ling is a vampire who lives in the underwater ruins of Narino, north of Mintarn. Normally Mei Ling feeds on the blood of merfolk and sea elves, but from time to time she rises from her underwater lair to sample Tarnian blood and make mischief. She might clamber aboard the ship and drain the blood of a Tarnian crew member, try to sabotage the vessel, or turn the cabin boy into a {@creature vampire spawn}. Mei Ling doesn't consider the ocean to be running water. For more information about Mei Ling and Narino, see "{@adventure Open Lord Dagult Neverember's Quest|BelzorMM|3|Dagult Neverember's Quest|0}" in {@adventure chapter 2|BelzorMM|3}.

entries.name: Toroa
entries: (CN female Chultan human {@creature war priest|vgm} of Kahulla) Hailing from a far-flung island nation south of the Sword Coast, Toroa belongs to The Chosen of the Stormheart, an order of clerics sent out into the world to chase down the largest storms and commune with their patron goddess Kahulla, an aspect of {@deity Talos|Faerûnian|scag}. Toroa is hot on the tail of an enormous tempest that is, unbeknownst to her, a {@creature storm giant quintessent|vgm}. Torora has dusky skin, electric blue hair and a preference for lightning magic.

footnotes.name: Sea Hags
entries: The characters encounter three {@creature sea hag|mm|sea hags} that comprise a coven. Their favourite trick is to pretend to be stranded or wounded peasants in need of rescue in a damaged or beached rowboat.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: If the characters defeat the {@creature sea hag|mm|sea hags} and search the area, roll twice on {@table Magic Item Table A} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} to determine what they find. Whatever treasure the hags have is stowed inside a rotted wooden {@item chest|phb}.

footnotes.name: Sharks
entries: The characters are attacked by either {@dice 1d3} {@creature hunter shark|mm|hunter sharks} or {@dice 2d4} {@creature reef shark|mm|reef sharks} depending on what variety of location they are in. Characters in large ships that could not be capsized by the sharks can easily avoid this encounter, so consider having it occur at a later date when a character or crew member has fallen overboard.

footnotes.name: Storm Giant
entries: Looming up ahead of the characters, either rising from the water, sailing in an enormous dinghy or lumbering along the sea floor is a lone {@creature storm giant}. {@creature Storm giant|mm|Storm giants} are typically good aligned and willing to help the characters if they explain their situation. A successful DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check is enough to convince a giant to fight with the party during their next combat. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, the giant can escort the characters to Maelstrom (see "Maelstrom" in chapter 3).

footnotes.name: Trolls
entries: The characters are ambushed by {@dice 1d2} {@creature troll|mm|trolls}. They attack from behind ridges, thickets, and even kelp forests. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 11 or higher notice the {@creature troll|mm|trolls} from a safe distance and can attempt to flee, otherwise the characters are surprised.

entries.name: Sea & Underwater
entries: Saltwater trolls are called {@creature scrag|BelzorMM|scrags}. They use the {@creature troll} stat block with the following changes:

items: Scrags have a swim speed of 30 feet.

items.name: Amphibious
entries: The scrag can breathe air and water.

items.name: Aquatic Regeneration
entries: The scrag regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn if it fully submerged in water. If the scrag takes acid or fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the scrag's next turn. The scrag only dies if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

footnotes.name: Vodyanoi
entries: The characters encounter a {@creature vodyanoi|BelzorMM} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}) which attacks a random character or their ship. These relatives of the {@creature umber hulk} are capable of punching through ship hulls or capsizing smaller vessels.

footnotes.name: Whirlpool
entries: The roar of the waves increases and spray shoots into the air. A whirlpool forms {@dice 1d4 × 10} feet away from characters or their ship, the pull of which can immediately be felt.

The whirlpool forms a vortex that is 5 feet wide at the base, 50 feet wide at the top, and 25 feet tall. Any creature or object in the water and within 25 feet of the vortex is pulled 10 feet toward it. A creature can swim away from the vortex with a successful DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. A ship can be rowed away if the crew succeed on a the same group check.

A creature or object that enters the vortex for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there must make a DC 15 Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes {@damage 2d8} bludgeoning damage and is caught in the vortex. On a successful save, the creature takes half damage and isn't caught. A creature caught in the vortex can use its action to try to escape from the vortex as described above but has disadvantage on the Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check to do so. A ship's crew can attempt the same group check.
A creature pulled beneath the waves must hold its breath or begin to drown (see chapter 8 of the {@i Player's Handbook} for rules on "{@quickref Suffocating||2}").

footnotes.name: Aldani
entries: The characters are shadowed by {@dice 1d4} {@creature aldani (lobsterfolk)|Toa|aldani} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}), which are noticed by any character with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 12 or higher. The aldani don't communicate with others unless they must, and they won't fight unless the characters refuse to take a bribe to leave the area. The aldani aid the characters only if they're offered something of great value in return–for example, an offer to drive off a pack of predatory sahuagin encroaching on their territory.

footnotes.name: Coelenites
entries: The characters are attacked by {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature coelenite|BelzorMM|coelenites} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}) who try and pull them down into the water and drown them. The {@creature coelenite|BelzorMM|coelenites} try to avoid leaving the ocean if possible but foray onto the shore or climb aboard boats to pursue their prey.

entries.name: Higher Levels
entries: If the characters are 4th level or higher, replace one of the {@creature coelenite|BelzorMM|coelenites} with a {@creature coelenite mass mind|BelzorMM} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}). The {@creature coelenite|BelzorMM|coelenites} telepathically threaten the characters with drowning unless they provide a tribute of food. The {@creature coelenite|BelzorMM|coelenites} can be appeased with food (four day's supply per coelenite in the group). Otherwise, they attack.

footnotes.name: Dolphins
entries: The characters spot a pod of {@dice 3d4} {@creature dolphin|vgm|dolphins} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}). If the characters are above the surface of the water, they notice the beautiful creatures leaping between the waves. They are naturally inquisitive and might come within 10 feet of the boat to take a look.

A {@creature dolphin|vgm} that is successfully {@condition grappled}, caught in a {@item net|phb}, or otherwise prevented from escaping can be trained as a mount by a character with proficiency in {@skill Animal Handling} who spends a few hours a day working with the mammal. At the end of 1 week, the character makes a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check. On a success, the dolphin becomes a willing mount for any humanoid.

footnotes.name: Floating Debris
entries: The characters notice something floating one hundred feet away. A successful DC 16 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check reveals the nature of the debris. Roll a {@dice d6}:

items.name: 1–3.
entries: Barrels and crates.

items.name: 4–5.
entries: Shattered wooden planks.
Chests.

entries.name: Barrels and Crates
entries: Bobbing on the waves are {@dice 4d4} crates and {@item barrel|phb|barrels} filled with goods. These may contain alcohol, {@item rations (1 day)|phb|rations}, rope or other basic items typically found aboard ships.

entries.name: Shattered Wooden Planks
entries: Planks of shattered wood float atop the ocean. Clearly, these are remnants of a ship which has been recently attacked and perhaps destroyed. There is a {@chance 50} chance that a pirate ship is nearby (see "Pirate Ship" in this section).

entries.name: Chests
entries: Mostly sunk beneath the water's surface are {@dice 1d4} {@item chest|phb|chests}. These must have been jettisoned from another vessel. The {@item chest|phb|chests} are locked and keyless and require a successful DC 14 Dexterity check with {@item thieves' tools|phb} or a successful DC 16 Strength check to open. Inside are valuable items worth 100 gp, such as money, gems, candlesticks, jewellery and the like. There is a {@chance 10} chance that the chest contains a more expensive item worth 250 gp, such as a gemstone or {@table 250 gp art objects|dmg|art object}. This could be replaced with a magic item (roll once on {@table Magic Item Table A} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

footnotes.name: Giant Crab
entries: A {@creature giant crab} scuttles out from a kelp forest or coastal cave and attacks a random character. The target is surprised unless they have a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 14 or higher. The crab attempts to {@action grapple} the character, then drop overboard with them and drown them (see "{@quickref Suffocating||2}" in chapter 8 of the {@i Player's Handbook}). If the encounter occurs at sea, the crab claws its way up the hull to ambush the character.

entries.name: Higher Levels
entries: If the characters are above 4th level, consider using a {@creature hulking crab|SKT} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}).

footnotes.name: Giant Lightning Eel
entries: A {@creature giant lightning eel|tftyp} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}) shoots out from a coral reef or rocky crevasse to attack a random character. The character targeted by the eel is surprised unless they have a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 13 or higher.

footnotes.name: Giant Octopus
entries: A {@creature giant octopus} shows some curiosity in the characters. The intelligent animal uses its dextrous tentacles to search their backpacks for food or curious treasures that it can steal away to its hoard. So long as the characters don't attack it, the octopus is not hostile. If the octopus finds a {@item rations (1 day)|phb|ration} or shiny treasure on the characters, it attempts to steal it. The octopus makes a Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) check against the characters passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}). If the octopus succeeds, it steals the item and swims back to its lair.

entries.name: Higher Levels
entries: If the characters are above 5th level, consider using a colossal octopus ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}).

footnotes.name: Giant Sea Horses
entries: The characters encounter {@dice 1d4} friendly {@creature giant sea horse|mm|giant sea horses}. Like their smaller kin, giant sea horses are shy, colourful fish with elongated bodies and curled tails. These creatures are often trained as mounts by aquatic elves.

A giant sea horse that is {@condition grappled}, caught in a {@item net|phb}, or otherwise prevented from escaping can be trained as a mount by a character with proficiency in {@skill Animal Handling}. At the end of 1 week with the animal, the character makes a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check. On a success, the giant sea horse becomes a willing mount for any humanoid.

footnotes.name: Giant Shark
entries: A {@creature giant shark} surges through the water toward the party and attacks a random character. The size of the creature makes it impossible to miss, and the characters each have a turn to try and flee or {@action hide} before it arrives and attacks. Giant sharks are 30 feet long and utterly fearless.

entries.name: Ships
entries: If this encounter occurs while the characters are on a ship, the giant shark attacks whatever vessel the characters are on. These enormous fish are capable of sinking smaller ships but are just as likely to ram larger ones to try and knock unsuspecting crew overboard. If the shark rams the ship, and characters on deck must make a DC 16 Dexterity saving throw or be thrown overboard.

footnotes.name: Giant Spider
entries: The characters are ambushed by a {@creature giant spider}.

entries.name: Sea
entries: Whilst travelling through an area of low visibility, such as a rocky crevasse or a coral reef, a random character is attacked by a {@creature giant spider} with a swim speed of 30 ft. The character is surprised unless they have a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 17 or higher.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: If the characters succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check, they can track back to the spider's lair; a sheltered cave covered in sticky webs with corpses hanging from the ceiling. There is a {@chance 25} chance that one of these corpses has a magic item, determined by rolling on {@table Magic Item Table B} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

footnotes.name: Kelpie
entries: A hypnotic {@creature kelpie|tftyp} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}), an intelligent, aquatic plant that resembles a pile of seaweed, tries to lure one of the characters to their death. The {@creature kelpie|tftyp} can take the form of a {@filter Small, Medium or Large beast or humanoid|bestiary|size=S;M;L|type=beast;humanoid}, and uses this to its advantage, posing as a desirable creature such as a giant sea horse, or a stranded commoner drowning in rough seas.

footnotes.name: Killer Whales
entries: The party is attacked by a pod of {@dice 1d4 + 2} {@creature killer whale|mm|killer whales} who surge toward them through the water. If the characters are on a vessel that couldn't be capsized by the orcas, they simply notice them hunting not far from the ship.

footnotes.name: Kraken Sighting
entries: A huge shadow passes beneath the vessel on which the party sail. A successful DC 16 Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) or Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check allows characters to realise that the form is a {@creature kraken}. It pays no attention to the ship unless attacked by the crew.
Obviously, any crew members who notice the beast are be terrified, fleeing into the belly of the ship, muttering prayers or climbing up rigging.

If you wish, the kraken could be {@creature Slarkrethel|SKT} (see {@adventure chapter 5|BelzorMM|9} for his full statistics). This gives the characters the chance to realise that not all is well with the kraken, thanks to the exposed brain, which is actually Zellix'Phor the {@creature elder brain|vgm}.

footnotes.name: Lycanthropes
entries: Depending on where the characters are exploring, they come across one or more lycanthropes. The lycanthropes might be initially encountered in their animal, hybrid, or humanoid form depending on the focus of the encounter.

entries.name: Coast, Sea & Underwater
entries: The characters encounter a {@creature wereshark|BelzorMM} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}) hunting during the day or camping at night. Weresharks are loners and tend to be rude or hostile. If a {@creature wereshark|BelzorMM} gets a taste for humanoid flesh, it takes great mental fortitude to oppress the urge to kill.

footnotes.name: Mephits
entries: The characters might encounter {@creature dust mephit|mm|dust mephits}, {@creature ice mephit|mm|ice mephits}, {@creature mud mephit|mm|mud mephits}, or {@creature steam mephit|mm|steam mephits} (each appearing as a group of {@dice 2d6}). The mephits don't attack unless they outnumber the characters two to one, but they're reluctant to be helpful unless they themselves are outnumbered.

footnotes.name: Merfolk
entries: Emerging from the depths are a group of {@dice 2d6 + 2} {@creature merfolk} traders. These peaceful, water-dwelling folk come to the surface in order to trade with passing ships. They don't value gold but instead delight in useful magical items or metal weapons that they lack the ability to craft. In return, they can offer treasures of the deep such as {@item pearl|dmg|pearls}, necklaces, and armour made of corals, glowing jellyfish in glass jars and magic potions. They may also have strange artifacts that they have scavenged from the depths such as parts of the crash-landed Illithid ship. Crew members often become infatuated with {@creature merfolk} and go on about them for days after the encounter.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The merfolk group carry treasures worth 250 gp. There is a {@chance 50} chance that they carry {@dice 1d4} magic items, determined by rolling on {@table Magic Item Table A} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

footnotes.name: Merrow
entries: The characters encounter {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature merrow} in the depths. They hunt humanoids in fishing vessels or on the coast. Their main tactic is to harpoon creatures into the water and drown them, taking their corpses down to underwater grottoes to feed. There is a {@chance 25} chance that the merrow have {@dice 1d4} {@creature merfolk} prisoners with them, bound in thick kelp rope. The {@creature merfolk} are from a nearby settlement where the characters could take refuge should they choose to free the prisoners.

footnotes.name: Nereid
entries: The characters encounter a {@creature nereid|tftyp} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}); a fey creature of otherworldly beauty. There is a {@chance 50} chance that the neried is good aligned and can help guide the characters through the next leg of their journey or point them in the direction of a previously unknown location. An evil aligned nereid convinces the characters into believing that they are good before using their drowning kiss and aquatic invisibility to launch a deadly surprise attack.

footnotes.name: Ruins
entries: The adventurers come across a small ruin; the remains of a wizard tower, a dilapidated dwarven mine, an abandoned goblinoid fort, a destroyed aquatic elf city beneath the waves, or a sunken ship. If the characters camp here, and the ruins are not already occupied (see below), they can finish a long rest with no chance of an encounter.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: There is a {@chance 50} chance the ruins are inhabited; {@creature sahuagin baron} on the coast, {@dice 1d4 - 1} {@creature owlbear|mm|owlbears} in the forest, {@dice 2d4} of {@creature centaur} in grasslands, an {@creature ettin} in hills or moors, a {@creature nothic} by the roadside, or {@dice 1d4 - 1} {@creature sea lion|tftyp|sea lions} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}) underwater.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: If the ruins are home to a creature, there is treasure within. If not, there is still a {@chance 50} chance that the ruins contain treasure. Roll a {@dice d20}:

items.name: 1–10.
items.entry: A humanoid skeleton clad in rusted armour holding a {@item silvered weapon|phb|silvered, nonmagical weapon} (your choice) with {@dice 1d4} magic items in a mouldy satchel (roll on {@table Magic Item Table A} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

items.name: 11–15.
items.entry: A humanoid corpse clutching a weapon (your choice) and a pouch containing {@dice 3d4} 50 gp gems.

items.name: 15–17.
items.entry: A smashed {@item chest|phb} containing a dozen battered books, {@dice 1d4} {@item trinket|phb|trinkets} (see chapter 5, "{@book Equipment|phb|6|Trinkets}" of the {@i Player's Handbook}) and {@dice 1d4} magic items (roll on {@table Magic Item Table B} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

items.name: 18–19.
items.entry: A monster hoard containing {@dice 2d6} 50 gp gems and {@dice 1d4} magic items (roll on {@table Magic Item Table C} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).
A slain adventurer atop a monster hoard containing {@dice 3d4} 50 gp gems and {@dice 1d4} magic items (roll on {@table Magic Item Table D} in chapter 7 on the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

footnotes.name: Sahuagin
entries: The party encounter a gang of {@dice 2d4 + 2} {@creature sahuagin} accompanied by {@dice 1d4 + 2} {@creature hunter shark|mm|hunter sharks}. There is a {@chance 20} chance that the hunting party is led by a {@creature sahuagin priestess} or a {@creature sahuagin raider|BelzorMM} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}). The {@creature sahuagin} attempt to throw characters into the water where the {@creature hunter shark|mm|sharks} viciously maul them. {@creature Sahuagin} have a hatred for elves, and always attack elven characters first if possible.

The sea devils have been stirred up by the influence of Zellix'Phor. Previously, the {@creature sahuagin} had little to do with Slarkrethel but since the discovery of the nautiloid crash, things have changed. Pieces of strange mind flayer technology have made their way into the hands of the {@creature sahuagin}, who have distributed it throughout their tribes, spreading the influence of the elder brain. The sea devils may carry with them {@item spear|phb|spears} made of strange metal, foreign tablets with {@language Qualith|vgm} inscriptions, or even weapons created by the illithid for them (see {@book Volo's Guide to Monsters|vgm|0|Mind Flayers: Scourge of Worlds}).
{@creature Sahuagin} carry exotic weapons adorned with pearls, coral and other naturally beautiful items. Each weapon is worth twice its normal value.
entries.name: Treasure

footnotes.name: Salty Sea Dogs
entries: Whilst travelling the high seas, the party encounter an NPC (or group thereof) who provide the chance for roleplay, gaining allies, making enemies, or gathering information:

entries.name: Flotsam & Jetsam
entries: (CN male and female {@creature goblin|mm|goblins}) This pair of {@creature goblin|mm|goblins} have fashioned themselves a barely seaworthy vessel from an old {@item barrel|phb}, using a tablecloth for a sail. They both have the additional skill: {@skill Sleight of Hand} {@dice 1d20+6|+6} and are kleptomaniacs. The {@creature goblin|mm|goblins} can become steadfast allies, who happily accompany the crew rather than remain in their dangerous little boat. They are also willing to "... swashbuckle..." alongside the characters but might not be able to resist pinching a particularly shiny piece of treasure from them should the opportunity arise.

entries.name: Anka
entries: (NN female {@creature anka|BelzorMM|ogre} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12})). Previously the first mate of the notorious Captain Callous, {@creature Anka|BelzorMM} made her last dim-witted mistake upon 'The Devil's Fin' and was forced to walk the plank by the captain. The characters encounter her 'starfished' on her back in the water, desperately trying to stay afloat. {@creature Anka|BelzorMM|Anka's} left arm has been replaced with a huge anchor which is slowly dragging her down. If saved, {@creature Anka|BelzorMM} temporarily allies with the characters, helping them track Captain Callous. Despite this, a successful DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check by Captain Callous causes her to come back to his side.

entries.name: T'zen'lix
entries: (LE male {@creature neogi|vgm}). T'zen'lix is an alien, spiderlike creature from the Astral Plane that accidently ended up here after stowing away on the nautiloid. When it crashlanded, 'Lix managed to enslave a farmer from Gundarlun and escape. Since then, 'Lix has been on a whirlwind ride discovering that wanton control over living beings often ends in sticky situations. 'Lix mostly wants to get back to the Astral Plane and joins together with the characters if they can help him achieve this goal. 'Lix doesn't think twice about mind controlling the characters to alleviate even the smallest of stresses for himself.

entries.name: Mei Ling
entries: (LE female {@creature vampire} with a swim speed of 30 ft.) Mei Ling is a vampire who lives in the underwater ruins of Narino, north of Mintarn. Normally Mei Ling feeds on the blood of merfolk and sea elves, but from time to time she rises from her underwater lair to sample Tarnian blood and make mischief. She might clamber aboard the ship and drain the blood of a Tarnian crew member, try to sabotage the vessel, or turn the cabin boy into a {@creature vampire spawn}. Mei Ling doesn't consider the ocean to be running water. For more information about Mei Ling and Narino, see "{@adventure Open Lord Dagult Neverember's Quest|BelzorMM|3|Dagult Neverember's Quest|0}" in {@adventure chapter 2|BelzorMM|3}.

entries.name: Toroa
entries: (CN female Chultan human {@creature war priest|vgm} of Kahulla) Hailing from a far-flung island nation south of the Sword Coast, Toroa belongs to The Chosen of the Stormheart, an order of clerics sent out into the world to chase down the largest storms and commune with their patron goddess Kahulla, an aspect of {@deity Talos|Faerûnian|scag}. Toroa is hot on the tail of an enormous tempest that is, unbeknownst to her, a {@creature storm giant quintessent|vgm}. Torora has dusky skin, electric blue hair and a preference for lightning magic.

footnotes.name: Sea Hags
entries: The characters encounter three {@creature sea hag|mm|sea hags} that comprise a coven. Their favourite trick is to pretend to be stranded or wounded peasants in need of rescue in a damaged or beached rowboat.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: If the characters defeat the {@creature sea hag|mm|sea hags} and search the area, roll twice on {@table Magic Item Table A} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} to determine what they find. Whatever treasure the hags have is stowed inside a rotted wooden {@item chest|phb}.

footnotes.name: Sea Lions
entries: The characters encounter {@dice 1d3} {@creature sea lion|tftyp|sea lions} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}); fearsome monsters with the head and forepaws of a lion and the lower body and tail of a fish. If this encounter occurs during the day, they are hunting a group of {@creature dolphin|vgm|dolphins} or a whale. If the encounter occurs at night, they are guarding their lair which contains {@dice 2d4} {@creature sea cub|BelzorMM|sea cubs} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}). {@creature sea cub|BelzorMM|Sea cubs} are a prized pet among fishing communities and can be sold for 50 gp.

footnotes.name: Sea Spawn
entries: The characters come across {@dice 3d4 + 2} {@creature sea spawn|BelzorMM}. These disturbing, piscine humanoids are the creation of Slarkrethel the kraken. There is a {@chance 25} chance that these {@creature sea spawn|BelzorMM} have prisoners in tow. A sample group of prisoners is presented here, but you can create others.

The prisoners are {@dice 1d4 + 1} Northlander human {@creature commoner|mm|commoners} from Uttersea on Tuern. The strongest among them is a young woman named Nadya Greenrock. The {@creature sea spawn|BelzorMM} raided the town of Uttersea during the night, slipping past the guards thanks to their humanoid forms. They slipped into the houses of the local folk and kidnapped them from their beds. The {@creature sea spawn|BelzorMM} are taking the prisoners to Ascarle to be consumed by the Illithid colony. The prisoners can survive underwater thanks to the {@spell water breathing} spell cast by one of the {@creature sea spawn|BelzorMM}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The {@creature sea spawn|BelzorMM} have {@dice 1d3 - 1} {@item spell scroll (3rd level)|dmg|spell scrolls} of {@spell water breathing} among them. If the characters can rescue the Tuernish villagers and escort them back to Uttersea, they are rewarded by High King Ossul Haarn with a {@item longship|BelzorMM} named 'Flamescale'.

footnotes.name: Sharks
entries: The characters are attacked by either {@dice 1d3} {@creature hunter shark|mm|hunter sharks} or {@dice 2d4} {@creature reef shark|mm|reef sharks} depending on what variety of location they are in. Characters in large ships that could not be capsized by the sharks can easily avoid this encounter, so consider having it occur at a later date when a character or crew member has fallen overboard.

footnotes.name: Storm Giant
entries: Looming up ahead of the characters, either rising from the water, sailing in an enormous dinghy or lumbering along the sea floor is a lone {@creature storm giant}. {@creature Storm giant|mm|Storm giants} are typically good aligned and willing to help the characters if they explain their situation. A successful DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check is enough to convince a giant to fight with the party during their next combat. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, the giant can escort the characters to Maelstrom (see "Maelstrom" in chapter 3).

footnotes.name: Treant
entries: The characters hear a crashing from the forest and spot a {@creature treant} from a safe distance away. The {@creature treant} has been awoken by a shift in the natural balance and is confused by the changing cycle. There is a {@chance 50} chance that the {@creature treant} is curious and friendly, or confused and angry.

entries.name: Underwater
entries: The {@creature treant} resembles a giant anemone.

entries.name: Repeat Encounters
entries: Instead of a {@creature treant}, you can replace this encounter with a {@creature shambling mound} that stealthily makes its way toward camped characters, or lies in wait beside a trail for them to draw near. When encountered underwater, a {@creature shambling mound} resembles a coralencrusted heap covered in seaweed.

footnotes.name: Trolls
entries: The characters are ambushed by {@dice 1d2} {@creature troll|mm|trolls}. They attack from behind ridges, thickets, and even kelp forests. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 11 or higher notice the {@creature troll|mm|trolls} from a safe distance and can attempt to flee, otherwise the characters are surprised.

entries.name: Sea & Underwater
entries: Saltwater trolls are called {@creature scrag|BelzorMM|scrags}. They use the {@creature troll} stat block with the following changes:

items: Scrags have a swim speed of 30 feet.

items.name: Amphibious
entries: The scrag can breathe air and water.

items.name: Aquatic Regeneration
entries: The scrag regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn if it fully submerged in water. If the scrag takes acid or fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the scrag's next turn. The scrag only dies if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

footnotes.name: Vodyanoi
entries: The characters encounter a {@creature vodyanoi|BelzorMM} ({@adventure appendix B|BelzorMM|12}) which attacks a random character or their ship. These relatives of the {@creature umber hulk} are capable of punching through ship hulls or capsizing smaller vessels.

footnotes.name: Whirlpool
entries: The roar of the waves increases and spray shoots into the air. A whirlpool forms {@dice 1d4 × 10} feet away from characters or their ship, the pull of which can immediately be felt.

The whirlpool forms a vortex that is 5 feet wide at the base, 50 feet wide at the top, and 25 feet tall. Any creature or object in the water and within 25 feet of the vortex is pulled 10 feet toward it. A creature can swim away from the vortex with a successful DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. A ship can be rowed away if the crew succeed on a the same group check.

A creature or object that enters the vortex for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there must make a DC 15 Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes {@damage 2d8} bludgeoning damage and is caught in the vortex. On a successful save, the creature takes half damage and isn't caught. A creature caught in the vortex can use its action to try to escape from the vortex as described above but has disadvantage on the Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check to do so. A ship's crew can attempt the same group check.
A creature pulled beneath the waves must hold its breath or begin to drown (see chapter 8 of the {@i Player's Handbook|phb} for rules on "{@quickref Suffocating||2}").

table.caption: Ship Crew
table.name: Random Ships & Crew; Ship Crew
rows: Elf {@creature veteran|mm|veterans}, elf {@creature veteran} with 90 hit points
{@creature lizardfolk}, {@creature lizard king|mm|lizardfolk king}/{@creature lizard queen|mm|queen}

entries.name: Merchant
entries: Merchant ships typically belong to a trading company, such as the Scaly Eye Merchant Company. They are commonly captained by wealthy traders who buy and sell wares in major cities. Their crew are often hired mercenaries from factions such as the Zhentarim or Flaming Fists. Most mercenary crews have neutral alignments.

entries.name: Naval
entries: Naval ships are those belonging to an organised force, such as the White Sails Mercenary Company of Mintarn or the Waterdhavian Navy. Naval ships are most often encountered patrolling major sea lanes for pirates. Most naval crews have lawful-good or -evil alignments.

entries.name: Pirate
entries: Pirate ships are those crewed by criminals and cutthroats. They range from organised bands of Zhentarim thugs to bloodthirsty monstrous humanoids in longboats eager for slaughter and plunder. Pirate ships always attack smaller ships they think they can board. Most pirate crews have chaotic-evil or -neutral alignments.

entries.name: Trade
entries: Trade ships are those such as fishers, whalers, and professional treasure hunters. They differ from merchant ships in that they are actually engaged in a craft of some kind, rather than trading one resource for another. Most trade crews have lawful alignments.

table.name: Random Ships & Crew; Ship Treasure
table.caption: Ship Treasure
rows: {@dice #$prompt_number:min=1,title=Number of crew,default=10$#d4|1d4} gp per crew plus 250 gp of treasure items
{@dice #$prompt_number:min=1,title=Number of crew,default=10$#d6|1d6} gp per crew plus 500 gp of treasure items
{@dice #$prompt_number:min=1,title=Number of crew,default=10$#d6|1d6} gp per crew plus {@dice 1d4} items from {@table Magic Item Table A}
{@dice #$prompt_number:min=1,title=Number of crew,default=10$#d6|1d6} gp per crew plus {@dice 1d4} items from {@table Magic Item Table B}
{@dice #$prompt_number:min=1,title=Number of crew,default=10$#d6|1d6} gp per crew plus {@dice 1d4} items from {@table Magic Item Table C}

table.name: Random Ships & Crew; Ship Type
table.caption: Ship Type
footnotes: {@note Note that {@adventure Call from the Deep|BelzorMM|14} uses a simplified version of the rules presented in {@adventure Ghosts of Saltmarsh|GoS|8}. You may wish to use those {@variantrule Ship Stat Blocks|GoS|rules} and their respective {@filter stat blocks|vehicles|source=GoS} instead.}

trap.name: Combat Training
entries: This combat training facility was designed by Luzgrigaul. The facility pitches the trainee against animated constructs, whilst making them dodge jets of flame erupting from the floor and spinning blades which scythe the room.
trigger: The chamber door locks behind anyone who enters. Unless immediately opened, the trap activates.
eActive: Combat Training involves construct combatants, jets of flame, and scything blades.

items.name: Counter Combatants (Initiative 20).
entries: Five {@creature combat training construct|BelzorMM|constructs} emerge from the secret trap door and attack the creature with the highest Intelligence. They use {@creature helmed horror} statistics with the {@footnote following changes|Included in the linked statblock.}:

items: They are immune to fire damage, and the following spells: {@spell cone of cold}, {@spell ice storm}, {@spell lightning bolt}.
Their longsword attacks deal an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) psychic damage, and they can {@action shove} a creature within 5 feet of them as a bonus action.

items.name: Flame Jets (Initiative 10).
items.entry: Fire shoots from the holes in the floor. Each creature standing on the floor takes 11 ({@damage 2d10}) fire damage.

items.name: Scything Blades (Initiative 5).
items.entry: Psionically charged blades swarm toward non-construct creatures in the room. Each non-construct creature must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) slashing damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful save.

eDynamic: The flame jets become more dangerous the longer the trap remains active.

items.name: Added Fuel.
items.entry: The damage from the Flame Jets element increases by 11 ({@damage 2d10}) each round after it activates, to a maximum of 55 ({@damage 10d10}).

eConstant: A creature that starts its turn on the floor must make a {@footnote saving throw|No information about the ability or DC is provided. I recommend a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw.} against the Flame Jets.
countermeasures: There are a few ways the trap can be overcome:

items.name: Open the Door.
items.entry: The door is locked with a Qualith door lock (see "{@adventure Additional Features: Illithid Lair|BelzorMM|9|Qualith Door Locks|0}"). Any creature that leaves the room is no longer affected by the trap. If all creatures leave the room, the trap resets.

items.name: Plug the Jets.
items.entry: A creature can use an action to plug a 5-foot square of holes from which the flame jets burst with a non-flammable material, such as cloth soaked in water. The flame jets no longer function in that area.

items.name: Dispel the Blades.
items.entry: The swarming blades are powered by psionics. A creature can {@action ready} an action to cast {@spell dispel magic} (DC 15) on the blades as they swarm. Doing so reduces the DC to avoid the blades by 3. When the DC drops to 0, the blades deactivate.

items.name: Kill the Constructs
items.entry: Killing all five helmed horrors causes the trap to deactivate.

trap.name: Drown in Sorrow
entries: This magical trap was enchanted by Granny Saltwood to prevent people stealing her magic items. The trap causes the cavern in to fill with water and animates lengths of rope to restrain and drown intruders.
trigger: The trap activates when a character who is not Granny Saltwood touches her chest of magic items.
eActive: Drown in Sorrow fills the room with sea water and other effects.

items.name: Door Slams (Initiative 20).
items.entry: The false wall slams shut. This effect occurs once, the first time the trap activates.

items.name: Crashing Waves (Initiative 20).
items.entry: The room fills with the sound of crashing waves. Each creature must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or become deafened by the sound. This effect occurs once, the first time the trap activates.

items.name: Hangman's Noose (Initiative 20).
items.entry: Reels of rope wound about the cavern animate and lash out toward the characters. They attack each creature with a {@hit +5} bonus to the attack roll, dealing 5 ({@dice 1d10}) slashing damage on a hit. In addition, the creature is {@condition grappled} by the ropes (escape DC 15). If a creature is {@condition grappled} by the ropes on initiative 20 it is not attacked, but must succeed on a DC 15 Strength or Dexterity saving throw or become {@condition restrained}.

items.name: Surging Seawater (Initiative 10).
items.entry: The cavern begins to fill with seawater at a rate of 10 feet per round (on the first initiative 10 it rises to 10 feet, then 20, then 30, which fills the cavern).

countermeasures: There are a few ways that the trap can be overcome.

items.name: Open the False Wall.
items.entry: Opening the false wall disables the trap, but it is warded with magic. To open the doors the characters must first make a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check to find the handle. After that, a successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check opens the door. Each check requires an action.

items.name: Hangman's Noose.
items.entry: Characters can slash at or snap the ropes. The ropes cease to be animated if their total attack bonus from attacks and checks reaches {@hit +0}.

items.name: Attack.
items.entry: A creature in the cavern can slash at the ropes. The ropes have AC 11 and 5 hit points. Destroying a rope reduces the Hangman's Noose attack bonus by 1.

items.name: Strength Check DC 15.
items.entry: Creatures can use raw strength to snap the ropes. A successful check reduces the Hangman's Noose attack bonus by 1.

items.name: Enchanted Chest.
items.entry: A successful casting of {@spell dispel magic} upon the chest disables the trap.

trap.name: Electric Panels
entries: A 10-foot-square panel fills with an electric current. Each companion on the panel must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or take 1d6 lightning damage and become paralyzed until the end of their next turn.

trap.name: Ethereal Platforms
entries: One of the platforms above the arena briefly enters the ethereal plane, causing any companion on it to fall. The platform reappears at the start of the next round.

trap.name: Flame Throwers
entries: 1d6 holes in the side of the arena shoot fire out in a 10-foot line. Each companion in the area must succeed on a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw or take 1d4 fire damage.

trap.name: Fog Burst
entries: An explosion of thick fog fills a 20-foot-square area and remains for 1d4 rounds. While the fog persists, any companion inside of it is considered heavily obscured.

trap.name: Grasping Ice
entries: A small pool of 4 inch deep water covers a 10-foot-square platform, and then instantly freezes over. Each companion in the area must succeed on a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw or take 1d6 cold damage and become restrained until the end of its next turn.

trap.name: Kraken's Arms
entries: This trap was designed by the Kraken Society to prevent intruders getting into this section of Slarkrethel's lair.
trigger: This trap activates if a creature not wearing a Kraken Society symbol enters the corridor, and stays active while such a creature remains within.
eActive: The Kraken's Arms includes grasping tentacles along the first 60 feet, acidic water throughout, and an idol of fear in its final 30 feet.

items.name: Grasping Tentacles (Initiative 20).
items.entry: The tentacles attack each creature in the first 70 feet of the hallway with a {@hit 8} bonus to the attack roll. A target hit by the attack takes 22 ({@damage 4d10}) bludgeoning damage and is {@condition grappled} (escape DC 15).

items.name: Acidic Water (Initiative 10).
items.entry: Each creature in the corridor must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw, taking 5 ({@damage 1d10}) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

items.name: Idol of Fear (Initiative 10).
items.entry: Each creature in the 30-foot-long area beyond the Grasping Tentacles must make a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature becomes {@condition frightened} of the idol, and must immediately use its action to move its speed toward the tentacles. The {@condition frightened} creature can't move closer to the idol until it uses its action to make a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw, ending the condition on itself on a success.

eDynamic: The acid and idol become more dangeorus the longer the trap remains active.

items.name: Acid Increases.
items.entry: More acid is pumped into the corridor. After its turn, the Acidic Water damage increases by 5 ({@damage 1d10}), to a maximum of 55 ({@damage 10d10}).

items.name: Idol's Defence.
items.entry: Tampering with the Idol of Fear causes a psychic wave. Each successful check made to disable the idol causes a 30-foot cone of energy to blast from it. Each creature in the area must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) psychic damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

eConstant: The Grasping Tentacles and Idol of Fear affect each creature that ends its turn in the area affected by these elements.

items.name: Grasping Tentacles.
items.entry: Any creature that ends its turn in the tentacles' area is targeted by an attack: {@hit 5} attack bonus, 5 ({@damage 1d10}) bludgeoning damage on a hit.

items.name: Idol of Fear.
items.entry: Any creature that ends its turn within 30 feet of the idol must make a saving throw against the Idol of Fear effect.

countermeasures: Each of the trap's active elements can be thwarted by particular countermeasures.

items.name: Grasping Tentacles.
items.entry: Characters can sever the tentacles, attempt to dispel them, or dodge them. The tentacles disappear if their attack bonus is reduced to {@hit -8}. Ways to reduce it are described below:

items.name: Dexterity (Acrobatics), DC 15.
items.entry: As an action, a creature that can see the tentacles can attempt a Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check. A successful check allows the character to dodge the tentacles' failing, imposing disadvantage on the tentacles' attacks against the creature while it isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

items.name: Attack.
items.entry: A creature in the area can {@action ready} an attack against one of the tentacles as it goes by. The tentacle gains advantage on its attack against the creature. The creature then attacks. Each tentalce has AC 15 and 15 hit points. Destroying a tentacle reduces the Grasping Tentalces attack bonus by 2.

items.name: Intelligence (Arcana) check, DC 15.
items.entry: Creatures can use their knowledge of magic to attempt to dispel the shadowy tentacles. A successful check reduces the Grasping Tentacles attack bonus by 2.

items.name: Acidic Water.
items.entry: Characters can attempt to neutralise the acid or to block the holes from which it leaks:

items.name: Neutralise.
items.entry: A creature can reset the Acid Water damage to 0 by casting {@spell purify food and drink} or similar magic.

items.name: Block the Holes.
items.entry: There are four sets of holes through which the acid is pumped. A creature can use an action to make a DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check, finding a set of holes on each success. A subsequent action can be used to plug the holes with shredded cloth. Once all four sets are plugged, the Acidic Waters damage cannot increase.

items.name: Idol of Fear
items.entry: The idol can be dispelled or destroyed:

items.name: Dispel.
items.entry: The idol can be dispelled with three successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) checks. Each check requires an action. A creature must be within 5 feet of the idol to attempt this check, and only one creature can work on this task at any one time. Alternatively, the idol can be disabled with three successful {@spell dispel magic} (DC 15) spells.

items.name: Destroy.
items.entry: The idol has AC 15, 50 hit points, immunity to poison and psychic damage, and resistance to all nonmagical damage.

trap.name: Kraken's Maw
entries: This trap was constructed to prevent tomb robbers infiltrating the resting place of Vestress. It is a {@footnote corridor|150 feet long and 10 feet wide in {@adventure the adventure|BelzorMM}.} that fills with surging water, black ink, and crushing teeth.
trigger: This trap activates as soon as a non-Krakenar enters the {@footnote marked area|Two 10-foot squares 20 feet apart, on either side of the Crushing Teeth area.} and it remains active while any non-Krakenar creature is within the area.
eActive: The Kraken's Maw includes a torrent of water and black ink throughout, plus smashing teeth in the central 20 feet.

items.name: Surging Water (Initiative 20).
items.entry: Water surges from north to south. Each creature in the hallway must make a DC 20 Strength saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 22 ({@damage 4d10}) bludgeoning damage, is knocked {@condition prone}, and pushed 30 feet south. On a successful save, the creature takes half the damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone} or shoved. The surging water is difficult terrain.

items.name: Ink Cloud (Initiative 20).
items.entry: The area between the {@footnote two triggers|Two 10-foot squares 20 feet apart, on either side of the Crushing Teeth area.} is filled with a cloud of ink. The area is heavily obscured as long as the trap remains active.

items.name: Crushing Teeth (Initiative 10).
items.entry: Each creature in the central 20 feet of the corridor must make a DC 20 Dexterity saving throw, taking 33 ({@damage 6d10}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

eConstant: Certain elements affect each creature that ends its turn in an area affected by them.

items.name: Surging Water.
items.entry: Any creature that ends its turn in the corridor must make a saving throw against the Surging Water effect.

items.name: Crushing Teeth.
items.entry: Any creature that ends its turn in the area affected by the Crushing Teeth must make a saving throw against its effect.

countermeasures: Each of the trap's active elements can be thwarted by particular countermeasures.

items.name: Open the Doors.
items.entry: To deactivate the trap, the doors to {@footnote {@adventure area 78|BelzorMM|9|78. Tomb of Vestress|0}|A room to one side of the corridor, about 35 feet from the expected entrace to the trap.} must be opened. To open the doors, a character must first succeed on a DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check to find the lock. A successful DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check disables the sphere of force surroudning the lock ({@spell dispel magic} also works). Success on a DC 20 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb} picks the lock. Finally, a successful DC 20 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check pushes the door open. Each check requires an action.

items.name: Ink Cloud.
items.entry: The ink can be disabled by blocking its flow. A successful DC 20 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}, or a DC 15 Strength check to block up the holes with a cloak of similar object, clears the ink in a 10-foot square.

items.name: Crushing Teeth.
items.entry: A successful DC 20 Strength check allows a character to prevent a set of the teeth activating provided they remain within 5 feet of them. Placing a {@item piton|phb} or similar item to prevent a set of teeth activating requires a successful DC 20 Intelligence check.

trap.name: Lava Panels
entries: A 10-foot-square panel drops into a bed of lava 5 feet below. Each companion on the panel must succeed on a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw or take 1d6 fire damage. The panel resurfaces at the start of the next round, but deals 1 fire damage to any companion that steps on it for the duration of that round.

trap.name: Levitating Panels
entries: One of the platforms above the arena moves up to 30 feet in a random direction to another space inside the arena.

trap.name: Mind Melter
entries: A lethal dose of psionic force is released when a crystal in the door is broken, sapping the intellect of nearby creatures.
trigger: Attempting to open the door triggers the trap.
effect: The triggering creature must make a DC 20 Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, the target's Intelligence score is reduced by {@dice 3d4}. The creature dies if this reduces its Intelligence to 0. Otherwise, the reduction lasts untli the creature benefits from {@spell greater restoration} or similar magic.
countermeasures: A successful DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check reveals a crystal embedded in the door's frame. A successful DC 20 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb} disables the crystal, but a check with a total of 10 or lower triggers the trap.

trap.name: Pincer Walls
entries: Two 10-square-foot walls appear and begin closing in on a 10x20 foot area. Each companion inside the area must succeed on a DC 12 Strength check or take 2d6 bludgeoning damage. The walls then crumble to dust.

trap.name: Pitfalls
entries: A 10-foot-square section of the arena floor becomes an illusion, hiding a 20-foot deep pit below it. Any companion attempting to cross it must succeed on a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw or take 2d6 bludgeoning damage and fall prone. At the start of the next round, the bottom of the pit rises up to replace the missing segment of the floor.

trap.name: Spikes
entries: Groups of spikes rise out of the ground in 4 separate areas in the arena, each 5 feet wide. Any companion standing above the spikes must succeed on a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw or take 1d6 piercing damage.

trap.name: Spinning Platforms
entries: One of the platforms above the arena begins to spin. Any companion not in the center of the platform must succeed on a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw or be flung off of the platform.

trap.name: Springboard
entries: 2 ({@dice 1d4}) 5-foot-square panels suddenly spring upward. Each companion standing on one of these panels must succeed on a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw or be launched 20 feet into the air.

trap.name: Toxic Gas
entries: Small holes on the surface of a 10-foot-square platform expel toxic gas that fills up a 5 foot area above them. Each companion in that area must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or take 1d8 poison damage.

trap.name: Weapon Flurry
entries: An assortment of light weapons such as daggers or handaxes fly out of an open panel, targeting any companion within a 15 foot line. Companions targeted by this trap must succeed on a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw or take 2d4 slashing damage. The weapons can be retrieved and used for the rest of the duel.

trap.name: Wrath of Undersea
entries: The wrath of Undersea is a deadly trap devised by the acolytes of {@deity Deep Sashelas|Elven|mtf} to protect their holy treasures.
trigger: This trap activates as soon as a creature not beraing a symbol of {@deity Deep Sashelas|Elven|mtf} enters the room, and remains active while such a creature is in the room.
eActive: The trap fills the room with a whirlpool and other deadly effects.

items.name: Sleep Spell (Initiative 20).
items.entry: The trap casts the {@spell sleep} spell at 9th level (94 ({@dice 21d8}) hit points).

items.name: Whirlpool (Initiative 20).
items.entry: A whirlpool forms centred on the bottom of the pit. Each creature in the room must make a DC 20 Strength saving throw. On a failed saving throw, the creature takes 33 ({@damage 6d10}) bludgeoning damage, is knocked {@condition prone}, and is pulled 30 feet toward the bottom of the pit. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone} or pulled.

items.name: Seaweed Growth (Initiative 10).
items.entry: A 5-foot-thick mat of seaweed grows to cover the pit.

eDynamic: The longer the whirlpool lasts, the more lethal it becomes.

items.name: Increased Velocity.
items.entry: The damage from the Whirlpool element increases by 11 ({@damage 2d10}) each round after it activates, to a maximum of 55 ({@damage 10d10}).

countermeasures: The trap can be thwarted in the following ways:

items.name: Whirlpool.
items.entry: Characters can use an action to brace themselves against the floor, wall, or ceiling. Doing so gives them advantage on the saving throw against the Whirlpool element until the start of their next turn.

items.name: Seaweed Mat.
items.entry: A 5-foot square section of the mat can be destroyed with either a successful DC 20 Strength check or by attacking it (AC 15, 15 hit points, immunity to poison and psychic damage).

items.name: Leave the Room
items.entry: The easiest way to deactivate the trap is to leave the room. Once the room is empty of triggering creatures, it deactivates.

variantrule.name: Farm Implements
entries: Farm implements are a tool category in which a PC may have proficiency. Most farm implements are also adventuring gear, as they have use outside a farm, and a few can also be weaponized, to create short-notice equipment for civilian militias.
Proficiency with these tools let you add your proficiency modifier to checks made to plow fields, harvest crops, sheer sheep or other strenuous farm activity. Normally these are Constitution checks.

Each different implement is purchased separately and used for one particular activity, but proficiency in farm implements gives you proficiency in all of these tools. The cost for farm implements covers storage and maintenance of the tools.
Examples include:

items: {@item Shovel|phb}
{@item Pitchfork|BelzorMM}
Scythe
{@item Sickle|phb}
Crook
Distaff
Lasso
Spade
Sod Saw
Horn Saw
Cattle Prod
Pruning Shears
Shearing Scissors

variantrule.name: Horror
entries: Horror involves more than simple fright. It entails revulsion and anguish. It arises when adventurers see something completely contrary to their understanding of the world, or upon the realisation of a dreadful truth.

In such a situation, you can call on the characters to make a Charisma saving throw to resist the horror. Disturbing events that occur on the islands have a DC noted next to them, but you can set the DC yourself based on the magnitude of the horrific circumstances. On a failed save, the character gains a {@table short-term madness} effect, or a {@table long-term madness|DMG|long-term} effect if the save fails by 5 or more, that you choose or determine randomly (see {@variantrule madness|dmg|chapter 8} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

variantrule.name: Sanity Scores
entries: If you want to leave a psychological scar on characters, and have their consent, you can introduce a new score: Sanity. A character's Sanity score equals their Wisdom modifier + Charisma modifier (minimum of 2). It is an indication of how well they can bear the consequences of confronting disturbing circumstances and resist the call of madness.
Characters can spend a Sanity point to help them succeed in certain situations. They can expend a point of Sanity to automatically succeed on:

items: An ability check to understand eldritch clues, such deciphering the mind-warping text on a shrine to Slarkrethel.
A Charisma saving throw to resist horror.

entries: Whenever a character gains a form of madness they lose a Sanity point. A {@spell greater restoration} spell restores a point of Sanity to a creature who still has at least one point remaining. If a character's Sanity is reduced to 0, they go indefinitely insane—their mind is so corrupted by horror that they cannot continue. The character might die of a heart attack, commit suicide, or be reduced to a gibbering mess. Any spell that brings a character back to life, such as {@spell raise dead}, restores the character and their Sanity score, but they return with a form of indefinite madness that cannot be removed short of a {@spell wish} spell. Choose or determine the madness from the table below:

entries.caption: Madness
colLabels: Flaw (lasts until cured by a {@spell wish} spell)
rows: "I adorn myself with fish skeletons, wash in sea water, and wear clothes of matted seaweed."
"I have been contacted by Slarkrethel, who speaks to me through my dreams."
"I am convinced I must immerse myself in salt water every eight hours or I will die."
"Defeating Slarkrethel is my only aim. Nothing will stand between me and my goal."
"I only eat raw fish and seaweed."
"I pick at my skin constantly, trying to find the scales and suckers that I know are underneath."
"The ocean terrifies me; being on the coast gives me jitters, being submerged would kill me."
"I am convinced that the Kraken Society are hunting me, and their agents watch me always."
"I see writhing tentacles in the shadows. They are horrors of the deep that want to devour me."
"I can't take anything seriously. The more serious the situation, the funnier I find it."
"Human sacrifice is the only way to appease the kraken, Slarkrethel."
